instance Amazonka.Data.ByteString.ToByteString Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance Amazonka.Data.Text.ToText Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance Amazonka.Data.Text.FromText Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance GHC.Classes.Ord Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortInfoSourceType.PortInfoSourceType


module Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.InstanceEntry

-- | Describes the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud instance and related
--   resources to be created using the <tt>create cloud formation
--   stack</tt> operation.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInstanceEntry</a> smart constructor.
data InstanceEntry
InstanceEntry' :: Maybe Text -> Text -> Text -> PortInfoSourceType -> Text -> InstanceEntry

-- | A launch script you can create that configures a server with
--   additional user data. For example, you might want to run <tt>apt-get
--   -y update</tt>.
--   
--   Depending on the machine image you choose, the command to get software
--   on your instance varies. Amazon Linux and CentOS use <tt>yum</tt>,
--   Debian and Ubuntu use <tt>apt-get</tt>, and FreeBSD uses <tt>pkg</tt>.
[$sel:userData:InstanceEntry'] :: InstanceEntry -> Maybe Text

-- | The name of the export snapshot record, which contains the exported
--   Lightsail instance snapshot that will be used as the source of the new
--   Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   Use the <tt>get export snapshot records</tt> operation to get a list
--   of export snapshot records that you can use to create a CloudFormation
--   stack.
[$sel:sourceName:InstanceEntry'] :: InstanceEntry -> Text

-- | The instance type (e.g., <tt>t2.micro</tt>) to use for the new Amazon
--   EC2 instance.
[$sel:instanceType:InstanceEntry'] :: InstanceEntry -> Text

-- | The port configuration to use for the new Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   The following configuration options are available:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>DEFAULT</tt> - Use the default firewall settings from the
--   Lightsail instance blueprint. If this is specified, then IPv4 and IPv6
--   will be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon
--   EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>INSTANCE</tt> - Use the configured firewall settings from the
--   source Lightsail instance. If this is specified, the new instance that
--   is created in Amazon EC2 will be configured to match the configuration
--   of the source Lightsail instance. For example, if the source instance
--   is configured for dual-stack (IPv4 and IPv6), then IPv4 and IPv6 will
--   be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon EC2. If
--   the source instance is configured for IPv4 only, then only IPv4 will
--   be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>NONE</tt> - Use the default Amazon EC2 security group. If this
--   is specified, then only IPv4 will be configured for the new instance
--   that is created in Amazon EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>CLOSED</tt> - All ports closed. If this is specified, then
--   only IPv4 will be configured for the new instance that is created in
--   Amazon EC2.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If you configured <tt>lightsail-connect</tt> as a
--   <tt>cidrListAliases</tt> on your instance, or if you chose to allow
--   the Lightsail browser-based SSH or RDP clients to connect to your
--   instance, that configuration is not carried over to your new Amazon
--   EC2 instance.
[$sel:portInfoSource:InstanceEntry'] :: InstanceEntry -> PortInfoSourceType

-- | The Availability Zone for the new Amazon EC2 instance.
[$sel:availabilityZone:InstanceEntry'] :: InstanceEntry -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>InstanceEntry</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:userData:InstanceEntry'</a>, <a>instanceEntry_userData</a> - A
--   launch script you can create that configures a server with additional
--   user data. For example, you might want to run <tt>apt-get -y
--   update</tt>.
--   
--   Depending on the machine image you choose, the command to get software
--   on your instance varies. Amazon Linux and CentOS use <tt>yum</tt>,
--   Debian and Ubuntu use <tt>apt-get</tt>, and FreeBSD uses <tt>pkg</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sourceName:InstanceEntry'</a>, <a>instanceEntry_sourceName</a>
--   - The name of the export snapshot record, which contains the exported
--   Lightsail instance snapshot that will be used as the source of the new
--   Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   Use the <tt>get export snapshot records</tt> operation to get a list
--   of export snapshot records that you can use to create a CloudFormation
--   stack.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceType:InstanceEntry'</a>,
--   <a>instanceEntry_instanceType</a> - The instance type (e.g.,
--   <tt>t2.micro</tt>) to use for the new Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:portInfoSource:InstanceEntry'</a>,
--   <a>instanceEntry_portInfoSource</a> - The port configuration to use
--   for the new Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   The following configuration options are available:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>DEFAULT</tt> - Use the default firewall settings from the
--   Lightsail instance blueprint. If this is specified, then IPv4 and IPv6
--   will be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon
--   EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>INSTANCE</tt> - Use the configured firewall settings from the
--   source Lightsail instance. If this is specified, the new instance that
--   is created in Amazon EC2 will be configured to match the configuration
--   of the source Lightsail instance. For example, if the source instance
--   is configured for dual-stack (IPv4 and IPv6), then IPv4 and IPv6 will
--   be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon EC2. If
--   the source instance is configured for IPv4 only, then only IPv4 will
--   be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>NONE</tt> - Use the default Amazon EC2 security group. If this
--   is specified, then only IPv4 will be configured for the new instance
--   that is created in Amazon EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>CLOSED</tt> - All ports closed. If this is specified, then
--   only IPv4 will be configured for the new instance that is created in
--   Amazon EC2.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If you configured <tt>lightsail-connect</tt> as a
--   <tt>cidrListAliases</tt> on your instance, or if you chose to allow
--   the Lightsail browser-based SSH or RDP clients to connect to your
--   instance, that configuration is not carried over to your new Amazon
--   EC2 instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:availabilityZone:InstanceEntry'</a>,
--   <a>instanceEntry_availabilityZone</a> - The Availability Zone for the
--   new Amazon EC2 instance.
newInstanceEntry :: Text -> Text -> PortInfoSourceType -> Text -> InstanceEntry

-- | A launch script you can create that configures a server with
--   additional user data. For example, you might want to run <tt>apt-get
--   -y update</tt>.
--   
--   Depending on the machine image you choose, the command to get software
--   on your instance varies. Amazon Linux and CentOS use <tt>yum</tt>,
--   Debian and Ubuntu use <tt>apt-get</tt>, and FreeBSD uses <tt>pkg</tt>.
instanceEntry_userData :: Lens' InstanceEntry (Maybe Text)

-- | The name of the export snapshot record, which contains the exported
--   Lightsail instance snapshot that will be used as the source of the new
--   Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   Use the <tt>get export snapshot records</tt> operation to get a list
--   of export snapshot records that you can use to create a CloudFormation
--   stack.
instanceEntry_sourceName :: Lens' InstanceEntry Text

-- | The instance type (e.g., <tt>t2.micro</tt>) to use for the new Amazon
--   EC2 instance.
instanceEntry_instanceType :: Lens' InstanceEntry Text

-- | The port configuration to use for the new Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   The following configuration options are available:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>DEFAULT</tt> - Use the default firewall settings from the
--   Lightsail instance blueprint. If this is specified, then IPv4 and IPv6
--   will be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon
--   EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>INSTANCE</tt> - Use the configured firewall settings from the
--   source Lightsail instance. If this is specified, the new instance that
--   is created in Amazon EC2 will be configured to match the configuration
--   of the source Lightsail instance. For example, if the source instance
--   is configured for dual-stack (IPv4 and IPv6), then IPv4 and IPv6 will
--   be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon EC2. If
--   the source instance is configured for IPv4 only, then only IPv4 will
--   be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>NONE</tt> - Use the default Amazon EC2 security group. If this
--   is specified, then only IPv4 will be configured for the new instance
--   that is created in Amazon EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>CLOSED</tt> - All ports closed. If this is specified, then
--   only IPv4 will be configured for the new instance that is created in
--   Amazon EC2.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If you configured <tt>lightsail-connect</tt> as a
--   <tt>cidrListAliases</tt> on your instance, or if you chose to allow
--   the Lightsail browser-based SSH or RDP clients to connect to your
--   instance, that configuration is not carried over to your new Amazon
--   EC2 instance.
instanceEntry_portInfoSource :: Lens' InstanceEntry PortInfoSourceType

-- | The Availability Zone for the new Amazon EC2 instance.
instanceEntry_availabilityZone :: Lens' InstanceEntry Text
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.InstanceEntry.InstanceEntry
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.InstanceEntry.InstanceEntry
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.InstanceEntry.InstanceEntry
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.InstanceEntry.InstanceEntry
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.InstanceEntry.InstanceEntry
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.InstanceEntry.InstanceEntry
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.InstanceEntry.InstanceEntry


module Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortState
newtype PortState
PortState' :: Text -> PortState
[fromPortState] :: PortState -> Text
pattern PortState_Closed :: PortState
pattern PortState_Open :: PortState
instance Amazonka.Data.XML.ToXML Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance Amazonka.Data.XML.FromXML Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSONKey Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSONKey Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance Amazonka.Data.Query.ToQuery Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance Amazonka.Data.Headers.ToHeader Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance Amazonka.Data.Log.ToLog Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance Amazonka.Data.ByteString.ToByteString Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance Amazonka.Data.Text.ToText Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance Amazonka.Data.Text.FromText Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance GHC.Classes.Ord Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.PortState.PortState


module Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.InstancePortState

-- | Describes open ports on an instance, the IP addresses allowed to
--   connect to the instance through the ports, and the protocol.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInstancePortState</a> smart constructor.
data InstancePortState
InstancePortState' :: Maybe Int -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe PortState -> Maybe NetworkProtocol -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Int -> InstancePortState

-- | The first port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP type for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP type for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:fromPort:InstancePortState'] :: InstancePortState -> Maybe Int

-- | The IPv4 address, or range of IPv4 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol.
--   
--   The <tt>ipv6Cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv6 addresses that are
--   allowed to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
[$sel:cidrs:InstancePortState'] :: InstancePortState -> Maybe [Text]

-- | Specifies whether the instance port is <tt>open</tt> or
--   <tt>closed</tt>.
--   
--   The port state for Lightsail instances is always <tt>open</tt>.
[$sel:state:InstancePortState'] :: InstancePortState -> Maybe PortState

-- | The IP protocol name.
--   
--   The name can be one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>tcp</tt> - Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) provides
--   reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of streamed data between
--   applications running on hosts communicating by an IP network. If you
--   have an application that doesn't require reliable data stream service,
--   use UDP instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>all</tt> - All transport layer protocol types. For more
--   general information, see <a>Transport layer</a> on
--   <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li><tt>udp</tt> - With User Datagram Protocol (UDP), computer
--   applications can send messages (or datagrams) to other hosts on an
--   Internet Protocol (IP) network. Prior communications are not required
--   to set up transmission channels or data paths. Applications that don't
--   require reliable data stream service can use UDP, which provides a
--   connectionless datagram service that emphasizes reduced latency over
--   reliability. If you do require reliable data stream service, use TCP
--   instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>icmp</tt> - Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is used
--   to send error messages and operational information indicating success
--   or failure when communicating with an instance. For example, an error
--   is indicated when an instance could not be reached. When you specify
--   <tt>icmp</tt> as the <tt>protocol</tt>, you must specify the ICMP type
--   using the <tt>fromPort</tt> parameter, and ICMP code using the
--   <tt>toPort</tt> parameter.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:protocol:InstancePortState'] :: InstancePortState -> Maybe NetworkProtocol

-- | An alias that defines access for a preconfigured range of IP
--   addresses.
--   
--   The only alias currently supported is <tt>lightsail-connect</tt>,
--   which allows IP addresses of the browser-based RDP/SSH client in the
--   Lightsail console to connect to your instance.
[$sel:cidrListAliases:InstancePortState'] :: InstancePortState -> Maybe [Text]

-- | The IPv6 address, or range of IPv6 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol. Only devices with an IPv6 address can connect to an instance
--   through IPv6; otherwise, IPv4 should be used.
--   
--   The <tt>cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv4 addresses that are allowed
--   to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
[$sel:ipv6Cidrs:InstancePortState'] :: InstancePortState -> Maybe [Text]

-- | The last port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP code for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP code for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:toPort:InstancePortState'] :: InstancePortState -> Maybe Int

-- | Create a value of <a>InstancePortState</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:fromPort:InstancePortState'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortState_fromPort</a> - The first port in a range of open
--   ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP type for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP type for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:cidrs:InstancePortState'</a>, <a>instancePortState_cidrs</a> -
--   The IPv4 address, or range of IPv4 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol.
--   
--   The <tt>ipv6Cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv6 addresses that are
--   allowed to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:state:InstancePortState'</a>, <a>instancePortState_state</a> -
--   Specifies whether the instance port is <tt>open</tt> or
--   <tt>closed</tt>.
--   
--   The port state for Lightsail instances is always <tt>open</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocol:InstancePortState'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortState_protocol</a> - The IP protocol name.
--   
--   The name can be one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>tcp</tt> - Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) provides
--   reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of streamed data between
--   applications running on hosts communicating by an IP network. If you
--   have an application that doesn't require reliable data stream service,
--   use UDP instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>all</tt> - All transport layer protocol types. For more
--   general information, see <a>Transport layer</a> on
--   <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li><tt>udp</tt> - With User Datagram Protocol (UDP), computer
--   applications can send messages (or datagrams) to other hosts on an
--   Internet Protocol (IP) network. Prior communications are not required
--   to set up transmission channels or data paths. Applications that don't
--   require reliable data stream service can use UDP, which provides a
--   connectionless datagram service that emphasizes reduced latency over
--   reliability. If you do require reliable data stream service, use TCP
--   instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>icmp</tt> - Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is used
--   to send error messages and operational information indicating success
--   or failure when communicating with an instance. For example, an error
--   is indicated when an instance could not be reached. When you specify
--   <tt>icmp</tt> as the <tt>protocol</tt>, you must specify the ICMP type
--   using the <tt>fromPort</tt> parameter, and ICMP code using the
--   <tt>toPort</tt> parameter.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:cidrListAliases:InstancePortState'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortState_cidrListAliases</a> - An alias that defines
--   access for a preconfigured range of IP addresses.
--   
--   The only alias currently supported is <tt>lightsail-connect</tt>,
--   which allows IP addresses of the browser-based RDP/SSH client in the
--   Lightsail console to connect to your instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipv6Cidrs:InstancePortState'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortState_ipv6Cidrs</a> - The IPv6 address, or range of
--   IPv6 addresses (in CIDR notation) that are allowed to connect to an
--   instance through the ports, and the protocol. Only devices with an
--   IPv6 address can connect to an instance through IPv6; otherwise, IPv4
--   should be used.
--   
--   The <tt>cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv4 addresses that are allowed
--   to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:toPort:InstancePortState'</a>, <a>instancePortState_toPort</a>
--   - The last port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP code for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP code for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
newInstancePortState :: InstancePortState

-- | The first port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP type for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP type for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
instancePortState_fromPort :: Lens' InstancePortState (Maybe Int)

-- | The IPv4 address, or range of IPv4 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol.
--   
--   The <tt>ipv6Cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv6 addresses that are
--   allowed to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
instancePortState_cidrs :: Lens' InstancePortState (Maybe [Text])

-- | Specifies whether the instance port is <tt>open</tt> or
--   <tt>closed</tt>.
--   
--   The port state for Lightsail instances is always <tt>open</tt>.
instancePortState_state :: Lens' InstancePortState (Maybe PortState)

-- | The IP protocol name.
--   
--   The name can be one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>tcp</tt> - Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) provides
--   reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of streamed data between
--   applications running on hosts communicating by an IP network. If you
--   have an application that doesn't require reliable data stream service,
--   use UDP instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>all</tt> - All transport layer protocol types. For more
--   general information, see <a>Transport layer</a> on
--   <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li><tt>udp</tt> - With User Datagram Protocol (UDP), computer
--   applications can send messages (or datagrams) to other hosts on an
--   Internet Protocol (IP) network. Prior communications are not required
--   to set up transmission channels or data paths. Applications that don't
--   require reliable data stream service can use UDP, which provides a
--   connectionless datagram service that emphasizes reduced latency over
--   reliability. If you do require reliable data stream service, use TCP
--   instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>icmp</tt> - Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is used
--   to send error messages and operational information indicating success
--   or failure when communicating with an instance. For example, an error
--   is indicated when an instance could not be reached. When you specify
--   <tt>icmp</tt> as the <tt>protocol</tt>, you must specify the ICMP type
--   using the <tt>fromPort</tt> parameter, and ICMP code using the
--   <tt>toPort</tt> parameter.</li>
--   </ul>
instancePortState_protocol :: Lens' InstancePortState (Maybe NetworkProtocol)

-- | An alias that defines access for a preconfigured range of IP
--   addresses.
--   
--   The only alias currently supported is <tt>lightsail-connect</tt>,
--   which allows IP addresses of the browser-based RDP/SSH client in the
--   Lightsail console to connect to your instance.
instancePortState_cidrListAliases :: Lens' InstancePortState (Maybe [Text])

-- | The IPv6 address, or range of IPv6 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol. Only devices with an IPv6 address can connect to an instance
--   through IPv6; otherwise, IPv4 should be used.
--   
--   The <tt>cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv4 addresses that are allowed
--   to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
instancePortState_ipv6Cidrs :: Lens' InstancePortState (Maybe [Text])

-- | The last port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP code for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP code for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
instancePortState_toPort :: Lens' InstancePortState (Maybe Int)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.InstancePortState.InstancePortState
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.InstancePortState.InstancePortState
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.InstancePortState.InstancePortState
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.InstancePortState.InstancePortState
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.InstancePortState.InstancePortState
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.InstancePortState.InstancePortState
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.InstancePortState.InstancePortState


module Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.QueryStringObject

-- | Describes the query string parameters that an Amazon Lightsail content
--   delivery network (CDN) distribution to bases caching on.
--   
--   For the query strings that you specify, your distribution caches
--   separate versions of the specified content based on the query string
--   values in viewer requests.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newQueryStringObject</a> smart constructor.
data QueryStringObject
QueryStringObject' :: Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Bool -> QueryStringObject

-- | The specific query strings that the distribution forwards to the
--   origin.
--   
--   Your distribution will cache content based on the specified query
--   strings.
--   
--   If the <tt>option</tt> parameter is true, then your distribution
--   forwards all query strings, regardless of what you specify using the
--   <tt>queryStringsAllowList</tt> parameter.
[$sel:queryStringsAllowList:QueryStringObject'] :: QueryStringObject -> Maybe [Text]

-- | Indicates whether the distribution forwards and caches based on query
--   strings.
[$sel:option:QueryStringObject'] :: QueryStringObject -> Maybe Bool

-- | Create a value of <a>QueryStringObject</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:queryStringsAllowList:QueryStringObject'</a>,
--   <a>queryStringObject_queryStringsAllowList</a> - The specific query
--   strings that the distribution forwards to the origin.
--   
--   Your distribution will cache content based on the specified query
--   strings.
--   
--   If the <tt>option</tt> parameter is true, then your distribution
--   forwards all query strings, regardless of what you specify using the
--   <tt>queryStringsAllowList</tt> parameter.
--   
--   <a>$sel:option:QueryStringObject'</a>, <a>queryStringObject_option</a>
--   - Indicates whether the distribution forwards and caches based on
--   query strings.
newQueryStringObject :: QueryStringObject

-- | The specific query strings that the distribution forwards to the
--   origin.
--   
--   Your distribution will cache content based on the specified query
--   strings.
--   
--   If the <tt>option</tt> parameter is true, then your distribution
--   forwards all query strings, regardless of what you specify using the
--   <tt>queryStringsAllowList</tt> parameter.
queryStringObject_queryStringsAllowList :: Lens' QueryStringObject (Maybe [Text])

-- | Indicates whether the distribution forwards and caches based on query
--   strings.
queryStringObject_option :: Lens' QueryStringObject (Maybe Bool)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.QueryStringObject.QueryStringObject
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.QueryStringObject.QueryStringObject
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.QueryStringObject.QueryStringObject
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.QueryStringObject.QueryStringObject
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.QueryStringObject.QueryStringObject
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.QueryStringObject.QueryStringObject
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.QueryStringObject.QueryStringObject
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.QueryStringObject.QueryStringObject


module Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.CacheSettings

-- | Describes the cache settings of an Amazon Lightsail content delivery
--   network (CDN) distribution.
--   
--   These settings apply only to your distribution's
--   <tt>cacheBehaviors</tt> (including the <tt>defaultCacheBehavior</tt>)
--   that have a <tt>behavior</tt> of <tt>cache</tt>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCacheSettings</a> smart constructor.
data CacheSettings
CacheSettings' :: Maybe Integer -> Maybe Text -> Maybe CookieObject -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Integer -> Maybe Integer -> Maybe HeaderObject -> Maybe QueryStringObject -> CacheSettings

-- | The maximum amount of time that objects stay in the distribution's
--   cache before the distribution forwards another request to the origin
--   to determine whether the object has been updated.
--   
--   The value specified applies only when the origin adds HTTP headers
--   such as <tt>Cache-Control max-age</tt>, <tt>Cache-Control
--   s-maxage</tt>, and <tt>Expires</tt> to objects.
[$sel:maximumTTL:CacheSettings'] :: CacheSettings -> Maybe Integer

-- | The HTTP method responses that are cached by your distribution.
--   
--   You can specify the following options:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>GET,HEAD</tt> - The distribution caches responses to the
--   <tt>GET</tt> and <tt>HEAD</tt> methods.</li>
--   <li><tt>GET,HEAD,OPTIONS</tt> - The distribution caches responses to
--   the <tt>GET</tt>, <tt>HEAD</tt>, and <tt>OPTIONS</tt> methods.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:cachedHTTPMethods:CacheSettings'] :: CacheSettings -> Maybe Text

-- | An object that describes the cookies that are forwarded to the origin.
--   Your content is cached based on the cookies that are forwarded.
[$sel:forwardedCookies:CacheSettings'] :: CacheSettings -> Maybe CookieObject

-- | The HTTP methods that are processed and forwarded to the
--   distribution's origin.
--   
--   You can specify the following options:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>GET,HEAD</tt> - The distribution forwards the <tt>GET</tt> and
--   <tt>HEAD</tt> methods.</li>
--   <li><tt>GET,HEAD,OPTIONS</tt> - The distribution forwards the
--   <tt>GET</tt>, <tt>HEAD</tt>, and <tt>OPTIONS</tt> methods.</li>
--   <li><tt>GET,HEAD,OPTIONS,PUT,PATCH,POST,DELETE</tt> - The distribution
--   forwards the <tt>GET</tt>, <tt>HEAD</tt>, <tt>OPTIONS</tt>,
--   <tt>PUT</tt>, <tt>PATCH</tt>, <tt>POST</tt>, and <tt>DELETE</tt>
--   methods.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If you specify the third option, you might need to restrict access to
--   your distribution's origin so users can't perform operations that you
--   don't want them to. For example, you might not want users to have
--   permission to delete objects from your origin.
[$sel:allowedHTTPMethods:CacheSettings'] :: CacheSettings -> Maybe Text

-- | The default amount of time that objects stay in the distribution's
--   cache before the distribution forwards another request to the origin
--   to determine whether the content has been updated.
--   
--   The value specified applies only when the origin does not add HTTP
--   headers such as <tt>Cache-Control max-age</tt>, <tt>Cache-Control
--   s-maxage</tt>, and <tt>Expires</tt> to objects.
[$sel:defaultTTL:CacheSettings'] :: CacheSettings -> Maybe Integer

-- | The minimum amount of time that objects stay in the distribution's
--   cache before the distribution forwards another request to the origin
--   to determine whether the object has been updated.
--   
--   A value of <tt>0</tt> must be specified for <tt>minimumTTL</tt> if the
--   distribution is configured to forward all headers to the origin.
[$sel:minimumTTL:CacheSettings'] :: CacheSettings -> Maybe Integer

-- | An object that describes the headers that are forwarded to the origin.
--   Your content is cached based on the headers that are forwarded.
[$sel:forwardedHeaders:CacheSettings'] :: CacheSettings -> Maybe HeaderObject

-- | An object that describes the query strings that are forwarded to the
--   origin. Your content is cached based on the query strings that are
--   forwarded.
[$sel:forwardedQueryStrings:CacheSettings'] :: CacheSettings -> Maybe QueryStringObject

-- | Create a value of <a>CacheSettings</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:maximumTTL:CacheSettings'</a>, <a>cacheSettings_maximumTTL</a>
--   - The maximum amount of time that objects stay in the distribution's
--   cache before the distribution forwards another request to the origin
--   to determine whether the object has been updated.
--   
--   The value specified applies only when the origin adds HTTP headers
--   such as <tt>Cache-Control max-age</tt>, <tt>Cache-Control
--   s-maxage</tt>, and <tt>Expires</tt> to objects.
--   
--   <a>$sel:cachedHTTPMethods:CacheSettings'</a>,
--   <a>cacheSettings_cachedHTTPMethods</a> - The HTTP method responses
--   that are cached by your distribution.
--   
--   You can specify the following options:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>GET,HEAD</tt> - The distribution caches responses to the
--   <tt>GET</tt> and <tt>HEAD</tt> methods.</li>
--   <li><tt>GET,HEAD,OPTIONS</tt> - The distribution caches responses to
--   the <tt>GET</tt>, <tt>HEAD</tt>, and <tt>OPTIONS</tt> methods.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:forwardedCookies:CacheSettings'</a>,
--   <a>cacheSettings_forwardedCookies</a> - An object that describes the
--   cookies that are forwarded to the origin. Your content is cached based
--   on the cookies that are forwarded.
--   
--   <a>$sel:allowedHTTPMethods:CacheSettings'</a>,
--   <a>cacheSettings_allowedHTTPMethods</a> - The HTTP methods that are
--   processed and forwarded to the distribution's origin.
--   
--   You can specify the following options:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>GET,HEAD</tt> - The distribution forwards the <tt>GET</tt> and
--   <tt>HEAD</tt> methods.</li>
--   <li><tt>GET,HEAD,OPTIONS</tt> - The distribution forwards the
--   <tt>GET</tt>, <tt>HEAD</tt>, and <tt>OPTIONS</tt> methods.</li>
--   <li><tt>GET,HEAD,OPTIONS,PUT,PATCH,POST,DELETE</tt> - The distribution
--   forwards the <tt>GET</tt>, <tt>HEAD</tt>, <tt>OPTIONS</tt>,
--   <tt>PUT</tt>, <tt>PATCH</tt>, <tt>POST</tt>, and <tt>DELETE</tt>
--   methods.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If you specify the third option, you might need to restrict access to
--   your distribution's origin so users can't perform operations that you
--   don't want them to. For example, you might not want users to have
--   permission to delete objects from your origin.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultTTL:CacheSettings'</a>, <a>cacheSettings_defaultTTL</a>
--   - The default amount of time that objects stay in the distribution's
--   cache before the distribution forwards another request to the origin
--   to determine whether the content has been updated.
--   
--   The value specified applies only when the origin does not add HTTP
--   headers such as <tt>Cache-Control max-age</tt>, <tt>Cache-Control
--   s-maxage</tt>, and <tt>Expires</tt> to objects.
--   
--   <a>$sel:minimumTTL:CacheSettings'</a>, <a>cacheSettings_minimumTTL</a>
--   - The minimum amount of time that objects stay in the distribution's
--   cache before the distribution forwards another request to the origin
--   to determine whether the object has been updated.
--   
--   A value of <tt>0</tt> must be specified for <tt>minimumTTL</tt> if the
--   distribution is configured to forward all headers to the origin.
--   
--   <a>$sel:forwardedHeaders:CacheSettings'</a>,
--   <a>cacheSettings_forwardedHeaders</a> - An object that describes the
--   headers that are forwarded to the origin. Your content is cached based
--   on the headers that are forwarded.
--   
--   <a>$sel:forwardedQueryStrings:CacheSettings'</a>,
--   <a>cacheSettings_forwardedQueryStrings</a> - An object that describes
--   the query strings that are forwarded to the origin. Your content is
--   cached based on the query strings that are forwarded.
newCacheSettings :: CacheSettings

-- | The maximum amount of time that objects stay in the distribution's
--   cache before the distribution forwards another request to the origin
--   to determine whether the object has been updated.
--   
--   The value specified applies only when the origin adds HTTP headers
--   such as <tt>Cache-Control max-age</tt>, <tt>Cache-Control
--   s-maxage</tt>, and <tt>Expires</tt> to objects.
cacheSettings_maximumTTL :: Lens' CacheSettings (Maybe Integer)

-- | The HTTP method responses that are cached by your distribution.
--   
--   You can specify the following options:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>GET,HEAD</tt> - The distribution caches responses to the
--   <tt>GET</tt> and <tt>HEAD</tt> methods.</li>
--   <li><tt>GET,HEAD,OPTIONS</tt> - The distribution caches responses to
--   the <tt>GET</tt>, <tt>HEAD</tt>, and <tt>OPTIONS</tt> methods.</li>
--   </ul>
cacheSettings_cachedHTTPMethods :: Lens' CacheSettings (Maybe Text)

-- | An object that describes the cookies that are forwarded to the origin.
--   Your content is cached based on the cookies that are forwarded.
cacheSettings_forwardedCookies :: Lens' CacheSettings (Maybe CookieObject)

-- | The HTTP methods that are processed and forwarded to the
--   distribution's origin.
--   
--   You can specify the following options:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>GET,HEAD</tt> - The distribution forwards the <tt>GET</tt> and
--   <tt>HEAD</tt> methods.</li>
--   <li><tt>GET,HEAD,OPTIONS</tt> - The distribution forwards the
--   <tt>GET</tt>, <tt>HEAD</tt>, and <tt>OPTIONS</tt> methods.</li>
--   <li><tt>GET,HEAD,OPTIONS,PUT,PATCH,POST,DELETE</tt> - The distribution
--   forwards the <tt>GET</tt>, <tt>HEAD</tt>, <tt>OPTIONS</tt>,
--   <tt>PUT</tt>, <tt>PATCH</tt>, <tt>POST</tt>, and <tt>DELETE</tt>
--   methods.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If you specify the third option, you might need to restrict access to
--   your distribution's origin so users can't perform operations that you
--   don't want them to. For example, you might not want users to have
--   permission to delete objects from your origin.
cacheSettings_allowedHTTPMethods :: Lens' CacheSettings (Maybe Text)

-- | The default amount of time that objects stay in the distribution's
--   cache before the distribution forwards another request to the origin
--   to determine whether the content has been updated.
--   
--   The value specified applies only when the origin does not add HTTP
--   headers such as <tt>Cache-Control max-age</tt>, <tt>Cache-Control
--   s-maxage</tt>, and <tt>Expires</tt> to objects.
cacheSettings_defaultTTL :: Lens' CacheSettings (Maybe Integer)

-- | The minimum amount of time that objects stay in the distribution's
--   cache before the distribution forwards another request to the origin
--   to determine whether the object has been updated.
--   
--   A value of <tt>0</tt> must be specified for <tt>minimumTTL</tt> if the
--   distribution is configured to forward all headers to the origin.
cacheSettings_minimumTTL :: Lens' CacheSettings (Maybe Integer)

-- | An object that describes the headers that are forwarded to the origin.
--   Your content is cached based on the headers that are forwarded.
cacheSettings_forwardedHeaders :: Lens' CacheSettings (Maybe HeaderObject)

-- | An object that describes the query strings that are forwarded to the
--   origin. Your content is cached based on the query strings that are
--   forwarded.
cacheSettings_forwardedQueryStrings :: Lens' CacheSettings (Maybe QueryStringObject)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.CacheSettings.CacheSettings
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.CacheSettings.CacheSettings
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.CacheSettings.CacheSettings
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.CacheSettings.CacheSettings

module Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.RegionInfo

-- | Describes the AWS Region.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRegionInfo</a> smart constructor.
data RegionInfo
RegionInfo' :: Maybe [AvailabilityZone] -> Maybe RegionName -> Maybe [AvailabilityZone] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> RegionInfo

-- | The Availability Zones. Follows the format <tt>us-east-2a</tt>
--   (case-sensitive).
[$sel:availabilityZones:RegionInfo'] :: RegionInfo -> Maybe [AvailabilityZone]

-- | The region name (e.g., <tt>us-east-2</tt>).
[$sel:name:RegionInfo'] :: RegionInfo -> Maybe RegionName

-- | The Availability Zones for databases. Follows the format
--   <tt>us-east-2a</tt> (case-sensitive).
[$sel:relationalDatabaseAvailabilityZones:RegionInfo'] :: RegionInfo -> Maybe [AvailabilityZone]

-- | The display name (e.g., <tt>Ohio</tt>).
[$sel:displayName:RegionInfo'] :: RegionInfo -> Maybe Text

-- | The continent code (e.g., <tt>NA</tt>, meaning North America).
[$sel:continentCode:RegionInfo'] :: RegionInfo -> Maybe Text

-- | The description of the AWS Region (e.g., <tt>This region is
--   recommended to serve users in the eastern United States and eastern
--   Canada</tt>).
[$sel:description:RegionInfo'] :: RegionInfo -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>RegionInfo</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:availabilityZones:RegionInfo'</a>,
--   <a>regionInfo_availabilityZones</a> - The Availability Zones. Follows
--   the format <tt>us-east-2a</tt> (case-sensitive).
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:RegionInfo'</a>, <a>regionInfo_name</a> - The region name
--   (e.g., <tt>us-east-2</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:relationalDatabaseAvailabilityZones:RegionInfo'</a>,
--   <a>regionInfo_relationalDatabaseAvailabilityZones</a> - The
--   Availability Zones for databases. Follows the format
--   <tt>us-east-2a</tt> (case-sensitive).
--   
--   <a>$sel:displayName:RegionInfo'</a>, <a>regionInfo_displayName</a> -
--   The display name (e.g., <tt>Ohio</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:continentCode:RegionInfo'</a>, <a>regionInfo_continentCode</a>
--   - The continent code (e.g., <tt>NA</tt>, meaning North America).
--   
--   <a>$sel:description:RegionInfo'</a>, <a>regionInfo_description</a> -
--   The description of the AWS Region (e.g., <tt>This region is
--   recommended to serve users in the eastern United States and eastern
--   Canada</tt>).
newRegionInfo :: RegionInfo

-- | The Availability Zones. Follows the format <tt>us-east-2a</tt>
--   (case-sensitive).
regionInfo_availabilityZones :: Lens' RegionInfo (Maybe [AvailabilityZone])

-- | The region name (e.g., <tt>us-east-2</tt>).
regionInfo_name :: Lens' RegionInfo (Maybe RegionName)

-- | The Availability Zones for databases. Follows the format
--   <tt>us-east-2a</tt> (case-sensitive).
regionInfo_relationalDatabaseAvailabilityZones :: Lens' RegionInfo (Maybe [AvailabilityZone])

-- | The display name (e.g., <tt>Ohio</tt>).
regionInfo_displayName :: Lens' RegionInfo (Maybe Text)

-- | The continent code (e.g., <tt>NA</tt>, meaning North America).
regionInfo_continentCode :: Lens' RegionInfo (Maybe Text)

-- | The description of the AWS Region (e.g., <tt>This region is
--   recommended to serve users in the eastern United States and eastern
--   Canada</tt>).
regionInfo_description :: Lens' RegionInfo (Maybe Text)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.RegionInfo.RegionInfo
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.RegionInfo.RegionInfo
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.RegionInfo.RegionInfo
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.RegionInfo.RegionInfo
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.RegionInfo.RegionInfo
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.RegionInfo.RegionInfo
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.RegionInfo.RegionInfo


module Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.InputOrigin

-- | Describes the origin resource of an Amazon Lightsail content delivery
--   network (CDN) distribution.
--   
--   An origin can be a Lightsail instance or load balancer. A distribution
--   pulls content from an origin, caches it, and serves it to viewers via
--   a worldwide network of edge servers.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInputOrigin</a> smart constructor.
data InputOrigin
InputOrigin' :: Maybe RegionName -> Maybe Text -> Maybe OriginProtocolPolicyEnum -> InputOrigin

-- | The AWS Region name of the origin resource.
[$sel:regionName:InputOrigin'] :: InputOrigin -> Maybe RegionName

-- | The name of the origin resource.
[$sel:name:InputOrigin'] :: InputOrigin -> Maybe Text

-- | The protocol that your Amazon Lightsail distribution uses when
--   establishing a connection with your origin to pull content.
[$sel:protocolPolicy:InputOrigin'] :: InputOrigin -> Maybe OriginProtocolPolicyEnum

-- | Create a value of <a>InputOrigin</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:regionName:InputOrigin'</a>, <a>inputOrigin_regionName</a> -
--   The AWS Region name of the origin resource.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:InputOrigin'</a>, <a>inputOrigin_name</a> - The name of
--   the origin resource.
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocolPolicy:InputOrigin'</a>,
--   <a>inputOrigin_protocolPolicy</a> - The protocol that your Amazon
--   Lightsail distribution uses when establishing a connection with your
--   origin to pull content.
newInputOrigin :: InputOrigin

-- | The AWS Region name of the origin resource.
inputOrigin_regionName :: Lens' InputOrigin (Maybe RegionName)

-- | The name of the origin resource.
inputOrigin_name :: Lens' InputOrigin (Maybe Text)

-- | The protocol that your Amazon Lightsail distribution uses when
--   establishing a connection with your origin to pull content.
inputOrigin_protocolPolicy :: Lens' InputOrigin (Maybe OriginProtocolPolicyEnum)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.InputOrigin.InputOrigin
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.InputOrigin.InputOrigin
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.InputOrigin.InputOrigin
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.InputOrigin.InputOrigin
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.InputOrigin.InputOrigin
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.InputOrigin.InputOrigin
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.InputOrigin.InputOrigin


module Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.RelationalDatabaseBundle

-- | Describes a database bundle. A bundle describes the performance
--   specifications of the database.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRelationalDatabaseBundle</a> smart constructor.
data RelationalDatabaseBundle
RelationalDatabaseBundle' :: Maybe Bool -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Double -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Double -> RelationalDatabaseBundle

-- | A Boolean value indicating whether the database bundle is encrypted.
[$sel:isEncrypted:RelationalDatabaseBundle'] :: RelationalDatabaseBundle -> Maybe Bool

-- | The number of virtual CPUs (vCPUs) for the database bundle.
[$sel:cpuCount:RelationalDatabaseBundle'] :: RelationalDatabaseBundle -> Maybe Int

-- | The data transfer rate per month in GB for the database bundle.
[$sel:transferPerMonthInGb:RelationalDatabaseBundle'] :: RelationalDatabaseBundle -> Maybe Int

-- | The ID for the database bundle.
[$sel:bundleId:RelationalDatabaseBundle'] :: RelationalDatabaseBundle -> Maybe Text

-- | The name for the database bundle.
[$sel:name:RelationalDatabaseBundle'] :: RelationalDatabaseBundle -> Maybe Text

-- | The size of the disk for the database bundle.
[$sel:diskSizeInGb:RelationalDatabaseBundle'] :: RelationalDatabaseBundle -> Maybe Int

-- | The cost of the database bundle in US currency.
[$sel:price:RelationalDatabaseBundle'] :: RelationalDatabaseBundle -> Maybe Double

-- | A Boolean value indicating whether the database bundle is active.
[$sel:isActive:RelationalDatabaseBundle'] :: RelationalDatabaseBundle -> Maybe Bool

-- | The amount of RAM in GB (for example, <tt>2.0</tt>) for the database
--   bundle.
[$sel:ramSizeInGb:RelationalDatabaseBundle'] :: RelationalDatabaseBundle -> Maybe Double

-- | Create a value of <a>RelationalDatabaseBundle</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:isEncrypted:RelationalDatabaseBundle'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabaseBundle_isEncrypted</a> - A Boolean value
--   indicating whether the database bundle is encrypted.
--   
--   <a>$sel:cpuCount:RelationalDatabaseBundle'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabaseBundle_cpuCount</a> - The number of virtual CPUs
--   (vCPUs) for the database bundle.
--   
--   <a>$sel:transferPerMonthInGb:RelationalDatabaseBundle'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabaseBundle_transferPerMonthInGb</a> - The data
--   transfer rate per month in GB for the database bundle.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bundleId:RelationalDatabaseBundle'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabaseBundle_bundleId</a> - The ID for the database
--   bundle.
--

--   bundle.

--   for the database bundle.
--   
--   <a>$sel:price:RelationalDatabaseBundle'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabaseBundle_price</a> - The cost of the database
--   bundle in US currency.
--   
--   <a>$sel:isActive:RelationalDatabaseBundle'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabaseBundle_isActive</a> - A Boolean value indicating
--   whether the database bundle is active.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ramSizeInGb:RelationalDatabaseBundle'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabaseBundle_ramSizeInGb</a> - The amount of RAM in GB
--   (for example, <tt>2.0</tt>) for the database bundle.

-- | The size of the disk for the database bundle.

module Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.RelationalDatabaseBlueprint

-- | Describes a database image, or blueprint. A blueprint describes the
--   major engine version of a database.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRelationalDatabaseBlueprint</a> smart constructor.
data RelationalDatabaseBlueprint
RelationalDatabaseBlueprint' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe RelationalDatabaseEngine -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> RelationalDatabaseBlueprint

-- | The database engine version for the database blueprint (for example,
--   <tt>5.7.23</tt>).
[$sel:engineVersion:RelationalDatabaseBlueprint'] :: RelationalDatabaseBlueprint -> Maybe Text

-- | A Boolean value indicating whether the engine version is the default
--   for the database blueprint.
[$sel:isEngineDefault:RelationalDatabaseBlueprint'] :: RelationalDatabaseBlueprint -> Maybe Bool

-- | The description of the database engine version for the database
--   blueprint.
[$sel:engineVersionDescription:RelationalDatabaseBlueprint'] :: RelationalDatabaseBlueprint -> Maybe Text

-- | The database software of the database blueprint (for example,
--   <tt>MySQL</tt>).
[$sel:engine:RelationalDatabaseBlueprint'] :: RelationalDatabaseBlueprint -> Maybe RelationalDatabaseEngine

-- | The ID for the database blueprint.
[$sel:blueprintId:RelationalDatabaseBlueprint'] :: RelationalDatabaseBlueprint -> Maybe Text

-- | The description of the database engine for the database blueprint.
[$sel:engineDescription:RelationalDatabaseBlueprint'] :: RelationalDatabaseBlueprint -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>RelationalDatabaseBlueprint</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:engineVersion:RelationalDatabaseBlueprint'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabaseBlueprint_engineVersion</a> - The database engine
--   version for the database blueprint (for example, <tt>5.7.23</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:isEngineDefault:RelationalDatabaseBlueprint'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabaseBlueprint_isEngineDefault</a> - A Boolean value
--   indicating whether the engine version is the default for the database
--   blueprint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:engineVersionDescription:RelationalDatabaseBlueprint'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabaseBlueprint_engineVersionDescription</a> - The
--   description of the database engine version for the database blueprint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:engine:RelationalDatabaseBlueprint'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabaseBlueprint_engine</a> - The database software of
--   the database blueprint (for example, <tt>MySQL</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:blueprintId:RelationalDatabaseBlueprint'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabaseBlueprint_blueprintId</a> - The ID for the
--   database blueprint.

--   <a>relationalDatabaseBlueprint_engineDescription</a> - The description
--   of the database engine for the database blueprint.

--   for the database blueprint.
relationalDatabaseBlueprint_isEngineDefault :: Lens' RelationalDatabaseBlueprint (Maybe Bool)

-- | The description of the database engine version for the database
--   blueprint.
relationalDatabaseBlueprint_engineVersionDescription :: Lens' RelationalDatabaseBlueprint (Maybe Text)

module Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.RelationalDatabaseParameter

-- | Describes the parameters of a database.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRelationalDatabaseParameter</a> smart constructor.
data RelationalDatabaseParameter
RelationalDatabaseParameter' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> RelationalDatabaseParameter

-- | Specifies the engine-specific parameter type.
[$sel:applyType:RelationalDatabaseParameter'] :: RelationalDatabaseParameter -> Maybe Text

-- | Specifies the value of the parameter.
[$sel:parameterValue:RelationalDatabaseParameter'] :: RelationalDatabaseParameter -> Maybe Text

-- | Indicates when parameter updates are applied.
--   
--   Can be <tt>immediate</tt> or <tt>pending-reboot</tt>.
[$sel:applyMethod:RelationalDatabaseParameter'] :: RelationalDatabaseParameter -> Maybe Text

-- | Specifies the valid data type for the parameter.
[$sel:dataType:RelationalDatabaseParameter'] :: RelationalDatabaseParameter -> Maybe Text

-- | A Boolean value indicating whether the parameter can be modified.
[$sel:isModifiable:RelationalDatabaseParameter'] :: RelationalDatabaseParameter -> Maybe Bool

-- | Specifies the valid range of values for the parameter.
[$sel:allowedValues:RelationalDatabaseParameter'] :: RelationalDatabaseParameter -> Maybe Text

-- | Specifies the name of the parameter.
[$sel:parameterName:RelationalDatabaseParameter'] :: RelationalDatabaseParameter -> Maybe Text

-- | Provides a description of the parameter.
[$sel:description:RelationalDatabaseParameter'] :: RelationalDatabaseParameter -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>RelationalDatabaseParameter</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:applyType:RelationalDatabaseParameter'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabaseParameter_applyType</a> - Specifies the
--   engine-specific parameter type.
--   
--   <a>$sel:parameterValue:RelationalDatabaseParameter'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabaseParameter_parameterValue</a> - Specifies the
--   value of the parameter.
--   
--   <a>$sel:applyMethod:RelationalDatabaseParameter'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabaseParameter_applyMethod</a> - Indicates when
--   parameter updates are applied.
--   
--   Can be <tt>immediate</tt> or <tt>pending-reboot</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:dataType:RelationalDatabaseParameter'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabaseParameter_dataType</a> - Specifies the valid data
--   type for the parameter.
--   
--   <a>$sel:isModifiable:RelationalDatabaseParameter'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabaseParameter_isModifiable</a> - A Boolean value
--   indicating whether the parameter can be modified.
--   
--   <a>$sel:allowedValues:RelationalDatabaseParameter'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabaseParameter_allowedValues</a> - Specifies the valid
--   range of values for the parameter.
--   
--   <a>$sel:parameterName:RelationalDatabaseParameter'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabaseParameter_parameterName</a> - Specifies the name
--   of the parameter.

--   <a>relationalDatabaseParameter_description</a> - Provides a

--

-- | The AWS Region name.
[$sel:regionName:ResourceLocation'] :: ResourceLocation -> Maybe RegionName

-- | The Availability Zone. Follows the format <tt>us-east-2a</tt>
--   (case-sensitive).

-- | Create a value of <a>ResourceLocation</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--

--   fields.
--

--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:regionName:ResourceLocation'</a>,
--   <a>resourceLocation_regionName</a> - The AWS Region name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:availabilityZone:ResourceLocation'</a>,
--   <a>resourceLocation_availabilityZone</a> - The Availability Zone.
--   Follows the format <tt>us-east-2a</tt> (case-sensitive).
newResourceLocation :: ResourceLocation

--   (case-sensitive).

module Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.ResourceRecord

-- | Describes the domain name system (DNS) records to add to your domain's
--   DNS to validate it for an Amazon Lightsail certificate.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newResourceRecord</a> smart constructor.
data ResourceRecord
ResourceRecord' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> ResourceRecord

-- | The value for the DNS record.
[$sel:value:ResourceRecord'] :: ResourceRecord -> Maybe Text

-- | The name of the record.
[$sel:name:ResourceRecord'] :: ResourceRecord -> Maybe Text

-- | The DNS record type.
[$sel:type':ResourceRecord'] :: ResourceRecord -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>ResourceRecord</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:value:ResourceRecord'</a>, <a>resourceRecord_value</a> - The
--   value for the DNS record.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:ResourceRecord'</a>, <a>resourceRecord_name</a> - The
--   name of the record.
--   
--   <a>$sel:type':ResourceRecord'</a>, <a>resourceRecord_type</a> - The
--   DNS record type.
newResourceRecord :: ResourceRecord

-- | The value for the DNS record.
resourceRecord_value :: Lens' ResourceRecord (Maybe Text)

-- | The name of the record.
resourceRecord_name :: Lens' ResourceRecord (Maybe Text)

-- | The DNS record type.
resourceRecord_type :: Lens' ResourceRecord (Maybe Text)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.ResourceRecord.ResourceRecord
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.ResourceRecord.ResourceRecord
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.ResourceRecord.ResourceRecord
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.ResourceRecord.ResourceRecord

module Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.DomainValidationRecord

-- | Describes the domain validation records of an Amazon Lightsail SSL/TLS
--   certificate.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newDomainValidationRecord</a> smart constructor.
data DomainValidationRecord
DomainValidationRecord' :: Maybe ResourceRecord -> Maybe Text -> DomainValidationRecord

-- | An object that describes the DNS records to add to your domain's DNS
--   to validate it for the certificate.
[$sel:resourceRecord:DomainValidationRecord'] :: DomainValidationRecord -> Maybe ResourceRecord

-- | The domain name of the certificate validation record. For example,
--   <tt>example.com</tt> or <tt>www.example.com</tt>.
[$sel:domainName:DomainValidationRecord'] :: DomainValidationRecord -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>DomainValidationRecord</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceRecord:DomainValidationRecord'</a>,
--   <a>domainValidationRecord_resourceRecord</a> - An object that
--   describes the DNS records to add to your domain's DNS to validate it
--   for the certificate.
--   
--   <a>$sel:domainName:DomainValidationRecord'</a>,
--   <a>domainValidationRecord_domainName</a> - The domain name of the
--   certificate validation record. For example, <tt>example.com</tt> or
--   <tt>www.example.com</tt>.
newDomainValidationRecord :: DomainValidationRecord

-- | An object that describes the DNS records to add to your domain's DNS
--   to validate it for the certificate.
domainValidationRecord_resourceRecord :: Lens' DomainValidationRecord (Maybe ResourceRecord)

-- | The domain name of the certificate validation record. For example,
--   <tt>example.com</tt> or <tt>www.example.com</tt>.
domainValidationRecord_domainName :: Lens' DomainValidationRecord (Maybe Text)

instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.DomainValidationRecord.DomainValidationRecord


module Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.RenewalSummary

-- | Describes the status of a SSL/TLS certificate renewal managed by
--   Amazon Lightsail.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRenewalSummary</a> smart constructor.
data RenewalSummary
RenewalSummary' :: Maybe RenewalStatus -> Maybe [DomainValidationRecord] -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe Text -> RenewalSummary

-- | The renewal status of the certificate.
--   
--   The following renewal status are possible:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>PendingAutoRenewal</tt></b> - Lightsail is attempting to
--   automatically validate the domain names of the certificate. No further
--   action is required.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>PendingValidation</tt></b> - Lightsail couldn't
--   automatically validate one or more domain names of the certificate.
--   You must take action to validate these domain names or the certificate
--   won't be renewed. Check to make sure your certificate's domain
--   validation records exist in your domain's DNS, and that your
--   certificate remains in use.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Success</tt></b> - All domain names in the certificate are
--   validated, and Lightsail renewed the certificate. No further action is
--   required.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Failed</tt></b> - One or more domain names were not
--   validated before the certificate expired, and Lightsail did not renew
--   the certificate. You can request a new certificate using the
--   <tt>CreateCertificate</tt> action.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:renewalStatus:RenewalSummary'] :: RenewalSummary -> Maybe RenewalStatus

-- | An array of objects that describe the domain validation records of the
--   certificate.
[$sel:domainValidationRecords:RenewalSummary'] :: RenewalSummary -> Maybe [DomainValidationRecord]

-- | The timestamp when the certificate was last updated.
[$sel:updatedAt:RenewalSummary'] :: RenewalSummary -> Maybe POSIX

-- | The reason for the renewal status of the certificate.
[$sel:renewalStatusReason:RenewalSummary'] :: RenewalSummary -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>RenewalSummary</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:renewalStatus:RenewalSummary'</a>,
--   <a>renewalSummary_renewalStatus</a> - The renewal status of the
--   certificate.
--   
--   The following renewal status are possible:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>PendingAutoRenewal</tt></b> - Lightsail is attempting to
--   automatically validate the domain names of the certificate. No further
--   action is required.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>PendingValidation</tt></b> - Lightsail couldn't
--   automatically validate one or more domain names of the certificate.
--   You must take action to validate these domain names or the certificate
--   won't be renewed. Check to make sure your certificate's domain
--   validation records exist in your domain's DNS, and that your
--   certificate remains in use.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Success</tt></b> - All domain names in the certificate are
--   validated, and Lightsail renewed the certificate. No further action is
--   required.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Failed</tt></b> - One or more domain names were not
--   validated before the certificate expired, and Lightsail did not renew
--   the certificate. You can request a new certificate using the
--   <tt>CreateCertificate</tt> action.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:domainValidationRecords:RenewalSummary'</a>,
--   <a>renewalSummary_domainValidationRecords</a> - An array of objects
--   that describe the domain validation records of the certificate.
--   
--   <a>$sel:updatedAt:RenewalSummary'</a>, <a>renewalSummary_updatedAt</a>
--   - The timestamp when the certificate was last updated.
--   
--   <a>$sel:renewalStatusReason:RenewalSummary'</a>,
--   <a>renewalSummary_renewalStatusReason</a> - The reason for the renewal
--   status of the certificate.
newRenewalSummary :: RenewalSummary

-- | The renewal status of the certificate.
--   
--   The following renewal status are possible:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>PendingAutoRenewal</tt></b> - Lightsail is attempting to
--   automatically validate the domain names of the certificate. No further
--   action is required.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>PendingValidation</tt></b> - Lightsail couldn't
--   automatically validate one or more domain names of the certificate.
--   You must take action to validate these domain names or the certificate
--   won't be renewed. Check to make sure your certificate's domain
--   validation records exist in your domain's DNS, and that your
--   certificate remains in use.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Success</tt></b> - All domain names in the certificate are
--   validated, and Lightsail renewed the certificate. No further action is
--   required.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Failed</tt></b> - One or more domain names were not
--   validated before the certificate expired, and Lightsail did not renew
--   the certificate. You can request a new certificate using the
--   <tt>CreateCertificate</tt> action.</li>
--   </ul>
renewalSummary_renewalStatus :: Lens' RenewalSummary (Maybe RenewalStatus)

-- | An array of objects that describe the domain validation records of the
--   certificate.
renewalSummary_domainValidationRecords :: Lens' RenewalSummary (Maybe [DomainValidationRecord])

-- | The timestamp when the certificate was last updated.
renewalSummary_updatedAt :: Lens' RenewalSummary (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | The reason for the renewal status of the certificate.
renewalSummary_renewalStatusReason :: Lens' RenewalSummary (Maybe Text)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.RenewalSummary.RenewalSummary
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.RenewalSummary.RenewalSummary
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.RenewalSummary.RenewalSummary
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.RenewalSummary.RenewalSummary
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.RenewalSummary.RenewalSummary
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.RenewalSummary.RenewalSummary
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.RenewalSummary.RenewalSummary

module Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.Origin

-- | Describes the origin resource of an Amazon Lightsail content delivery
--   network (CDN) distribution.
--   
--   An origin can be a Lightsail instance or load balancer. A distribution
--   pulls content from an origin, caches it, and serves it to viewers via
--   a worldwide network of edge servers.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newOrigin</a> smart constructor.
data Origin
Origin' :: Maybe RegionName -> Maybe ResourceType -> Maybe Text -> Maybe OriginProtocolPolicyEnum -> Origin

-- | The AWS Region name of the origin resource.
[$sel:regionName:Origin'] :: Origin -> Maybe RegionName

-- | The resource type of the origin resource (e.g., <i>Instance</i>).
[$sel:resourceType:Origin'] :: Origin -> Maybe ResourceType

-- | The name of the origin resource.
[$sel:name:Origin'] :: Origin -> Maybe Text

-- | The protocol that your Amazon Lightsail distribution uses when
--   establishing a connection with your origin to pull content.
[$sel:protocolPolicy:Origin'] :: Origin -> Maybe OriginProtocolPolicyEnum

-- | Create a value of <a>Origin</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:regionName:Origin'</a>, <a>origin_regionName</a> - The AWS
--   Region name of the origin resource.
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceType:Origin'</a>, <a>origin_resourceType</a> - The
--   resource type of the origin resource (e.g., <i>Instance</i>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:Origin'</a>, <a>origin_name</a> - The name of the origin
--   resource.
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocolPolicy:Origin'</a>, <a>origin_protocolPolicy</a> - The
--   protocol that your Amazon Lightsail distribution uses when
--   establishing a connection with your origin to pull content.
newOrigin :: Origin

-- | The AWS Region name of the origin resource.
origin_regionName :: Lens' Origin (Maybe RegionName)

-- | The resource type of the origin resource (e.g., <i>Instance</i>).
origin_resourceType :: Lens' Origin (Maybe ResourceType)

-- | The name of the origin resource.
origin_name :: Lens' Origin (Maybe Text)

-- | The protocol that your Amazon Lightsail distribution uses when
--   establishing a connection with your origin to pull content.
origin_protocolPolicy :: Lens' Origin (Maybe OriginProtocolPolicyEnum)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.Origin.Origin
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.Origin.Origin
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.Origin.Origin
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.Origin.Origin
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.Origin.Origin
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.Origin.Origin
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.Origin.Origin


module Amazonka.Lightsail.Types.Operation

-- | Describes the API operation.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newOperation</a> smart constructor.
data Operation
Operation' :: Maybe OperationStatus -> Maybe Text -> Maybe ResourceType -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe Text -> Maybe ResourceLocation -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe OperationType -> Maybe Bool -> Operation

-- | The status of the operation.
[$sel:status:Operation'] :: Operation -> Maybe OperationStatus

-- | Details about the operation (e.g., <tt>Debian-1GB-Ohio-1</tt>).
[$sel:operationDetails:Operation'] :: Operation -> Maybe Text

-- | The resource type.
[$sel:resourceType:Operation'] :: Operation -> Maybe ResourceType

-- | The timestamp when the operation was initialized (e.g.,
--   <tt>1479816991.349</tt>).
[$sel:createdAt:Operation'] :: Operation -> Maybe POSIX

-- | The resource name.
[$sel:resourceName:Operation'] :: Operation -> Maybe Text

-- | The AWS Region and Availability Zone.
[$sel:location:Operation'] :: Operation -> Maybe ResourceLocation

-- | The timestamp when the status was changed (e.g.,
--   <tt>1479816991.349</tt>).
[$sel:statusChangedAt:Operation'] :: Operation -> Maybe POSIX

-- | The error details.
[$sel:errorDetails:Operation'] :: Operation -> Maybe Text

-- | The error code.
[$sel:errorCode:Operation'] :: Operation -> Maybe Text

-- | The ID of the operation.
[$sel:id:Operation'] :: Operation -> Maybe Text

-- | The type of operation.
[$sel:operationType:Operation'] :: Operation -> Maybe OperationType

-- | A Boolean value indicating whether the operation is terminal.
[$sel:isTerminal:Operation'] :: Operation -> Maybe Bool

-- | Create a value of <a>Operation</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:status:Operation'</a>, <a>operation_status</a> - The status of
--   the operation.
--   
--   <a>$sel:operationDetails:Operation'</a>,
--   <a>operation_operationDetails</a> - Details about the operation (e.g.,
--   <tt>Debian-1GB-Ohio-1</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceType:Operation'</a>, <a>operation_resourceType</a> -
--   The resource type.
--   
--   <a>$sel:createdAt:Operation'</a>, <a>operation_createdAt</a> - The
--   timestamp when the operation was initialized (e.g.,
--   <tt>1479816991.349</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceName:Operation'</a>, <a>operation_resourceName</a> -
--   The resource name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:location:Operation'</a>, <a>operation_location</a> - The AWS
--   Region and Availability Zone.
--   
--   <a>$sel:statusChangedAt:Operation'</a>,
--   <a>operation_statusChangedAt</a> - The timestamp when the status was
--   changed (e.g., <tt>1479816991.349</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:errorDetails:Operation'</a>, <a>operation_errorDetails</a> -
--   The error details.
--   
--   <a>$sel:errorCode:Operation'</a>, <a>operation_errorCode</a> - The
--   error code.
--   
--   <a>$sel:id:Operation'</a>, <a>operation_id</a> - The ID of the
--   operation.
--   
--   <a>$sel:operationType:Operation'</a>, <a>operation_operationType</a> -
--   The type of operation.
--   
--   <a>$sel:isTerminal:Operation'</a>, <a>operation_isTerminal</a> - A
--   Boolean value indicating whether the operation is terminal.
newOperation :: Operation

-- | The status of the operation.
operation_status :: Lens' Operation (Maybe OperationStatus)

-- | Details about the operation (e.g., <tt>Debian-1GB-Ohio-1</tt>).
operation_operationDetails :: Lens' Operation (Maybe Text)

-- | The resource type.
operation_resourceType :: Lens' Operation (Maybe ResourceType)

-- | The timestamp when the operation was initialized (e.g.,
--   <tt>1479816991.349</tt>).
operation_createdAt :: Lens' Operation (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | The resource name.
operation_resourceName :: Lens' Operation (Maybe Text)

-- | The AWS Region and Availability Zone.
operation_location :: Lens' Operation (Maybe ResourceLocation)

-- | The timestamp when the status was changed (e.g.,
--   <tt>1479816991.349</tt>).
operation_statusChangedAt :: Lens' Operation (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | The error details.
operation_errorDetails :: Lens' Operation (Maybe Text)

-- | The error code.
operation_errorCode :: Lens' Operation (Maybe Text)

-- | The ID of the operation.

-- | The type of operation.
