-- | Describes ports to open on an instance, the IP addresses allowed to
--   connect to the instance through the ports, and the protocol.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newPortInfo</a> smart constructor.
data PortInfo
PortInfo' :: Maybe Int -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe NetworkProtocol -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Int -> PortInfo

-- | The first port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP type for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP type for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:fromPort:PortInfo'] :: PortInfo -> Maybe Int

-- | The IPv4 address, or range of IPv4 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol.
--   
--   The <tt>ipv6Cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv6 addresses that are
--   allowed to connect to an instance.
--   
--   Examples:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>To allow the IP address <tt>192.0.2.44</tt>, specify
--   <tt>192.0.2.44</tt> or <tt>192.0.2.44/32</tt>.</li>
--   <li>To allow the IP addresses <tt>192.0.2.0</tt> to
--   <tt>192.0.2.255</tt>, specify <tt>192.0.2.0/24</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
[$sel:cidrs:PortInfo'] :: PortInfo -> Maybe [Text]

-- | The IP protocol name.
--   
--   The name can be one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>tcp</tt> - Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) provides
--   reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of streamed data between
--   applications running on hosts communicating by an IP network. If you
--   have an application that doesn't require reliable data stream service,
--   use UDP instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>all</tt> - All transport layer protocol types. For more
--   general information, see <a>Transport layer</a> on
--   <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li><tt>udp</tt> - With User Datagram Protocol (UDP), computer
--   applications can send messages (or datagrams) to other hosts on an
--   Internet Protocol (IP) network. Prior communications are not required
--   to set up transmission channels or data paths. Applications that don't
--   require reliable data stream service can use UDP, which provides a
--   connectionless datagram service that emphasizes reduced latency over
--   reliability. If you do require reliable data stream service, use TCP
--   instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>icmp</tt> - Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is used
--   to send error messages and operational information indicating success
--   or failure when communicating with an instance. For example, an error
--   is indicated when an instance could not be reached. When you specify
--   <tt>icmp</tt> as the <tt>protocol</tt>, you must specify the ICMP type
--   using the <tt>fromPort</tt> parameter, and ICMP code using the
--   <tt>toPort</tt> parameter.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:protocol:PortInfo'] :: PortInfo -> Maybe NetworkProtocol

-- | An alias that defines access for a preconfigured range of IP
--   addresses.
--   
--   The only alias currently supported is <tt>lightsail-connect</tt>,
--   which allows IP addresses of the browser-based RDP/SSH client in the
--   Lightsail console to connect to your instance.
[$sel:cidrListAliases:PortInfo'] :: PortInfo -> Maybe [Text]

-- | The IPv6 address, or range of IPv6 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol. Only devices with an IPv6 address can connect to an instance
--   through IPv6; otherwise, IPv4 should be used.
--   
--   The <tt>cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv4 addresses that are allowed
--   to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
[$sel:ipv6Cidrs:PortInfo'] :: PortInfo -> Maybe [Text]

-- | The last port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP code for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP code for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:toPort:PortInfo'] :: PortInfo -> Maybe Int

-- | Create a value of <a>PortInfo</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:fromPort:PortInfo'</a>, <a>portInfo_fromPort</a> - The first
--   port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP type for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP type for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:cidrs:PortInfo'</a>, <a>portInfo_cidrs</a> - The IPv4 address,
--   or range of IPv4 addresses (in CIDR notation) that are allowed to
--   connect to an instance through the ports, and the protocol.
--   
--   The <tt>ipv6Cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv6 addresses that are
--   allowed to connect to an instance.
--   
--   Examples:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>To allow the IP address <tt>192.0.2.44</tt>, specify
--   <tt>192.0.2.44</tt> or <tt>192.0.2.44/32</tt>.</li>
--   <li>To allow the IP addresses <tt>192.0.2.0</tt> to
--   <tt>192.0.2.255</tt>, specify <tt>192.0.2.0/24</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocol:PortInfo'</a>, <a>portInfo_protocol</a> - The IP
--   protocol name.
--   
--   The name can be one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>tcp</tt> - Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) provides
--   reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of streamed data between
--   applications running on hosts communicating by an IP network. If you
--   have an application that doesn't require reliable data stream service,
--   use UDP instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>all</tt> - All transport layer protocol types. For more
--   general information, see <a>Transport layer</a> on
--   <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li><tt>udp</tt> - With User Datagram Protocol (UDP), computer
--   applications can send messages (or datagrams) to other hosts on an
--   Internet Protocol (IP) network. Prior communications are not required
--   to set up transmission channels or data paths. Applications that don't
--   require reliable data stream service can use UDP, which provides a
--   connectionless datagram service that emphasizes reduced latency over
--   reliability. If you do require reliable data stream service, use TCP
--   instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>icmp</tt> - Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is used
--   to send error messages and operational information indicating success
--   or failure when communicating with an instance. For example, an error
--   is indicated when an instance could not be reached. When you specify
--   <tt>icmp</tt> as the <tt>protocol</tt>, you must specify the ICMP type
--   using the <tt>fromPort</tt> parameter, and ICMP code using the
--   <tt>toPort</tt> parameter.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:cidrListAliases:PortInfo'</a>, <a>portInfo_cidrListAliases</a>
--   - An alias that defines access for a preconfigured range of IP
--   addresses.
--   
--   The only alias currently supported is <tt>lightsail-connect</tt>,
--   which allows IP addresses of the browser-based RDP/SSH client in the
--   Lightsail console to connect to your instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipv6Cidrs:PortInfo'</a>, <a>portInfo_ipv6Cidrs</a> - The IPv6
--   address, or range of IPv6 addresses (in CIDR notation) that are
--   allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the protocol.
--   Only devices with an IPv6 address can connect to an instance through
--   IPv6; otherwise, IPv4 should be used.
--   
--   The <tt>cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv4 addresses that are allowed
--   to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:toPort:PortInfo'</a>, <a>portInfo_toPort</a> - The last port
--   in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP code for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP code for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
newPortInfo :: PortInfo

-- | The first port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP type for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP type for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
portInfo_fromPort :: Lens' PortInfo (Maybe Int)

-- | The IPv4 address, or range of IPv4 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol.
--   
--   The <tt>ipv6Cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv6 addresses that are
--   allowed to connect to an instance.
--   
--   Examples:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>To allow the IP address <tt>192.0.2.44</tt>, specify
--   <tt>192.0.2.44</tt> or <tt>192.0.2.44/32</tt>.</li>
--   <li>To allow the IP addresses <tt>192.0.2.0</tt> to
--   <tt>192.0.2.255</tt>, specify <tt>192.0.2.0/24</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
portInfo_cidrs :: Lens' PortInfo (Maybe [Text])

-- | The IP protocol name.
--   
--   The name can be one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>tcp</tt> - Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) provides
--   reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of streamed data between
--   applications running on hosts communicating by an IP network. If you
--   have an application that doesn't require reliable data stream service,
--   use UDP instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>all</tt> - All transport layer protocol types. For more
--   general information, see <a>Transport layer</a> on
--   <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li><tt>udp</tt> - With User Datagram Protocol (UDP), computer
--   applications can send messages (or datagrams) to other hosts on an
--   Internet Protocol (IP) network. Prior communications are not required
--   to set up transmission channels or data paths. Applications that don't
--   require reliable data stream service can use UDP, which provides a
--   connectionless datagram service that emphasizes reduced latency over
--   reliability. If you do require reliable data stream service, use TCP
--   instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>icmp</tt> - Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is used
--   to send error messages and operational information indicating success
--   or failure when communicating with an instance. For example, an error
--   is indicated when an instance could not be reached. When you specify
--   <tt>icmp</tt> as the <tt>protocol</tt>, you must specify the ICMP type
--   using the <tt>fromPort</tt> parameter, and ICMP code using the
--   <tt>toPort</tt> parameter.</li>
--   </ul>
portInfo_protocol :: Lens' PortInfo (Maybe NetworkProtocol)

-- | An alias that defines access for a preconfigured range of IP
--   addresses.
--   
--   The only alias currently supported is <tt>lightsail-connect</tt>,
--   which allows IP addresses of the browser-based RDP/SSH client in the
--   Lightsail console to connect to your instance.
portInfo_cidrListAliases :: Lens' PortInfo (Maybe [Text])

-- | The IPv6 address, or range of IPv6 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol. Only devices with an IPv6 address can connect to an instance
--   through IPv6; otherwise, IPv4 should be used.
--   
--   The <tt>cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv4 addresses that are allowed
--   to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
portInfo_ipv6Cidrs :: Lens' PortInfo (Maybe [Text])

-- | The last port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP code for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP code for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
portInfo_toPort :: Lens' PortInfo (Maybe Int)

-- | Describes the query string parameters that an Amazon Lightsail content
--   delivery network (CDN) distribution to bases caching on.
--   
--   For the query strings that you specify, your distribution caches
--   separate versions of the specified content based on the query string
--   values in viewer requests.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newQueryStringObject</a> smart constructor.
data QueryStringObject
QueryStringObject' :: Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Bool -> QueryStringObject

-- | The specific query strings that the distribution forwards to the
--   origin.
--   
--   Your distribution will cache content based on the specified query
--   strings.
--   
--   If the <tt>option</tt> parameter is true, then your distribution
--   forwards all query strings, regardless of what you specify using the
--   <tt>queryStringsAllowList</tt> parameter.
[$sel:queryStringsAllowList:QueryStringObject'] :: QueryStringObject -> Maybe [Text]

-- | Indicates whether the distribution forwards and caches based on query
--   strings.
[$sel:option:QueryStringObject'] :: QueryStringObject -> Maybe Bool

-- | Create a value of <a>QueryStringObject</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:queryStringsAllowList:QueryStringObject'</a>,
--   <a>queryStringObject_queryStringsAllowList</a> - The specific query
--   strings that the distribution forwards to the origin.
--   
--   Your distribution will cache content based on the specified query
--   strings.
--   
--   If the <tt>option</tt> parameter is true, then your distribution
--   forwards all query strings, regardless of what you specify using the
--   <tt>queryStringsAllowList</tt> parameter.
--   
--   <a>$sel:option:QueryStringObject'</a>, <a>queryStringObject_option</a>
--   - Indicates whether the distribution forwards and caches based on
--   query strings.
newQueryStringObject :: QueryStringObject

-- | The specific query strings that the distribution forwards to the
--   origin.
--   
--   Your distribution will cache content based on the specified query
--   strings.
--   
--   If the <tt>option</tt> parameter is true, then your distribution
--   forwards all query strings, regardless of what you specify using the
--   <tt>queryStringsAllowList</tt> parameter.
queryStringObject_queryStringsAllowList :: Lens' QueryStringObject (Maybe [Text])

-- | Indicates whether the distribution forwards and caches based on query
--   strings.
queryStringObject_option :: Lens' QueryStringObject (Maybe Bool)

-- | Describes the AWS Region.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRegionInfo</a> smart constructor.
data RegionInfo
RegionInfo' :: Maybe [AvailabilityZone] -> Maybe RegionName -> Maybe [AvailabilityZone] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> RegionInfo

-- | The Availability Zones. Follows the format <tt>us-east-2a</tt>
--   (case-sensitive).
[$sel:availabilityZones:RegionInfo'] :: RegionInfo -> Maybe [AvailabilityZone]

-- | The region name (e.g., <tt>us-east-2</tt>).
[$sel:name:RegionInfo'] :: RegionInfo -> Maybe RegionName

-- | The Availability Zones for databases. Follows the format
--   <tt>us-east-2a</tt> (case-sensitive).
[$sel:relationalDatabaseAvailabilityZones:RegionInfo'] :: RegionInfo -> Maybe [AvailabilityZone]

-- | The display name (e.g., <tt>Ohio</tt>).
[$sel:displayName:RegionInfo'] :: RegionInfo -> Maybe Text

-- | The continent code (e.g., <tt>NA</tt>, meaning North America).
[$sel:continentCode:RegionInfo'] :: RegionInfo -> Maybe Text

-- | The description of the AWS Region (e.g., <tt>This region is
--   recommended to serve users in the eastern United States and eastern
--   Canada</tt>).
[$sel:description:RegionInfo'] :: RegionInfo -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>RegionInfo</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:availabilityZones:RegionInfo'</a>,
--   <a>regionInfo_availabilityZones</a> - The Availability Zones. Follows
--   the format <tt>us-east-2a</tt> (case-sensitive).
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:RegionInfo'</a>, <a>regionInfo_name</a> - The region name
--   (e.g., <tt>us-east-2</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:relationalDatabaseAvailabilityZones:RegionInfo'</a>,
--   <a>regionInfo_relationalDatabaseAvailabilityZones</a> - The
--   Availability Zones for databases. Follows the format
--   <tt>us-east-2a</tt> (case-sensitive).
--   
--   <a>$sel:displayName:RegionInfo'</a>, <a>regionInfo_displayName</a> -
--   The display name (e.g., <tt>Ohio</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:continentCode:RegionInfo'</a>, <a>regionInfo_continentCode</a>
--   - The continent code (e.g., <tt>NA</tt>, meaning North America).
--   
--   <a>$sel:description:RegionInfo'</a>, <a>regionInfo_description</a> -
--   The description of the AWS Region (e.g., <tt>This region is
--   recommended to serve users in the eastern United States and eastern
--   Canada</tt>).
newRegionInfo :: RegionInfo

-- | The Availability Zones. Follows the format <tt>us-east-2a</tt>
--   (case-sensitive).
regionInfo_availabilityZones :: Lens' RegionInfo (Maybe [AvailabilityZone])

-- | The region name (e.g., <tt>us-east-2</tt>).
regionInfo_name :: Lens' RegionInfo (Maybe RegionName)

-- | The Availability Zones for databases. Follows the format
--   <tt>us-east-2a</tt> (case-sensitive).
regionInfo_relationalDatabaseAvailabilityZones :: Lens' RegionInfo (Maybe [AvailabilityZone])

-- | The display name (e.g., <tt>Ohio</tt>).
regionInfo_displayName :: Lens' RegionInfo (Maybe Text)

-- | The continent code (e.g., <tt>NA</tt>, meaning North America).
regionInfo_continentCode :: Lens' RegionInfo (Maybe Text)

-- | The description of the AWS Region (e.g., <tt>This region is
--   recommended to serve users in the eastern United States and eastern
--   Canada</tt>).
regionInfo_description :: Lens' RegionInfo (Maybe Text)

-- | Describes a database.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRelationalDatabase</a> smart constructor.
data RelationalDatabase
RelationalDatabase' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe RelationalDatabaseEndpoint -> Maybe Text -> Maybe ResourceType -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe ResourceLocation -> Maybe Text -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [PendingMaintenanceAction] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe PendingModifiedRelationalDatabaseValues -> Maybe Text -> Maybe RelationalDatabaseHardware -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Tag] -> RelationalDatabase

-- | The database engine version (for example, <tt>5.7.23</tt>).
[$sel:engineVersion:RelationalDatabase'] :: RelationalDatabase -> Maybe Text

-- | The bundle ID for the database. A bundle describes the performance
--   specifications for your database.
[$sel:relationalDatabaseBundleId:RelationalDatabase'] :: RelationalDatabase -> Maybe Text

-- | The master endpoint for the database.
[$sel:masterEndpoint:RelationalDatabase'] :: RelationalDatabase -> Maybe RelationalDatabaseEndpoint

-- | Describes the current state of the database.
[$sel:state:RelationalDatabase'] :: RelationalDatabase -> Maybe Text

-- | The Lightsail resource type for the database (for example,
--   <tt>RelationalDatabase</tt>).
[$sel:resourceType:RelationalDatabase'] :: RelationalDatabase -> Maybe ResourceType

-- | A Boolean value indicating whether the database is publicly
--   accessible.
[$sel:publiclyAccessible:RelationalDatabase'] :: RelationalDatabase -> Maybe Bool

-- | The master user name of the database.
[$sel:masterUsername:RelationalDatabase'] :: RelationalDatabase -> Maybe Text

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the database.
[$sel:arn:RelationalDatabase'] :: RelationalDatabase -> Maybe Text

-- | The timestamp when the database was created. Formatted in Unix time.
[$sel:createdAt:RelationalDatabase'] :: RelationalDatabase -> Maybe POSIX

-- | The Region name and Availability Zone where the database is located.
[$sel:location:RelationalDatabase'] :: RelationalDatabase -> Maybe ResourceLocation

-- | The database software (for example, <tt>MySQL</tt>).
[$sel:engine:RelationalDatabase'] :: RelationalDatabase -> Maybe Text

-- | The latest point in time to which the database can be restored.
--   Formatted in Unix time.
[$sel:latestRestorableTime:RelationalDatabase'] :: RelationalDatabase -> Maybe POSIX

-- | The weekly time range during which system maintenance can occur on the
--   database.
--   
--   In the format <tt>ddd:hh24:mi-ddd:hh24:mi</tt>. For example,
--   <tt>Tue:17:00-Tue:17:30</tt>.
[$sel:preferredMaintenanceWindow:RelationalDatabase'] :: RelationalDatabase -> Maybe Text

-- | The blueprint ID for the database. A blueprint describes the major
--   engine version of a database.
[$sel:relationalDatabaseBlueprintId:RelationalDatabase'] :: RelationalDatabase -> Maybe Text

-- | The certificate associated with the database.
[$sel:caCertificateIdentifier:RelationalDatabase'] :: RelationalDatabase -> Maybe Text

-- | The unique name of the database resource in Lightsail.
[$sel:name:RelationalDatabase'] :: RelationalDatabase -> Maybe Text

-- | A Boolean value indicating whether automated backup retention is
--   enabled for the database.
[$sel:backupRetentionEnabled:RelationalDatabase'] :: RelationalDatabase -> Maybe Bool

-- | The daily time range during which automated backups are created for
--   the database (for example, <tt>16:00-16:30</tt>).
[$sel:preferredBackupWindow:RelationalDatabase'] :: RelationalDatabase -> Maybe Text

-- | Describes the pending maintenance actions for the database.
[$sel:pendingMaintenanceActions:RelationalDatabase'] :: RelationalDatabase -> Maybe [PendingMaintenanceAction]

-- | The support code for the database. Include this code in your email to
--   support when you have questions about a database in Lightsail. This
--   code enables our support team to look up your Lightsail information
--   more easily.
[$sel:supportCode:RelationalDatabase'] :: RelationalDatabase -> Maybe Text

-- | Describes the secondary Availability Zone of a high availability
--   database.
--   
--   The secondary database is used for failover support of a high
--   availability database.
[$sel:secondaryAvailabilityZone:RelationalDatabase'] :: RelationalDatabase -> Maybe Text

-- | Describes pending database value modifications.
[$sel:pendingModifiedValues:RelationalDatabase'] :: RelationalDatabase -> Maybe PendingModifiedRelationalDatabaseValues

-- | The name of the master database created when the Lightsail database
--   resource is created.
[$sel:masterDatabaseName:RelationalDatabase'] :: RelationalDatabase -> Maybe Text

-- | Describes the hardware of the database.
[$sel:hardware:RelationalDatabase'] :: RelationalDatabase -> Maybe RelationalDatabaseHardware

-- | The status of parameter updates for the database.
[$sel:parameterApplyStatus:RelationalDatabase'] :: RelationalDatabase -> Maybe Text

-- | The tag keys and optional values for the resource. For more
--   information about tags in Lightsail, see the <a>Amazon Lightsail
--   Developer Guide</a>.
[$sel:tags:RelationalDatabase'] :: RelationalDatabase -> Maybe [Tag]

-- | Create a value of <a>RelationalDatabase</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:engineVersion:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_engineVersion</a> - The database engine version
--   (for example, <tt>5.7.23</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:relationalDatabaseBundleId:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_relationalDatabaseBundleId</a> - The bundle ID
--   for the database. A bundle describes the performance specifications
--   for your database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:masterEndpoint:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_masterEndpoint</a> - The master endpoint for the
--   database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:state:RelationalDatabase'</a>, <a>relationalDatabase_state</a>
--   - Describes the current state of the database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceType:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_resourceType</a> - The Lightsail resource type
--   for the database (for example, <tt>RelationalDatabase</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:publiclyAccessible:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_publiclyAccessible</a> - A Boolean value
--   indicating whether the database is publicly accessible.
--   
--   <a>$sel:masterUsername:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_masterUsername</a> - The master user name of the
--   database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:arn:RelationalDatabase'</a>, <a>relationalDatabase_arn</a> -
--   The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:createdAt:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_createdAt</a> - The timestamp when the database
--   was created. Formatted in Unix time.
--   
--   <a>$sel:location:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_location</a> - The Region name and Availability
--   Zone where the database is located.
--   
--   <a>$sel:engine:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_engine</a> - The database software (for example,
--   <tt>MySQL</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:latestRestorableTime:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_latestRestorableTime</a> - The latest point in
--   time to which the database can be restored. Formatted in Unix time.
--   
--   <a>$sel:preferredMaintenanceWindow:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_preferredMaintenanceWindow</a> - The weekly time
--   range during which system maintenance can occur on the database.
--   
--   In the format <tt>ddd:hh24:mi-ddd:hh24:mi</tt>. For example,
--   <tt>Tue:17:00-Tue:17:30</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:relationalDatabaseBlueprintId:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_relationalDatabaseBlueprintId</a> - The
--   blueprint ID for the database. A blueprint describes the major engine
--   version of a database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:caCertificateIdentifier:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_caCertificateIdentifier</a> - The certificate
--   associated with the database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:RelationalDatabase'</a>, <a>relationalDatabase_name</a> -
--   The unique name of the database resource in Lightsail.
--   
--   <a>$sel:backupRetentionEnabled:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_backupRetentionEnabled</a> - A Boolean value
--   indicating whether automated backup retention is enabled for the
--   database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:preferredBackupWindow:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_preferredBackupWindow</a> - The daily time range
--   during which automated backups are created for the database (for
--   example, <tt>16:00-16:30</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:pendingMaintenanceActions:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_pendingMaintenanceActions</a> - Describes the
--   pending maintenance actions for the database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:supportCode:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_supportCode</a> - The support code for the
--   database. Include this code in your email to support when you have
--   questions about a database in Lightsail. This code enables our support
--   team to look up your Lightsail information more easily.
--   
--   <a>$sel:secondaryAvailabilityZone:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_secondaryAvailabilityZone</a> - Describes the
--   secondary Availability Zone of a high availability database.
--   
--   The secondary database is used for failover support of a high
--   availability database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:pendingModifiedValues:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_pendingModifiedValues</a> - Describes pending
--   database value modifications.
--   
--   <a>$sel:masterDatabaseName:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_masterDatabaseName</a> - The name of the master
--   database created when the Lightsail database resource is created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:hardware:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_hardware</a> - Describes the hardware of the
--   database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:parameterApplyStatus:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_parameterApplyStatus</a> - The status of
--   parameter updates for the database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:RelationalDatabase'</a>, <a>relationalDatabase_tags</a> -
--   The tag keys and optional values for the resource. For more
--   information about tags in Lightsail, see the <a>Amazon Lightsail
--   Developer Guide</a>.
newRelationalDatabase :: RelationalDatabase

-- | The database engine version (for example, <tt>5.7.23</tt>).
relationalDatabase_engineVersion :: Lens' RelationalDatabase (Maybe Text)

-- | The bundle ID for the database. A bundle describes the performance
--   specifications for your database.
relationalDatabase_relationalDatabaseBundleId :: Lens' RelationalDatabase (Maybe Text)

-- | The master endpoint for the database.
relationalDatabase_masterEndpoint :: Lens' RelationalDatabase (Maybe RelationalDatabaseEndpoint)

-- | Describes the current state of the database.
relationalDatabase_state :: Lens' RelationalDatabase (Maybe Text)

-- | The Lightsail resource type for the database (for example,
--   <tt>RelationalDatabase</tt>).
relationalDatabase_resourceType :: Lens' RelationalDatabase (Maybe ResourceType)

-- | A Boolean value indicating whether the database is publicly
--   accessible.
relationalDatabase_publiclyAccessible :: Lens' RelationalDatabase (Maybe Bool)

-- | The master user name of the database.
relationalDatabase_masterUsername :: Lens' RelationalDatabase (Maybe Text)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the database.
relationalDatabase_arn :: Lens' RelationalDatabase (Maybe Text)

-- | The timestamp when the database was created. Formatted in Unix time.
relationalDatabase_createdAt :: Lens' RelationalDatabase (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | The Region name and Availability Zone where the database is located.
relationalDatabase_location :: Lens' RelationalDatabase (Maybe ResourceLocation)

-- | The database software (for example, <tt>MySQL</tt>).
relationalDatabase_engine :: Lens' RelationalDatabase (Maybe Text)

-- | The latest point in time to which the database can be restored.
--   Formatted in Unix time.
relationalDatabase_latestRestorableTime :: Lens' RelationalDatabase (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | The weekly time range during which system maintenance can occur on the
--   database.
--   
--   In the format <tt>ddd:hh24:mi-ddd:hh24:mi</tt>. For example,
--   <tt>Tue:17:00-Tue:17:30</tt>.
relationalDatabase_preferredMaintenanceWindow :: Lens' RelationalDatabase (Maybe Text)

-- | The blueprint ID for the database. A blueprint describes the major
--   engine version of a database.
relationalDatabase_relationalDatabaseBlueprintId :: Lens' RelationalDatabase (Maybe Text)

-- | The certificate associated with the database.
relationalDatabase_caCertificateIdentifier :: Lens' RelationalDatabase (Maybe Text)

-- | The unique name of the database resource in Lightsail.
relationalDatabase_name :: Lens' RelationalDatabase (Maybe Text)

-- | A Boolean value indicating whether automated backup retention is
--   enabled for the database.
relationalDatabase_backupRetentionEnabled :: Lens' RelationalDatabase (Maybe Bool)

-- | The daily time range during which automated backups are created for
--   the database (for example, <tt>16:00-16:30</tt>).
relationalDatabase_preferredBackupWindow :: Lens' RelationalDatabase (Maybe Text)

-- | Describes the pending maintenance actions for the database.
relationalDatabase_pendingMaintenanceActions :: Lens' RelationalDatabase (Maybe [PendingMaintenanceAction])

-- | The support code for the database. Include this code in your email to
--   support when you have questions about a database in Lightsail. This
--   code enables our support team to look up your Lightsail information
--   more easily.
relationalDatabase_supportCode :: Lens' RelationalDatabase (Maybe Text)

-- | Describes the secondary Availability Zone of a high availability
--   database.
--   
--   The secondary database is used for failover support of a high
--   availability database.
relationalDatabase_secondaryAvailabilityZone :: Lens' RelationalDatabase (Maybe Text)

-- | Describes pending database value modifications.
relationalDatabase_pendingModifiedValues :: Lens' RelationalDatabase (Maybe PendingModifiedRelationalDatabaseValues)

-- | The name of the master database created when the Lightsail database
--   resource is created.
relationalDatabase_masterDatabaseName :: Lens' RelationalDatabase (Maybe Text)

-- | Describes the hardware of the database.
relationalDatabase_hardware :: Lens' RelationalDatabase (Maybe RelationalDatabaseHardware)

-- | The status of parameter updates for the database.
relationalDatabase_parameterApplyStatus :: Lens' RelationalDatabase (Maybe Text)

-- | The tag keys and optional values for the resource. For more
--   information about tags in Lightsail, see the <a>Amazon Lightsail
--   Developer Guide</a>.
relationalDatabase_tags :: Lens' RelationalDatabase (Maybe [Tag])

-- | Describes a database image, or blueprint. A blueprint describes the
--   major engine version of a database.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRelationalDatabaseBlueprint</a> smart constructor.
data RelationalDatabaseBlueprint
RelationalDatabaseBlueprint' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe RelationalDatabaseEngine -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> RelationalDatabaseBlueprint

-- | The database engine version for the database blueprint (for example,
--   <tt>5.7.23</tt>).
[$sel:engineVersion:RelationalDatabaseBlueprint'] :: RelationalDatabaseBlueprint -> Maybe Text

-- | A Boolean value indicating whether the engine version is the default
--   for the database blueprint.
[$sel:isEngineDefault:RelationalDatabaseBlueprint'] :: RelationalDatabaseBlueprint -> Maybe Bool

-- | The description of the database engine version for the database
--   blueprint.
[$sel:engineVersionDescription:RelationalDatabaseBlueprint'] :: RelationalDatabaseBlueprint -> Maybe Text

-- | The database software of the database blueprint (for example,
--   <tt>MySQL</tt>).
[$sel:engine:RelationalDatabaseBlueprint'] :: RelationalDatabaseBlueprint -> Maybe RelationalDatabaseEngine

-- | The ID for the database blueprint.
[$sel:blueprintId:RelationalDatabaseBlueprint'] :: RelationalDatabaseBlueprint -> Maybe Text

-- | The description of the database engine for the database blueprint.
[$sel:engineDescription:RelationalDatabaseBlueprint'] :: RelationalDatabaseBlueprint -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>RelationalDatabaseBlueprint</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:engineVersion:RelationalDatabaseBlueprint'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabaseBlueprint_engineVersion</a> - The database engine
--   version for the database blueprint (for example, <tt>5.7.23</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:isEngineDefault:RelationalDatabaseBlueprint'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabaseBlueprint_isEngineDefault</a> - A Boolean value
--   indicating whether the engine version is the default for the database
--   blueprint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:engineVersionDescription:RelationalDatabaseBlueprint'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabaseBlueprint_engineVersionDescription</a> - The
--   description of the database engine version for the database blueprint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:engine:RelationalDatabaseBlueprint'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabaseBlueprint_engine</a> - The database software of
--   the database blueprint (for example, <tt>MySQL</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:blueprintId:RelationalDatabaseBlueprint'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabaseBlueprint_blueprintId</a> - The ID for the
--   database blueprint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:engineDescription:RelationalDatabaseBlueprint'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabaseBlueprint_engineDescription</a> - The description
--   of the database engine for the database blueprint.
newRelationalDatabaseBlueprint :: RelationalDatabaseBlueprint

-- | The database engine version for the database blueprint (for example,
--   <tt>5.7.23</tt>).
relationalDatabaseBlueprint_engineVersion :: Lens' RelationalDatabaseBlueprint (Maybe Text)

--   for the database blueprint.
relationalDatabaseBlueprint_isEngineDefault :: Lens' RelationalDatabaseBlueprint (Maybe Bool)

-- | The description of the database engine version for the database
--   blueprint.
relationalDatabaseBlueprint_engineVersionDescription :: Lens' RelationalDatabaseBlueprint (Maybe Text)

--   <tt>MySQL</tt>).
relationalDatabaseBlueprint_engine :: Lens' RelationalDatabaseBlueprint (Maybe RelationalDatabaseEngine)

relationalDatabaseBlueprint_blueprintId :: Lens' RelationalDatabaseBlueprint (Maybe Text)

-- | The description of the database engine for the database blueprint.
relationalDatabaseBlueprint_engineDescription :: Lens' RelationalDatabaseBlueprint (Maybe Text)

-- | Describes a database bundle. A bundle describes the performance
--   specifications of the database.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRelationalDatabaseBundle</a> smart constructor.
data RelationalDatabaseBundle
RelationalDatabaseBundle' :: Maybe Bool -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Double -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Double -> RelationalDatabaseBundle

-- | A Boolean value indicating whether the database bundle is encrypted.
[$sel:isEncrypted:RelationalDatabaseBundle'] :: RelationalDatabaseBundle -> Maybe Bool

-- | The number of virtual CPUs (vCPUs) for the database bundle.

-- | The data transfer rate per month in GB for the database bundle.
[$sel:transferPerMonthInGb:RelationalDatabaseBundle'] :: RelationalDatabaseBundle -> Maybe Int

[$sel:bundleId:RelationalDatabaseBundle'] :: RelationalDatabaseBundle -> Maybe Text

-- | The name for the database bundle.
[$sel:name:RelationalDatabaseBundle'] :: RelationalDatabaseBundle -> Maybe Text

-- | The size of the disk for the database bundle.
[$sel:diskSizeInGb:RelationalDatabaseBundle'] :: RelationalDatabaseBundle -> Maybe Int

-- | The cost of the database bundle in US currency.
[$sel:price:RelationalDatabaseBundle'] :: RelationalDatabaseBundle -> Maybe Double

-- | A Boolean value indicating whether the database bundle is active.
[$sel:isActive:RelationalDatabaseBundle'] :: RelationalDatabaseBundle -> Maybe Bool

-- | The amount of RAM in GB (for example, <tt>2.0</tt>) for the database
--   bundle.
[$sel:ramSizeInGb:RelationalDatabaseBundle'] :: RelationalDatabaseBundle -> Maybe Double

--   fields omitted.

-- | Describes the parameters of a database.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRelationalDatabaseParameter</a> smart constructor.
data RelationalDatabaseParameter
RelationalDatabaseParameter' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> RelationalDatabaseParameter

-- | Specifies the engine-specific parameter type.
[$sel:applyType:RelationalDatabaseParameter'] :: RelationalDatabaseParameter -> Maybe Text

-- | Specifies the value of the parameter.
[$sel:parameterValue:RelationalDatabaseParameter'] :: RelationalDatabaseParameter -> Maybe Text

-- | Indicates when parameter updates are applied.
--   
--   Can be <tt>immediate</tt> or <tt>pending-reboot</tt>.
[$sel:applyMethod:RelationalDatabaseParameter'] :: RelationalDatabaseParameter -> Maybe Text

-- | Specifies the valid data type for the parameter.
[$sel:dataType:RelationalDatabaseParameter'] :: RelationalDatabaseParameter -> Maybe Text

[$sel:isModifiable:RelationalDatabaseParameter'] :: RelationalDatabaseParameter -> Maybe Bool

-- | Specifies the valid range of values for the parameter.
[$sel:allowedValues:RelationalDatabaseParameter'] :: RelationalDatabaseParameter -> Maybe Text

-- | Specifies the name of the parameter.
[$sel:parameterName:RelationalDatabaseParameter'] :: RelationalDatabaseParameter -> Maybe Text

-- | Provides a description of the parameter.
[$sel:description:RelationalDatabaseParameter'] :: RelationalDatabaseParameter -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>RelationalDatabaseParameter</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.

--   fields.

-- | Describes a database snapshot.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRelationalDatabaseSnapshot</a> smart constructor.
data RelationalDatabaseSnapshot
RelationalDatabaseSnapshot' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe ResourceType -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe ResourceLocation -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Tag] -> RelationalDatabaseSnapshot

-- | The database engine version for the database snapshot (for example,
--   <tt>5.7.23</tt>).
[$sel:engineVersion:RelationalDatabaseSnapshot'] :: RelationalDatabaseSnapshot -> Maybe Text

-- | The state of the database snapshot.
[$sel:state:RelationalDatabaseSnapshot'] :: RelationalDatabaseSnapshot -> Maybe Text

-- | The name of the source database from which the database snapshot was
--   created.
[$sel:fromRelationalDatabaseName:RelationalDatabaseSnapshot'] :: RelationalDatabaseSnapshot -> Maybe Text

-- | The Lightsail resource type.
[$sel:resourceType:RelationalDatabaseSnapshot'] :: RelationalDatabaseSnapshot -> Maybe ResourceType

-- | The blueprint ID of the database from which the database snapshot was
--   created. A blueprint describes the major engine version of a database.
[$sel:fromRelationalDatabaseBlueprintId:RelationalDatabaseSnapshot'] :: RelationalDatabaseSnapshot -> Maybe Text

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the database snapshot.
[$sel:arn:RelationalDatabaseSnapshot'] :: RelationalDatabaseSnapshot -> Maybe Text

-- | The timestamp when the database snapshot was created.
[$sel:createdAt:RelationalDatabaseSnapshot'] :: RelationalDatabaseSnapshot -> Maybe POSIX

-- | The Region name and Availability Zone where the database snapshot is
--   located.
[$sel:location:RelationalDatabaseSnapshot'] :: RelationalDatabaseSnapshot -> Maybe ResourceLocation

-- | The software of the database snapshot (for example, <tt>MySQL</tt>)
[$sel:engine:RelationalDatabaseSnapshot'] :: RelationalDatabaseSnapshot -> Maybe Text

-- | The name of the database snapshot.
[$sel:name:RelationalDatabaseSnapshot'] :: RelationalDatabaseSnapshot -> Maybe Text

-- | The size of the disk in GB (for example, <tt>32</tt>) for the database
--   snapshot.
[$sel:sizeInGb:RelationalDatabaseSnapshot'] :: RelationalDatabaseSnapshot -> Maybe Int

-- | The support code for the database snapshot. Include this code in your
--   email to support when you have questions about a database snapshot in
--   Lightsail. This code enables our support team to look up your
--   Lightsail information more easily.
[$sel:supportCode:RelationalDatabaseSnapshot'] :: RelationalDatabaseSnapshot -> Maybe Text

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the database from which the database
--   snapshot was created.
[$sel:fromRelationalDatabaseArn:RelationalDatabaseSnapshot'] :: RelationalDatabaseSnapshot -> Maybe Text

-- | The bundle ID of the database from which the database snapshot was
--   created.

--   information about tags in Lightsail, see the <a>Amazon Lightsail
--   Developer Guide</a>.

-- | Describes the status of a SSL/TLS certificate renewal managed by
--   Amazon Lightsail.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRenewalSummary</a> smart constructor.
data RenewalSummary
RenewalSummary' :: Maybe RenewalStatus -> Maybe [DomainValidationRecord] -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe Text -> RenewalSummary

-- | The renewal status of the certificate.
--   
--   The following renewal status are possible:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>PendingAutoRenewal</tt></b> - Lightsail is attempting to
--   automatically validate the domain names of the certificate. No further
--   action is required.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>PendingValidation</tt></b> - Lightsail couldn't
--   automatically validate one or more domain names of the certificate.
--   You must take action to validate these domain names or the certificate
--   won't be renewed. Check to make sure your certificate's domain
--   validation records exist in your domain's DNS, and that your
--   certificate remains in use.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Success</tt></b> - All domain names in the certificate are
--   validated, and Lightsail renewed the certificate. No further action is
--   required.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Failed</tt></b> - One or more domain names were not
--   validated before the certificate expired, and Lightsail did not renew
--   the certificate. You can request a new certificate using the
--   <tt>CreateCertificate</tt> action.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:renewalStatus:RenewalSummary'] :: RenewalSummary -> Maybe RenewalStatus

-- | An array of objects that describe the domain validation records of the
--   certificate.
[$sel:domainValidationRecords:RenewalSummary'] :: RenewalSummary -> Maybe [DomainValidationRecord]

-- | The timestamp when the certificate was last updated.
[$sel:updatedAt:RenewalSummary'] :: RenewalSummary -> Maybe POSIX

-- | The reason for the renewal status of the certificate.
[$sel:renewalStatusReason:RenewalSummary'] :: RenewalSummary -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>RenewalSummary</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:renewalStatus:RenewalSummary'</a>,
--   <a>renewalSummary_renewalStatus</a> - The renewal status of the
--   certificate.
--   
--   The following renewal status are possible:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>PendingAutoRenewal</tt></b> - Lightsail is attempting to
--   automatically validate the domain names of the certificate. No further
--   action is required.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>PendingValidation</tt></b> - Lightsail couldn't
--   automatically validate one or more domain names of the certificate.
--   You must take action to validate these domain names or the certificate
--   won't be renewed. Check to make sure your certificate's domain
--   validation records exist in your domain's DNS, and that your
--   certificate remains in use.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Success</tt></b> - All domain names in the certificate are
--   validated, and Lightsail renewed the certificate. No further action is
--   required.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Failed</tt></b> - One or more domain names were not
--   validated before the certificate expired, and Lightsail did not renew
--   the certificate. You can request a new certificate using the
--   <tt>CreateCertificate</tt> action.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:domainValidationRecords:RenewalSummary'</a>,
--   <a>renewalSummary_domainValidationRecords</a> - An array of objects
--   that describe the domain validation records of the certificate.
--   
--   <a>$sel:updatedAt:RenewalSummary'</a>, <a>renewalSummary_updatedAt</a>
--   - The timestamp when the certificate was last updated.
--   
--   <a>$sel:renewalStatusReason:RenewalSummary'</a>,
--   <a>renewalSummary_renewalStatusReason</a> - The reason for the renewal
--   status of the certificate.
newRenewalSummary :: RenewalSummary

-- | The renewal status of the certificate.
--   
--   The following renewal status are possible:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>PendingAutoRenewal</tt></b> - Lightsail is attempting to
--   automatically validate the domain names of the certificate. No further
--   action is required.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>PendingValidation</tt></b> - Lightsail couldn't
--   automatically validate one or more domain names of the certificate.
--   You must take action to validate these domain names or the certificate
--   won't be renewed. Check to make sure your certificate's domain
--   validation records exist in your domain's DNS, and that your
--   certificate remains in use.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Success</tt></b> - All domain names in the certificate are
--   validated, and Lightsail renewed the certificate. No further action is
--   required.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Failed</tt></b> - One or more domain names were not
--   validated before the certificate expired, and Lightsail did not renew
--   the certificate. You can request a new certificate using the
--   <tt>CreateCertificate</tt> action.</li>
--   </ul>
renewalSummary_renewalStatus :: Lens' RenewalSummary (Maybe RenewalStatus)

-- | An array of objects that describe the domain validation records of the
--   certificate.
renewalSummary_domainValidationRecords :: Lens' RenewalSummary (Maybe [DomainValidationRecord])

-- | The timestamp when the certificate was last updated.
renewalSummary_updatedAt :: Lens' RenewalSummary (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | The reason for the renewal status of the certificate.
renewalSummary_renewalStatusReason :: Lens' RenewalSummary (Maybe Text)

--   have questions about an instance or another resource in Lightsail.
--   This code enables our support team to look up your Lightsail
--   information more easily.

--   <tt>Amazon_Linux-1GB-Ohio-1</tt>).

-- | Describes a tag key and optional value assigned to an Amazon Lightsail
--   resource.
--   
--   For more information about tags in Lightsail, see the <a>Amazon
--   Lightsail Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newTag</a> smart constructor.
data Tag
Tag' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Tag

-- | The value of the tag.
--   
--   Constraints: Tag values accept a maximum of 256 letters, numbers,
--   spaces in UTF-8, or the following characters: + - = . _ : / @
[$sel:value:Tag'] :: Tag -> Maybe Text

-- | The key of the tag.
--   
--   Constraints: Tag keys accept a maximum of 128 letters, numbers, spaces
--   in UTF-8, or the following characters: + - = . _ : / @
[$sel:key:Tag'] :: Tag -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>Tag</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:value:Tag'</a>, <a>tag_value</a> - The value of the tag.
--   
--   Constraints: Tag values accept a maximum of 256 letters, numbers,
--   spaces in UTF-8, or the following characters: + - = . _ : / @
--   
--   <a>$sel:key:Tag'</a>, <a>tag_key</a> - The key of the tag.
--   
--   Constraints: Tag keys accept a maximum of 128 letters, numbers, spaces
--   in UTF-8, or the following characters: + - = . _ : / @
newTag :: Tag

--   
--   Constraints: Tag values accept a maximum of 256 letters, numbers,
--   spaces in UTF-8, or the following characters: + - = . _ : / @
tag_value :: Lens' Tag (Maybe Text)

-- | The key of the tag.
--   
--   Constraints: Tag keys accept a maximum of 128 letters, numbers, spaces
--   in UTF-8, or the following characters: + - = . _ : / @
tag_key :: Lens' Tag (Maybe Text)


-- | Tests an alarm by displaying a banner on the Amazon Lightsail console.
--   If a notification trigger is configured for the specified alarm, the
--   test also sends a notification to the notification protocol
--   (<tt>Email</tt> and/or <tt>SMS</tt>) configured for the alarm.
--   
--   An alarm is used to monitor a single metric for one of your resources.
--   When a metric condition is met, the alarm can notify you by email, SMS
--   text message, and a banner displayed on the Amazon Lightsail console.
--   For more information, see <a>Alarms in Amazon Lightsail</a>.
module Amazonka.Lightsail.TestAlarm

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newTestAlarm</a> smart constructor.
data TestAlarm
TestAlarm' :: Text -> AlarmState -> TestAlarm

-- | The name of the alarm to test.
[$sel:alarmName:TestAlarm'] :: TestAlarm -> Text

-- | The alarm state to test.
--   
--   An alarm has the following possible states that can be tested:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>ALARM</tt> - The metric is outside of the defined
--   threshold.</li>
--   <li><tt>INSUFFICIENT_DATA</tt> - The alarm has just started, the
--   metric is not available, or not enough data is available for the
--   metric to determine the alarm state.</li>
--   <li><tt>OK</tt> - The metric is within the defined threshold.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:state:TestAlarm'] :: TestAlarm -> AlarmState

-- | Create a value of <a>TestAlarm</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:alarmName:TestAlarm'</a>, <a>testAlarm_alarmName</a> - The
--   name of the alarm to test.
--   
--   <a>$sel:state:TestAlarm'</a>, <a>testAlarm_state</a> - The alarm state
--   to test.
--   
--   An alarm has the following possible states that can be tested:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>ALARM</tt> - The metric is outside of the defined
--   threshold.</li>
--   <li><tt>INSUFFICIENT_DATA</tt> - The alarm has just started, the
--   metric is not available, or not enough data is available for the
--   metric to determine the alarm state.</li>
--   <li><tt>OK</tt> - The metric is within the defined threshold.</li>
--   </ul>
newTestAlarm :: Text -> AlarmState -> TestAlarm

-- | The name of the alarm to test.
testAlarm_alarmName :: Lens' TestAlarm Text

-- | The alarm state to test.
--   
--   An alarm has the following possible states that can be tested:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>ALARM</tt> - The metric is outside of the defined
--   threshold.</li>
--   <li><tt>INSUFFICIENT_DATA</tt> - The alarm has just started, the
--   metric is not available, or not enough data is available for the
--   metric to determine the alarm state.</li>
--   <li><tt>OK</tt> - The metric is within the defined threshold.</li>
--   </ul>
testAlarm_state :: Lens' TestAlarm AlarmState

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newTestAlarmResponse</a> smart constructor.
data TestAlarmResponse
TestAlarmResponse' :: Maybe [Operation] -> Int -> TestAlarmResponse

-- | An array of objects that describe the result of the action, such as
--   the status of the request, the timestamp of the request, and the
--   resources affected by the request.
[$sel:operations:TestAlarmResponse'] :: TestAlarmResponse -> Maybe [Operation]

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:TestAlarmResponse'] :: TestAlarmResponse -> Int

--   omitted.

--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.

--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:

--   describe the result of the action, such as the status of the request,
--   the timestamp of the request, and the resources affected by the
--   request.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:TestAlarmResponse'</a>,
--   <a>testAlarmResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http status code.
newTestAlarmResponse :: Int -> TestAlarmResponse

-- | Adds one or more tags to the specified Amazon Lightsail resource. Each
--   resource can have a maximum of 50 tags. Each tag consists of a key and
--   an optional value. Tag keys must be unique per resource. For more
--   information about tags, see the <a>Amazon Lightsail Developer
--   Guide</a>.
--   
--   The <tt>tag resource</tt> operation supports tag-based access control
--   via request tags and resource tags applied to the resource identified
--   by <tt>resource name</tt>. For more information, see the <a>Amazon
--   Lightsail Developer Guide</a>.
module Amazonka.Lightsail.TagResource

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newTagResource</a> smart constructor.
data TagResource
TagResource' :: Maybe Text -> Text -> [Tag] -> TagResource

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource to which you want to
--   add a tag.
[$sel:resourceArn:TagResource'] :: TagResource -> Maybe Text

-- | The name of the resource to which you are adding tags.
[$sel:resourceName:TagResource'] :: TagResource -> Text

-- | The tag key and optional value.
[$sel:tags:TagResource'] :: TagResource -> [Tag]

-- | Create a value of <a>TagResource</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceArn:TagResource'</a>, <a>tagResource_resourceArn</a> -
--   The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource to which you want to
--   add a tag.
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceName:TagResource'</a>, <a>tagResource_resourceName</a>
--   - The name of the resource to which you are adding tags.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:TagResource'</a>, <a>tagResource_tags</a> - The tag key
--   and optional value.
newTagResource :: Text -> TagResource

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource to which you want to
--   add a tag.
tagResource_resourceArn :: Lens' TagResource (Maybe Text)

-- | The name of the resource to which you are adding tags.
tagResource_resourceName :: Lens' TagResource Text

-- | The tag key and optional value.
tagResource_tags :: Lens' TagResource [Tag]

-- | Stops a specific Amazon Lightsail instance that is currently running.
--   
--   When you start a stopped instance, Lightsail assigns a new public IP
--   address to the instance. To use the same IP address after stopping and
--   starting an instance, create a static IP address and attach it to the
--   instance. For more information, see the <a>Amazon Lightsail Developer
--   Guide</a>.
--   
--   The <tt>stop instance</tt> operation supports tag-based access control
--   via resource tags applied to the resource identified by <tt>instance
--   name</tt>. For more information, see the <a>Amazon Lightsail Developer
--   Guide</a>.
module Amazonka.Lightsail.StopInstance

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newStopInstance</a> smart constructor.
data StopInstance
StopInstance' :: Maybe Bool -> Text -> StopInstance

-- | When set to <tt>True</tt>, forces a Lightsail instance that is stuck
--   in a <tt>stopping</tt> state to stop.
--   
--   Only use the <tt>force</tt> parameter if your instance is stuck in the
--   <tt>stopping</tt> state. In any other state, your instance should stop
--   normally without adding this parameter to your API request.
[$sel:force:StopInstance'] :: StopInstance -> Maybe Bool

-- | The name of the instance (a virtual private server) to stop.
[$sel:instanceName:StopInstance'] :: StopInstance -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>StopInstance</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:force:StopInstance'</a>, <a>stopInstance_force</a> - When set
--   to <tt>True</tt>, forces a Lightsail instance that is stuck in a
--   <tt>stopping</tt> state to stop.
--   
--   Only use the <tt>force</tt> parameter if your instance is stuck in the
--   <tt>stopping</tt> state. In any other state, your instance should stop
--   normally without adding this parameter to your API request.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceName:StopInstance'</a>,
--   <a>stopInstance_instanceName</a> - The name of the instance (a virtual
--   private server) to stop.
newStopInstance :: Text -> StopInstance

-- | When set to <tt>True</tt>, forces a Lightsail instance that is stuck
--   in a <tt>stopping</tt> state to stop.
--   
--   Only use the <tt>force</tt> parameter if your instance is stuck in the
--   <tt>stopping</tt> state. In any other state, your instance should stop
--   normally without adding this parameter to your API request.
stopInstance_force :: Lens' StopInstance (Maybe Bool)

-- | The name of the instance (a virtual private server) to stop.
stopInstance_instanceName :: Lens' StopInstance Text

-- | Starts a specific Amazon Lightsail instance from a stopped state. To

--   The <tt>start instance</tt> operation supports tag-based access

-- | Sets the Amazon Lightsail resources that can access the specified
--   Lightsail bucket.
--   
--   Lightsail buckets currently support setting access for Lightsail
--   instances in the same AWS Region.
module Amazonka.Lightsail.SetResourceAccessForBucket

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newSetResourceAccessForBucket</a> smart constructor.
data SetResourceAccessForBucket
SetResourceAccessForBucket' :: Text -> Text -> ResourceBucketAccess -> SetResourceAccessForBucket

-- | The name of the Lightsail instance for which to set bucket access. The
--   instance must be in a running or stopped state.
[$sel:resourceName:SetResourceAccessForBucket'] :: SetResourceAccessForBucket -> Text

-- | The name of the bucket for which to set access to another Lightsail
--   resource.
[$sel:bucketName:SetResourceAccessForBucket'] :: SetResourceAccessForBucket -> Text

-- | The access setting.
--   
--   The following access settings are available:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>allow</tt> - Allows access to the bucket and its objects.</li>
--   <li><tt>deny</tt> - Denies access to the bucket and its objects. Use
--   this setting to remove access for a resource previously set to
--   <tt>allow</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:access:SetResourceAccessForBucket'] :: SetResourceAccessForBucket -> ResourceBucketAccess

-- | Create a value of <a>SetResourceAccessForBucket</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceName:SetResourceAccessForBucket'</a>,
--   <a>setResourceAccessForBucket_resourceName</a> - The name of the
--   Lightsail instance for which to set bucket access. The instance must
--   be in a running or stopped state.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bucketName:SetResourceAccessForBucket'</a>,
--   <a>setResourceAccessForBucket_bucketName</a> - The name of the bucket
--   for which to set access to another Lightsail resource.
--   
--   <a>$sel:access:SetResourceAccessForBucket'</a>,
--   <a>setResourceAccessForBucket_access</a> - The access setting.
--   
--   The following access settings are available:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>allow</tt> - Allows access to the bucket and its objects.</li>
--   <li><tt>deny</tt> - Denies access to the bucket and its objects. Use
--   this setting to remove access for a resource previously set to
--   <tt>allow</tt>.</li>

--

-- | Sets the IP address type for an Amazon Lightsail resource.
--   
--   Use this action to enable dual-stack for a resource, which enables
--   IPv4 and IPv6 for the specified resource. Alternately, you can use
--   this action to disable dual-stack, and enable IPv4 only.
module Amazonka.Lightsail.SetIpAddressType

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newSetIpAddressType</a> smart constructor.
data SetIpAddressType
SetIpAddressType' :: ResourceType -> Text -> IpAddressType -> SetIpAddressType

-- | The resource type.
--   
--   The possible values are <tt>Distribution</tt>, <tt>Instance</tt>, and
--   <tt>LoadBalancer</tt>.
--   
--   Distribution-related APIs are available only in the N. Virginia
--   (<tt>us-east-1</tt>) AWS Region. Set your AWS Region configuration to
--   <tt>us-east-1</tt> to create, view, or edit distributions.
[$sel:resourceType:SetIpAddressType'] :: SetIpAddressType -> ResourceType

-- | The name of the resource for which to set the IP address type.
[$sel:resourceName:SetIpAddressType'] :: SetIpAddressType -> Text

-- | The IP address type to set for the specified resource.
--   
--   The possible values are <tt>ipv4</tt> for IPv4 only, and
--   <tt>dualstack</tt> for IPv4 and IPv6.

--   omitted.

-- | Sends a verification request to an email contact method to ensure it's
--   owned by the requester. SMS contact methods don't need to be verified.
--   
--   A contact method is used to send you notifications about your Amazon
--   Lightsail resources. You can add one email address and one mobile
--   phone number contact method in each AWS Region. However, SMS text
--   messaging is not supported in some AWS Regions, and SMS text messages
--   cannot be sent to some countries/regions. For more information, see
--   <a>Notifications in Amazon Lightsail</a>.
--   
--   A verification request is sent to the contact method when you
--   initially create it. Use this action to send another verification
--   request if a previous verification request was deleted, or has
--   expired.
--   
--   Notifications are not sent to an email contact method until after it
--   is verified, and confirmed as valid.
module Amazonka.Lightsail.SendContactMethodVerification

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newSendContactMethodVerification</a> smart constructor.
data SendContactMethodVerification
SendContactMethodVerification' :: ContactMethodVerificationProtocol -> SendContactMethodVerification

-- | The protocol to verify, such as <tt>Email</tt> or <tt>SMS</tt> (text
--   messaging).
[$sel:protocol:SendContactMethodVerification'] :: SendContactMethodVerification -> ContactMethodVerificationProtocol

-- | Create a value of <a>SendContactMethodVerification</a> with all
--   optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocol:SendContactMethodVerification'</a>,
--   <a>sendContactMethodVerification_protocol</a> - The protocol to
--   verify, such as <tt>Email</tt> or <tt>SMS</tt> (text messaging).
newSendContactMethodVerification :: ContactMethodVerificationProtocol -> SendContactMethodVerification

-- | The protocol to verify, such as <tt>Email</tt> or <tt>SMS</tt> (text
--   messaging).

-- | Deletes currently cached content from your Amazon Lightsail content
--   delivery network (CDN) distribution.
--   
--   After resetting the cache, the next time a content request is made,
--   your distribution pulls, serves, and caches it from the origin.

-- | Deletes a specific static IP from your account.
module Amazonka.Lightsail.ReleaseStaticIp

-- | Registers a container image to your Amazon Lightsail container
--   service.
--   
--   This action is not required if you install and use the Lightsail
--   Control (lightsailctl) plugin to push container images to your
--   Lightsail container service. For more information, see <a>Pushing and
--   managing container images on your Amazon Lightsail container
--   services</a> in the <i>Amazon Lightsail Developer Guide</i>.
module Amazonka.Lightsail.RegisterContainerImage

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newRegisterContainerImage</a> smart constructor.
data RegisterContainerImage
RegisterContainerImage' :: Text -> Text -> Text -> RegisterContainerImage

-- | The name of the container service for which to register a container
--   image.
[$sel:serviceName:RegisterContainerImage'] :: RegisterContainerImage -> Text

-- | The label for the container image when it's registered to the
--   container service.
--   
--   Use a descriptive label that you can use to track the different
--   versions of your registered container images.
--   
--   Use the <tt>GetContainerImages</tt> action to return the container
--   images registered to a Lightsail container service. The label is the
--   <tt>&lt;imagelabel&gt;</tt> portion of the following image name
--   example:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><pre>:container-service-1.&lt;imagelabel&gt;.1</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If the name of your container service is <tt>mycontainerservice</tt>,
--   and the label that you specify is <tt>mystaticwebsite</tt>, then the
--   name of the registered container image will be
--   <tt>:mycontainerservice.mystaticwebsite.1</tt>.
--   
--   The number at the end of these image name examples represents the
--   version of the registered container image. If you push and register
--   another container image to the same Lightsail container service, with
--   the same label, then the version number for the new registered
--   container image will be <tt>2</tt>. If you push and register another
--   container image, the version number will be <tt>3</tt>, and so on.
[$sel:label:RegisterContainerImage'] :: RegisterContainerImage -> Text

-- | The digest of the container image to be registered.
[$sel:digest:RegisterContainerImage'] :: RegisterContainerImage -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>RegisterContainerImage</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:serviceName:RegisterContainerImage'</a>,
--   <a>registerContainerImage_serviceName</a> - The name of the container
--   service for which to register a container image.
--   
--   <a>$sel:label:RegisterContainerImage'</a>,
--   <a>registerContainerImage_label</a> - The label for the container
--   image when it's registered to the container service.
--   
--   Use a descriptive label that you can use to track the different
--   versions of your registered container images.
--   
--   Use the <tt>GetContainerImages</tt> action to return the container
--   images registered to a Lightsail container service. The label is the
--   <tt>&lt;imagelabel&gt;</tt> portion of the following image name
--   example:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><pre>:container-service-1.&lt;imagelabel&gt;.1</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If the name of your container service is <tt>mycontainerservice</tt>,
--   and the label that you specify is <tt>mystaticwebsite</tt>, then the
--   name of the registered container image will be
--   <tt>:mycontainerservice.mystaticwebsite.1</tt>.
--   
--   The number at the end of these image name examples represents the
--   version of the registered container image. If you push and register
--   another container image to the same Lightsail container service, with
--   the same label, then the version number for the new registered
--   container image will be <tt>2</tt>. If you push and register another
--   container image, the version number will be <tt>3</tt>, and so on.
--   
--   <a>$sel:digest:RegisterContainerImage'</a>,
--   <a>registerContainerImage_digest</a> - The digest of the container
--   image to be registered.
newRegisterContainerImage :: Text -> Text -> Text -> RegisterContainerImage

-- | The name of the container service for which to register a container
--   image.
registerContainerImage_serviceName :: Lens' RegisterContainerImage Text

-- | The label for the container image when it's registered to the
--   container service.
--   
--   Use a descriptive label that you can use to track the different
--   versions of your registered container images.
--   
--   Use the <tt>GetContainerImages</tt> action to return the container
--   images registered to a Lightsail container service. The label is the
--   <tt>&lt;imagelabel&gt;</tt> portion of the following image name
--   example:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><pre>:container-service-1.&lt;imagelabel&gt;.1</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If the name of your container service is <tt>mycontainerservice</tt>,
--   and the label that you specify is <tt>mystaticwebsite</tt>, then the
--   name of the registered container image will be
--   <tt>:mycontainerservice.mystaticwebsite.1</tt>.
--   
--   The number at the end of these image name examples represents the
--   version of the registered container image. If you push and register
--   another container image to the same Lightsail container service, with
--   the same label, then the version number for the new registered
--   container image will be <tt>2</tt>. If you push and register another
--   container image, the version number will be <tt>3</tt>, and so on.
registerContainerImage_label :: Lens' RegisterContainerImage Text

-- | The digest of the container image to be registered.
registerContainerImage_digest :: Lens' RegisterContainerImage Text

--   constructor.
data RegisterContainerImageResponse
RegisterContainerImageResponse' :: Maybe ContainerImage -> Int -> RegisterContainerImageResponse
[$sel:containerImage:RegisterContainerImageResponse'] :: RegisterContainerImageResponse -> Maybe ContainerImage

[$sel:httpStatus:RegisterContainerImageResponse'] :: RegisterContainerImageResponse -> Int

-- | Opens ports for a specific Amazon Lightsail instance, and specifies
--   the IP addresses allowed to connect to the instance through the ports,
--   and the protocol. This action also closes all currently open ports
--   that are not included in the request. Include all of the ports and the
--   protocols you want to open in your
--   <tt>PutInstancePublicPorts</tt>request. Or use the
--   <tt>OpenInstancePublicPorts</tt> action to open ports without closing
--   currently open ports.
--   
--   The <tt>PutInstancePublicPorts</tt> action supports tag-based access
--   control via resource tags applied to the resource identified by
--   <tt>instanceName</tt>. For more information, see the <a>Amazon
--   Lightsail Developer Guide</a>.
module Amazonka.Lightsail.PutInstancePublicPorts

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newPutInstancePublicPorts</a> smart constructor.

--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:

--   describe the ports to open for the specified instance.

--   for which to open ports.

--   instance.
