-- | Creates or updates an alarm, and associates it with the specified
--   metric.
--   
--   An alarm is used to monitor a single metric for one of your resources.
--   When a metric condition is met, the alarm can notify you by email, SMS
--   text message, and a banner displayed on the Amazon Lightsail console.
--   For more information, see <a>Alarms in Amazon Lightsail</a>.
--   
--   When this action creates an alarm, the alarm state is immediately set
--   to <tt>INSUFFICIENT_DATA</tt>. The alarm is then evaluated and its
--   state is set appropriately. Any actions associated with the new state
--   are then executed.
--   
--   When you update an existing alarm, its state is left unchanged, but
--   the update completely overwrites the previous configuration of the
--   alarm. The alarm is then evaluated with the updated configuration.
module Amazonka.Lightsail.PutAlarm

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newPutAlarm</a> smart constructor.
data PutAlarm
PutAlarm' :: Maybe TreatMissingData -> Maybe [ContactProtocol] -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe [AlarmState] -> Text -> MetricName -> Text -> ComparisonOperator -> Double -> Int -> PutAlarm

-- | Sets how this alarm will handle missing data points.
--   
--   An alarm can treat missing data in the following ways:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>breaching</tt> - Assume the missing data is not within the
--   threshold. Missing data counts towards the number of times the metric
--   is not within the threshold.</li>
--   <li><tt>notBreaching</tt> - Assume the missing data is within the
--   threshold. Missing data does not count towards the number of times the
--   metric is not within the threshold.</li>
--   <li><tt>ignore</tt> - Ignore the missing data. Maintains the current
--   alarm state.</li>
--   <li><tt>missing</tt> - Missing data is treated as missing.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If <tt>treatMissingData</tt> is not specified, the default behavior of
--   <tt>missing</tt> is used.
[$sel:treatMissingData:PutAlarm'] :: PutAlarm -> Maybe TreatMissingData

-- | The contact protocols to use for the alarm, such as <tt>Email</tt>,
--   <tt>SMS</tt> (text messaging), or both.
--   
--   A notification is sent via the specified contact protocol if
--   notifications are enabled for the alarm, and when the alarm is
--   triggered.
--   
--   A notification is not sent if a contact protocol is not specified, if
--   the specified contact protocol is not configured in the AWS Region, or
--   if notifications are not enabled for the alarm using the
--   <tt>notificationEnabled</tt> paramater.
--   
--   Use the <tt>CreateContactMethod</tt> action to configure a contact
--   protocol in an AWS Region.
[$sel:contactProtocols:PutAlarm'] :: PutAlarm -> Maybe [ContactProtocol]

-- | The number of data points that must be not within the specified
--   threshold to trigger the alarm. If you are setting an "M out of N"
--   alarm, this value (<tt>datapointsToAlarm</tt>) is the M.
[$sel:datapointsToAlarm:PutAlarm'] :: PutAlarm -> Maybe Int

-- | Indicates whether the alarm is enabled.
--   
--   Notifications are enabled by default if you don't specify this
--   parameter.
[$sel:notificationEnabled:PutAlarm'] :: PutAlarm -> Maybe Bool

-- | The alarm states that trigger a notification.
--   
--   An alarm has the following possible states:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>ALARM</tt> - The metric is outside of the defined
--   threshold.</li>
--   <li><tt>INSUFFICIENT_DATA</tt> - The alarm has just started, the
--   metric is not available, or not enough data is available for the
--   metric to determine the alarm state.</li>
--   <li><tt>OK</tt> - The metric is within the defined threshold.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   When you specify a notification trigger, the <tt>ALARM</tt> state must
--   be specified. The <tt>INSUFFICIENT_DATA</tt> and <tt>OK</tt> states
--   can be specified in addition to the <tt>ALARM</tt> state.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>If you specify <tt>OK</tt> as an alarm trigger, a notification is
--   sent when the alarm switches from an <tt>ALARM</tt> or
--   <tt>INSUFFICIENT_DATA</tt> alarm state to an <tt>OK</tt> state. This
--   can be thought of as an <i>all clear</i> alarm notification.</li>
--   <li>If you specify <tt>INSUFFICIENT_DATA</tt> as the alarm trigger, a
--   notification is sent when the alarm switches from an <tt>OK</tt> or
--   <tt>ALARM</tt> alarm state to an <tt>INSUFFICIENT_DATA</tt>
--   state.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The notification trigger defaults to <tt>ALARM</tt> if you don't
--   specify this parameter.
[$sel:notificationTriggers:PutAlarm'] :: PutAlarm -> Maybe [AlarmState]

-- | The name for the alarm. Specify the name of an existing alarm to
--   update, and overwrite the previous configuration of the alarm.
[$sel:alarmName:PutAlarm'] :: PutAlarm -> Text

-- | The name of the metric to associate with the alarm.
--   
--   You can configure up to two alarms per metric.
--   
--   The following metrics are available for each resource type:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b>Instances</b>: <tt>BurstCapacityPercentage</tt>,
--   <tt>BurstCapacityTime</tt>, <tt>CPUUtilization</tt>,
--   <tt>NetworkIn</tt>, <tt>NetworkOut</tt>, <tt>StatusCheckFailed</tt>,
--   <tt>StatusCheckFailed_Instance</tt>, and
--   <tt>StatusCheckFailed_System</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b>Load balancers</b>: <tt>ClientTLSNegotiationErrorCount</tt>,
--   <tt>HealthyHostCount</tt>, <tt>UnhealthyHostCount</tt>,
--   <tt>HTTPCode_LB_4XX_Count</tt>, <tt>HTTPCode_LB_5XX_Count</tt>,
--   <tt>HTTPCode_Instance_2XX_Count</tt>,
--   <tt>HTTPCode_Instance_3XX_Count</tt>,
--   <tt>HTTPCode_Instance_4XX_Count</tt>,
--   <tt>HTTPCode_Instance_5XX_Count</tt>, <tt>InstanceResponseTime</tt>,
--   <tt>RejectedConnectionCount</tt>, and <tt>RequestCount</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b>Relational databases</b>: <tt>CPUUtilization</tt>,
--   <tt>DatabaseConnections</tt>, <tt>DiskQueueDepth</tt>,
--   <tt>FreeStorageSpace</tt>, <tt>NetworkReceiveThroughput</tt>, and
--   <tt>NetworkTransmitThroughput</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about these metrics, see <a>Metrics available in
--   Lightsail</a>.
[$sel:metricName:PutAlarm'] :: PutAlarm -> MetricName

-- | The name of the Lightsail resource that will be monitored.
--   
--   Instances, load balancers, and relational databases are the only
--   Lightsail resources that can currently be monitored by alarms.
[$sel:monitoredResourceName:PutAlarm'] :: PutAlarm -> Text

-- | The arithmetic operation to use when comparing the specified statistic
--   to the threshold. The specified statistic value is used as the first
--   operand.
[$sel:comparisonOperator:PutAlarm'] :: PutAlarm -> ComparisonOperator

-- | The value against which the specified statistic is compared.
[$sel:threshold:PutAlarm'] :: PutAlarm -> Double

-- | The number of most recent periods over which data is compared to the
--   specified threshold. If you are setting an "M out of N" alarm, this
--   value (<tt>evaluationPeriods</tt>) is the N.
--   
--   If you are setting an alarm that requires that a number of consecutive
--   data points be breaching to trigger the alarm, this value specifies
--   the rolling period of time in which data points are evaluated.
--   
--   Each evaluation period is five minutes long. For example, specify an
--   evaluation period of 24 to evaluate a metric over a rolling period of
--   two hours.
--   
--   You can specify a minimum valuation period of 1 (5 minutes), and a
--   maximum evaluation period of 288 (24 hours).
[$sel:evaluationPeriods:PutAlarm'] :: PutAlarm -> Int

-- | Create a value of <a>PutAlarm</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:treatMissingData:PutAlarm'</a>,
--   <a>putAlarm_treatMissingData</a> - Sets how this alarm will handle
--   missing data points.
--   
--   An alarm can treat missing data in the following ways:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>breaching</tt> - Assume the missing data is not within the
--   threshold. Missing data counts towards the number of times the metric
--   is not within the threshold.</li>
--   <li><tt>notBreaching</tt> - Assume the missing data is within the
--   threshold. Missing data does not count towards the number of times the
--   metric is not within the threshold.</li>
--   <li><tt>ignore</tt> - Ignore the missing data. Maintains the current
--   alarm state.</li>
--   <li><tt>missing</tt> - Missing data is treated as missing.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If <tt>treatMissingData</tt> is not specified, the default behavior of
--   <tt>missing</tt> is used.
--   
--   <a>$sel:contactProtocols:PutAlarm'</a>,
--   <a>putAlarm_contactProtocols</a> - The contact protocols to use for
--   the alarm, such as <tt>Email</tt>, <tt>SMS</tt> (text messaging), or
--   both.
--   
--   A notification is sent via the specified contact protocol if
--   notifications are enabled for the alarm, and when the alarm is
--   triggered.
--   
--   A notification is not sent if a contact protocol is not specified, if
--   the specified contact protocol is not configured in the AWS Region, or
--   if notifications are not enabled for the alarm using the
--   <tt>notificationEnabled</tt> paramater.
--   
--   Use the <tt>CreateContactMethod</tt> action to configure a contact
--   protocol in an AWS Region.
--   
--   <a>$sel:datapointsToAlarm:PutAlarm'</a>,
--   <a>putAlarm_datapointsToAlarm</a> - The number of data points that
--   must be not within the specified threshold to trigger the alarm. If
--   you are setting an "M out of N" alarm, this value
--   (<tt>datapointsToAlarm</tt>) is the M.
--   
--   <a>$sel:notificationEnabled:PutAlarm'</a>,
--   <a>putAlarm_notificationEnabled</a> - Indicates whether the alarm is
--   enabled.
--   
--   Notifications are enabled by default if you don't specify this
--   parameter.
--   
--   <a>$sel:notificationTriggers:PutAlarm'</a>,
--   <a>putAlarm_notificationTriggers</a> - The alarm states that trigger a
--   notification.
--   
--   An alarm has the following possible states:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>ALARM</tt> - The metric is outside of the defined
--   threshold.</li>
--   <li><tt>INSUFFICIENT_DATA</tt> - The alarm has just started, the
--   metric is not available, or not enough data is available for the
--   metric to determine the alarm state.</li>
--   <li><tt>OK</tt> - The metric is within the defined threshold.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   When you specify a notification trigger, the <tt>ALARM</tt> state must
--   be specified. The <tt>INSUFFICIENT_DATA</tt> and <tt>OK</tt> states
--   can be specified in addition to the <tt>ALARM</tt> state.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>If you specify <tt>OK</tt> as an alarm trigger, a notification is
--   sent when the alarm switches from an <tt>ALARM</tt> or
--   <tt>INSUFFICIENT_DATA</tt> alarm state to an <tt>OK</tt> state. This
--   can be thought of as an <i>all clear</i> alarm notification.</li>
--   <li>If you specify <tt>INSUFFICIENT_DATA</tt> as the alarm trigger, a
--   notification is sent when the alarm switches from an <tt>OK</tt> or
--   <tt>ALARM</tt> alarm state to an <tt>INSUFFICIENT_DATA</tt>
--   state.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The notification trigger defaults to <tt>ALARM</tt> if you don't
--   specify this parameter.
--   
--   <a>$sel:alarmName:PutAlarm'</a>, <a>putAlarm_alarmName</a> - The name
--   for the alarm. Specify the name of an existing alarm to update, and
--   overwrite the previous configuration of the alarm.
--   
--   <a>$sel:metricName:PutAlarm'</a>, <a>putAlarm_metricName</a> - The
--   name of the metric to associate with the alarm.
--   
--   You can configure up to two alarms per metric.
--   
--   The following metrics are available for each resource type:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b>Instances</b>: <tt>BurstCapacityPercentage</tt>,
--   <tt>BurstCapacityTime</tt>, <tt>CPUUtilization</tt>,
--   <tt>NetworkIn</tt>, <tt>NetworkOut</tt>, <tt>StatusCheckFailed</tt>,
--   <tt>StatusCheckFailed_Instance</tt>, and
--   <tt>StatusCheckFailed_System</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b>Load balancers</b>: <tt>ClientTLSNegotiationErrorCount</tt>,
--   <tt>HealthyHostCount</tt>, <tt>UnhealthyHostCount</tt>,
--   <tt>HTTPCode_LB_4XX_Count</tt>, <tt>HTTPCode_LB_5XX_Count</tt>,
--   <tt>HTTPCode_Instance_2XX_Count</tt>,
--   <tt>HTTPCode_Instance_3XX_Count</tt>,
--   <tt>HTTPCode_Instance_4XX_Count</tt>,
--   <tt>HTTPCode_Instance_5XX_Count</tt>, <tt>InstanceResponseTime</tt>,
--   <tt>RejectedConnectionCount</tt>, and <tt>RequestCount</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b>Relational databases</b>: <tt>CPUUtilization</tt>,
--   <tt>DatabaseConnections</tt>, <tt>DiskQueueDepth</tt>,
--   <tt>FreeStorageSpace</tt>, <tt>NetworkReceiveThroughput</tt>, and
--   <tt>NetworkTransmitThroughput</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about these metrics, see <a>Metrics available in
--   Lightsail</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:monitoredResourceName:PutAlarm'</a>,
--   <a>putAlarm_monitoredResourceName</a> - The name of the Lightsail
--   resource that will be monitored.
--   
--   Instances, load balancers, and relational databases are the only
--   Lightsail resources that can currently be monitored by alarms.
--   
--   <a>$sel:comparisonOperator:PutAlarm'</a>,
--   <a>putAlarm_comparisonOperator</a> - The arithmetic operation to use
--   when comparing the specified statistic to the threshold. The specified
--   statistic value is used as the first operand.
--   
--   <a>$sel:threshold:PutAlarm'</a>, <a>putAlarm_threshold</a> - The value
--   against which the specified statistic is compared.
--   
--   <a>$sel:evaluationPeriods:PutAlarm'</a>,
--   <a>putAlarm_evaluationPeriods</a> - The number of most recent periods
--   over which data is compared to the specified threshold. If you are
--   setting an "M out of N" alarm, this value (<tt>evaluationPeriods</tt>)
--   is the N.
--   
--   If you are setting an alarm that requires that a number of consecutive
--   data points be breaching to trigger the alarm, this value specifies
--   the rolling period of time in which data points are evaluated.
--   
--   Each evaluation period is five minutes long. For example, specify an
--   evaluation period of 24 to evaluate a metric over a rolling period of
--   two hours.
--   
--   You can specify a minimum valuation period of 1 (5 minutes), and a
--   maximum evaluation period of 288 (24 hours).
newPutAlarm :: Text -> MetricName -> Text -> ComparisonOperator -> Double -> Int -> PutAlarm

-- | Sets how this alarm will handle missing data points.
--   
--   An alarm can treat missing data in the following ways:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>breaching</tt> - Assume the missing data is not within the
--   threshold. Missing data counts towards the number of times the metric
--   is not within the threshold.</li>
--   <li><tt>notBreaching</tt> - Assume the missing data is within the
--   threshold. Missing data does not count towards the number of times the
--   metric is not within the threshold.</li>
--   <li><tt>ignore</tt> - Ignore the missing data. Maintains the current
--   alarm state.</li>
--   <li><tt>missing</tt> - Missing data is treated as missing.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If <tt>treatMissingData</tt> is not specified, the default behavior of
--   <tt>missing</tt> is used.
putAlarm_treatMissingData :: Lens' PutAlarm (Maybe TreatMissingData)

-- | The contact protocols to use for the alarm, such as <tt>Email</tt>,
--   <tt>SMS</tt> (text messaging), or both.
--   
--   A notification is sent via the specified contact protocol if
--   notifications are enabled for the alarm, and when the alarm is
--   triggered.
--   
--   A notification is not sent if a contact protocol is not specified, if
--   the specified contact protocol is not configured in the AWS Region, or
--   if notifications are not enabled for the alarm using the
--   <tt>notificationEnabled</tt> paramater.
--   
--   Use the <tt>CreateContactMethod</tt> action to configure a contact
--   protocol in an AWS Region.
putAlarm_contactProtocols :: Lens' PutAlarm (Maybe [ContactProtocol])

-- | The number of data points that must be not within the specified
--   threshold to trigger the alarm. If you are setting an "M out of N"
--   alarm, this value (<tt>datapointsToAlarm</tt>) is the M.
putAlarm_datapointsToAlarm :: Lens' PutAlarm (Maybe Int)

-- | Indicates whether the alarm is enabled.
--   
--   Notifications are enabled by default if you don't specify this
--   parameter.
putAlarm_notificationEnabled :: Lens' PutAlarm (Maybe Bool)

-- | The alarm states that trigger a notification.
--   
--   An alarm has the following possible states:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>ALARM</tt> - The metric is outside of the defined
--   threshold.</li>
--   <li><tt>INSUFFICIENT_DATA</tt> - The alarm has just started, the
--   metric is not available, or not enough data is available for the
--   metric to determine the alarm state.</li>
--   <li><tt>OK</tt> - The metric is within the defined threshold.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   When you specify a notification trigger, the <tt>ALARM</tt> state must
--   be specified. The <tt>INSUFFICIENT_DATA</tt> and <tt>OK</tt> states
--   can be specified in addition to the <tt>ALARM</tt> state.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>If you specify <tt>OK</tt> as an alarm trigger, a notification is
--   sent when the alarm switches from an <tt>ALARM</tt> or
--   <tt>INSUFFICIENT_DATA</tt> alarm state to an <tt>OK</tt> state. This
--   can be thought of as an <i>all clear</i> alarm notification.</li>
--   <li>If you specify <tt>INSUFFICIENT_DATA</tt> as the alarm trigger, a
--   notification is sent when the alarm switches from an <tt>OK</tt> or
--   <tt>ALARM</tt> alarm state to an <tt>INSUFFICIENT_DATA</tt>
--   state.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The notification trigger defaults to <tt>ALARM</tt> if you don't
--   specify this parameter.
putAlarm_notificationTriggers :: Lens' PutAlarm (Maybe [AlarmState])

-- | The name for the alarm. Specify the name of an existing alarm to
--   update, and overwrite the previous configuration of the alarm.
putAlarm_alarmName :: Lens' PutAlarm Text

-- | The name of the metric to associate with the alarm.
--   
--   You can configure up to two alarms per metric.
--   
--   The following metrics are available for each resource type:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b>Instances</b>: <tt>BurstCapacityPercentage</tt>,
--   <tt>BurstCapacityTime</tt>, <tt>CPUUtilization</tt>,
--   <tt>NetworkIn</tt>, <tt>NetworkOut</tt>, <tt>StatusCheckFailed</tt>,

--   <tt>StatusCheckFailed_System</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b>Load balancers</b>: <tt>ClientTLSNegotiationErrorCount</tt>,
--   <tt>HealthyHostCount</tt>, <tt>UnhealthyHostCount</tt>,
--   <tt>HTTPCode_LB_4XX_Count</tt>, <tt>HTTPCode_LB_5XX_Count</tt>,
--   <tt>HTTPCode_Instance_2XX_Count</tt>,
--   <tt>HTTPCode_Instance_3XX_Count</tt>,

--   <tt>FreeStorageSpace</tt>, <tt>NetworkReceiveThroughput</tt>, and
--   <tt>NetworkTransmitThroughput</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>

--   For more information about these metrics, see <a>Metrics available in
--   Lightsail</a>.
putAlarm_metricName :: Lens' PutAlarm MetricName

-- | The name of the Lightsail resource that will be monitored.
--   
--   Instances, load balancers, and relational databases are the only
--   Lightsail resources that can currently be monitored by alarms.
putAlarm_monitoredResourceName :: Lens' PutAlarm Text

putAlarm_evaluationPeriods :: Lens' PutAlarm Int

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newPutAlarmResponse</a> smart constructor.
data PutAlarmResponse
PutAlarmResponse' :: Maybe [Operation] -> Int -> PutAlarmResponse

--   the status of the request, the timestamp of the request, and the

[$sel:httpStatus:PutAlarmResponse'] :: PutAlarmResponse -> Int

-- | Peers the Lightsail VPC with the user's default VPC.
module Amazonka.Lightsail.PeerVpc

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newPeerVpc</a> smart constructor.
data PeerVpc
PeerVpc' :: PeerVpc

-- | Create a value of <a>PeerVpc</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
newPeerVpc :: PeerVpc

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newPeerVpcResponse</a> smart constructor.
data PeerVpcResponse
PeerVpcResponse' :: Maybe Operation -> Int -> PeerVpcResponse

-- | An array of objects that describe the result of the action, such as
--   the status of the request, the timestamp of the request, and the
--   resources affected by the request.
[$sel:operation:PeerVpcResponse'] :: PeerVpcResponse -> Maybe Operation

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:PeerVpcResponse'] :: PeerVpcResponse -> Int

-- | Create a value of <a>PeerVpcResponse</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:operation:PeerVpcResponse'</a>,
--   <a>peerVpcResponse_operation</a> - An array of objects that describe
--   the result of the action, such as the status of the request, the
--   timestamp of the request, and the resources affected by the request.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:PeerVpcResponse'</a>,
--   <a>peerVpcResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http status code.
newPeerVpcResponse :: Int -> PeerVpcResponse

-- | An array of objects that describe the result of the action, such as
--   the status of the request, the timestamp of the request, and the
--   resources affected by the request.
peerVpcResponse_operation :: Lens' PeerVpcResponse (Maybe Operation)

-- | Opens ports for a specific Amazon Lightsail instance, and specifies
--   the IP addresses allowed to connect to the instance through the ports,
--   and the protocol.
--   
--   The <tt>OpenInstancePublicPorts</tt> action supports tag-based access
--   control via resource tags applied to the resource identified by
--   <tt>instanceName</tt>. For more information, see the <a>Amazon
--   Lightsail Developer Guide</a>.
module Amazonka.Lightsail.OpenInstancePublicPorts

-- | Returns the data points of the specified metric for a database in
--   Amazon Lightsail.
--   
--   Metrics report the utilization of your resources, and the error counts
--   generated by them. Monitor and collect metric data regularly to
--   maintain the reliability, availability, and performance of your
--   resources.
module Amazonka.Lightsail.GetRelationalDatabaseMetricData

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newGetRelationalDatabaseMetricData</a> smart
--   constructor.
data GetRelationalDatabaseMetricData
GetRelationalDatabaseMetricData' :: Text -> RelationalDatabaseMetricName -> Natural -> POSIX -> POSIX -> MetricUnit -> [MetricStatistic] -> GetRelationalDatabaseMetricData

-- | The name of your database from which to get metric data.
[$sel:relationalDatabaseName:GetRelationalDatabaseMetricData'] :: GetRelationalDatabaseMetricData -> Text

-- | The metric for which you want to return information.
--   
--   Valid relational database metric names are listed below, along with
--   the most useful <tt>statistics</tt> to include in your request, and
--   the published <tt>unit</tt> value. All relational database metric data
--   is available in 1-minute (60 seconds) granularity.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>CPUUtilization</tt></b> - The percentage of CPU utilization
--   currently in use on the database.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful
--   statistics are <tt>Maximum</tt> and <tt>Average</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>:
--   The published unit is <tt>Percent</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>DatabaseConnections</tt></b> - The number of database
--   connections in use.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistics are
--   <tt>Maximum</tt> and <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is
--   <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>DiskQueueDepth</tt></b> - The number of outstanding IOs
--   (read/write requests) that are waiting to access the
--   disk.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>FreeStorageSpace</tt></b> - The amount of available storage
--   space.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is <tt>Bytes</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>NetworkReceiveThroughput</tt></b> - The incoming (Receive)
--   network traffic on the database, including both customer database
--   traffic and AWS traffic used for monitoring and
--   replication.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Average</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is
--   <tt>Bytes/Second</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>NetworkTransmitThroughput</tt></b> - The outgoing
--   (Transmit) network traffic on the database, including both customer
--   database traffic and AWS traffic used for monitoring and
--   replication.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Average</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is
--   <tt>Bytes/Second</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:metricName:GetRelationalDatabaseMetricData'] :: GetRelationalDatabaseMetricData -> RelationalDatabaseMetricName

-- | The granularity, in seconds, of the returned data points.
--   
--   All relational database metric data is available in 1-minute (60
--   seconds) granularity.
[$sel:period:GetRelationalDatabaseMetricData'] :: GetRelationalDatabaseMetricData -> Natural

-- | The start of the time interval from which to get metric data.
--   
--   Constraints:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Specified in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).</li>
--   <li>Specified in the Unix time format.For example, if you wish to use
--   a start time of October 1, 2018, at 8 PM UTC, then you input
--   <tt>1538424000</tt> as the start time.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:startTime:GetRelationalDatabaseMetricData'] :: GetRelationalDatabaseMetricData -> POSIX

-- | The end of the time interval from which to get metric data.
--   
--   Constraints:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Specified in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).</li>
--   <li>Specified in the Unix time format.For example, if you wish to use
--   an end time of October 1, 2018, at 8 PM UTC, then you input
--   <tt>1538424000</tt> as the end time.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:endTime:GetRelationalDatabaseMetricData'] :: GetRelationalDatabaseMetricData -> POSIX

-- | The unit for the metric data request. Valid units depend on the metric
--   data being requested. For the valid units with each available metric,
--   see the <tt>metricName</tt> parameter.
[$sel:unit:GetRelationalDatabaseMetricData'] :: GetRelationalDatabaseMetricData -> MetricUnit

-- | The statistic for the metric.
--   
--   The following statistics are available:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>Minimum</tt> - The lowest value observed during the specified
--   period. Use this value to determine low volumes of activity for your
--   application.</li>
--   <li><tt>Maximum</tt> - The highest value observed during the specified
--   period. Use this value to determine high volumes of activity for your
--   application.</li>
--   <li><tt>Sum</tt> - All values submitted for the matching metric added
--   together. You can use this statistic to determine the total volume of
--   a metric.</li>
--   <li><tt>Average</tt> - The value of Sum / SampleCount during the
--   specified period. By comparing this statistic with the Minimum and
--   Maximum values, you can determine the full scope of a metric and how
--   close the average use is to the Minimum and Maximum values. This
--   comparison helps you to know when to increase or decrease your
--   resources.</li>
--   <li><tt>SampleCount</tt> - The count, or number, of data points used
--   for the statistical calculation.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:statistics:GetRelationalDatabaseMetricData'] :: GetRelationalDatabaseMetricData -> [MetricStatistic]

-- | Create a value of <a>GetRelationalDatabaseMetricData</a> with all
--   optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:relationalDatabaseName:GetRelationalDatabaseMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getRelationalDatabaseMetricData_relationalDatabaseName</a> - The
--   name of your database from which to get metric data.
--   
--   <a>$sel:metricName:GetRelationalDatabaseMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getRelationalDatabaseMetricData_metricName</a> - The metric for
--   which you want to return information.
--   
--   Valid relational database metric names are listed below, along with
--   the most useful <tt>statistics</tt> to include in your request, and
--   the published <tt>unit</tt> value. All relational database metric data
--   is available in 1-minute (60 seconds) granularity.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>CPUUtilization</tt></b> - The percentage of CPU utilization
--   currently in use on the database.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful
--   statistics are <tt>Maximum</tt> and <tt>Average</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>:
--   The published unit is <tt>Percent</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>DatabaseConnections</tt></b> - The number of database
--   connections in use.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistics are
--   <tt>Maximum</tt> and <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is
--   <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>DiskQueueDepth</tt></b> - The number of outstanding IOs
--   (read/write requests) that are waiting to access the
--   disk.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>FreeStorageSpace</tt></b> - The amount of available storage
--   space.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is <tt>Bytes</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>NetworkReceiveThroughput</tt></b> - The incoming (Receive)
--   network traffic on the database, including both customer database
--   traffic and AWS traffic used for monitoring and
--   replication.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Average</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is
--   <tt>Bytes/Second</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>NetworkTransmitThroughput</tt></b> - The outgoing
--   (Transmit) network traffic on the database, including both customer
--   database traffic and AWS traffic used for monitoring and
--   replication.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Average</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is
--   <tt>Bytes/Second</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:period:GetRelationalDatabaseMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getRelationalDatabaseMetricData_period</a> - The granularity, in
--   seconds, of the returned data points.
--   
--   All relational database metric data is available in 1-minute (60
--   seconds) granularity.
--   
--   <a>$sel:startTime:GetRelationalDatabaseMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getRelationalDatabaseMetricData_startTime</a> - The start of the
--   time interval from which to get metric data.
--   
--   Constraints:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Specified in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).</li>
--   <li>Specified in the Unix time format.For example, if you wish to use
--   a start time of October 1, 2018, at 8 PM UTC, then you input
--   <tt>1538424000</tt> as the start time.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:endTime:GetRelationalDatabaseMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getRelationalDatabaseMetricData_endTime</a> - The end of the time

--   </ul>

--   resources.</li>

-- | Returns the current, previous, or pending versions of the master user
--   password for a Lightsail database.
--   
--   The <tt>GetRelationalDatabaseMasterUserPassword</tt> operation
--   supports tag-based access control via resource tags applied to the
--   resource identified by relationalDatabaseName.
module Amazonka.Lightsail.GetRelationalDatabaseMasterUserPassword

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newGetRelationalDatabaseMasterUserPassword</a> smart
--   constructor.
data GetRelationalDatabaseMasterUserPassword
GetRelationalDatabaseMasterUserPassword' :: Maybe RelationalDatabasePasswordVersion -> Text -> GetRelationalDatabaseMasterUserPassword

-- | The password version to return.
--   
--   Specifying <tt>CURRENT</tt> or <tt>PREVIOUS</tt> returns the current
--   or previous passwords respectively. Specifying <tt>PENDING</tt>
--   returns the newest version of the password that will rotate to
--   <tt>CURRENT</tt>. After the <tt>PENDING</tt> password rotates to
--   <tt>CURRENT</tt>, the <tt>PENDING</tt> password is no longer
--   available.
--   
--   Default: <tt>CURRENT</tt>
[$sel:passwordVersion:GetRelationalDatabaseMasterUserPassword'] :: GetRelationalDatabaseMasterUserPassword -> Maybe RelationalDatabasePasswordVersion

-- | The name of your database for which to get the master user password.
[$sel:relationalDatabaseName:GetRelationalDatabaseMasterUserPassword'] :: GetRelationalDatabaseMasterUserPassword -> Text

--   password version to return.

-- | Returns information about all operations.
--   
--   Results are returned from oldest to newest, up to a maximum of 200.
--   Results can be paged by making each subsequent call to
--   <tt>GetOperations</tt> use the maximum (last) <tt>statusChangedAt</tt>
--   value from the previous request.
--   
--   This operation returns paginated results.
module Amazonka.Lightsail.GetOperations

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newGetOperations</a> smart constructor.
data GetOperations
GetOperations' :: Maybe Text -> GetOperations

-- | The token to advance to the next page of results from your request.
--   
--   To get a page token, perform an initial <tt>GetOperations</tt>
--   request. If your results are paginated, the response will return a
--   next page token that you can specify as the page token in a subsequent
--   request.
[$sel:pageToken:GetOperations'] :: GetOperations -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>GetOperations</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:pageToken:GetOperations'</a>, <a>getOperations_pageToken</a> -
--   The token to advance to the next page of results from your request.
--

--   request. If your results are paginated, the response will return a
--   next page token that you can specify as the page token in a subsequent
--   request.

-- | Returns information about the TLS certificates that are associated
--   with the specified Lightsail load balancer.
--   
--   TLS is just an updated, more secure version of Secure Socket Layer
--   (SSL).
--   
--   You can have a maximum of 2 certificates associated with a Lightsail
--   load balancer. One is active and the other is inactive.
module Amazonka.Lightsail.GetLoadBalancerTlsCertificates

-- | Returns information about health metrics for your Lightsail load
--   balancer.
--   
--   Metrics report the utilization of your resources, and the error counts
--   generated by them. Monitor and collect metric data regularly to
--   maintain the reliability, availability, and performance of your
--   resources.
module Amazonka.Lightsail.GetLoadBalancerMetricData

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newGetLoadBalancerMetricData</a> smart constructor.
data GetLoadBalancerMetricData
GetLoadBalancerMetricData' :: Text -> LoadBalancerMetricName -> Natural -> POSIX -> POSIX -> MetricUnit -> [MetricStatistic] -> GetLoadBalancerMetricData

-- | The name of the load balancer.
[$sel:loadBalancerName:GetLoadBalancerMetricData'] :: GetLoadBalancerMetricData -> Text

-- | The metric for which you want to return information.
--   
--   Valid load balancer metric names are listed below, along with the most
--   useful <tt>statistics</tt> to include in your request, and the
--   published <tt>unit</tt> value.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>ClientTLSNegotiationErrorCount</tt></b> - The number of TLS
--   connections initiated by the client that did not establish a session
--   with the load balancer due to a TLS error generated by the load
--   balancer. Possible causes include a mismatch of ciphers or
--   protocols.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>HealthyHostCount</tt></b> - The number of target instances
--   that are considered healthy.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful
--   statistic are <tt>Average</tt>, <tt>Minimum</tt>, and
--   <tt>Maximum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is
--   <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>HTTPCode_Instance_2XX_Count</tt></b> - The number of HTTP
--   2XX response codes generated by the target instances. This does not
--   include any response codes generated by the load
--   balancer.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>. Note that <tt>Minimum</tt>, <tt>Maximum</tt>, and
--   <tt>Average</tt> all return <tt>1</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>HTTPCode_Instance_3XX_Count</tt></b> - The number of HTTP
--   3XX response codes generated by the target instances. This does not
--   include any response codes generated by the load
--   balancer.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>. Note that <tt>Minimum</tt>, <tt>Maximum</tt>, and
--   <tt>Average</tt> all return <tt>1</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>HTTPCode_Instance_4XX_Count</tt></b> - The number of HTTP
--   4XX response codes generated by the target instances. This does not
--   include any response codes generated by the load
--   balancer.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>. Note that <tt>Minimum</tt>, <tt>Maximum</tt>, and
--   <tt>Average</tt> all return <tt>1</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>HTTPCode_Instance_5XX_Count</tt></b> - The number of HTTP
--   5XX response codes generated by the target instances. This does not
--   include any response codes generated by the load
--   balancer.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>. Note that <tt>Minimum</tt>, <tt>Maximum</tt>, and
--   <tt>Average</tt> all return <tt>1</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>HTTPCode_LB_4XX_Count</tt></b> - The number of HTTP 4XX
--   client error codes that originated from the load balancer. Client
--   errors are generated when requests are malformed or incomplete. These
--   requests were not received by the target instance. This count does not
--   include response codes generated by the target
--   instances.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>. Note that <tt>Minimum</tt>, <tt>Maximum</tt>, and
--   <tt>Average</tt> all return <tt>1</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>HTTPCode_LB_5XX_Count</tt></b> - The number of HTTP 5XX
--   server error codes that originated from the load balancer. This does
--   not include any response codes generated by the target instance. This
--   metric is reported if there are no healthy instances attached to the
--   load balancer, or if the request rate exceeds the capacity of the
--   instances (spillover) or the load balancer.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The
--   most useful statistic is <tt>Sum</tt>. Note that <tt>Minimum</tt>,
--   <tt>Maximum</tt>, and <tt>Average</tt> all return
--   <tt>1</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>InstanceResponseTime</tt></b> - The time elapsed, in
--   seconds, after the request leaves the load balancer until a response
--   from the target instance is received.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most
--   useful statistic is <tt>Average</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit
--   is <tt>Seconds</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>RejectedConnectionCount</tt></b> - The number of
--   connections that were rejected because the load balancer had reached
--   its maximum number of connections.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful
--   statistic is <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is
--   <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>RequestCount</tt></b> - The number of requests processed
--   over IPv4. This count includes only the requests with a response
--   generated by a target instance of the load
--   balancer.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>. Note that <tt>Minimum</tt>, <tt>Maximum</tt>, and
--   <tt>Average</tt> all return <tt>1</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>UnhealthyHostCount</tt></b> - The number of target
--   instances that are considered unhealthy.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most
--   useful statistic are <tt>Average</tt>, <tt>Minimum</tt>, and
--   <tt>Maximum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is
--   <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:metricName:GetLoadBalancerMetricData'] :: GetLoadBalancerMetricData -> LoadBalancerMetricName

-- | The granularity, in seconds, of the returned data points.
[$sel:period:GetLoadBalancerMetricData'] :: GetLoadBalancerMetricData -> Natural

-- | The start time of the period.
[$sel:startTime:GetLoadBalancerMetricData'] :: GetLoadBalancerMetricData -> POSIX

-- | The end time of the period.
[$sel:endTime:GetLoadBalancerMetricData'] :: GetLoadBalancerMetricData -> POSIX

-- | The unit for the metric data request. Valid units depend on the metric
--   data being requested. For the valid units with each available metric,
--   see the <tt>metricName</tt> parameter.
[$sel:unit:GetLoadBalancerMetricData'] :: GetLoadBalancerMetricData -> MetricUnit

-- | The statistic for the metric.
--   
--   The following statistics are available:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>Minimum</tt> - The lowest value observed during the specified
--   period. Use this value to determine low volumes of activity for your
--   application.</li>
--   <li><tt>Maximum</tt> - The highest value observed during the specified
--   period. Use this value to determine high volumes of activity for your
--   application.</li>
--   <li><tt>Sum</tt> - All values submitted for the matching metric added
--   together. You can use this statistic to determine the total volume of
--   a metric.</li>
--   <li><tt>Average</tt> - The value of Sum / SampleCount during the
--   specified period. By comparing this statistic with the Minimum and
--   Maximum values, you can determine the full scope of a metric and how
--   close the average use is to the Minimum and Maximum values. This
--   comparison helps you to know when to increase or decrease your
--   resources.</li>
--   <li><tt>SampleCount</tt> - The count, or number, of data points used
--   for the statistical calculation.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:statistics:GetLoadBalancerMetricData'] :: GetLoadBalancerMetricData -> [MetricStatistic]

-- | Create a value of <a>GetLoadBalancerMetricData</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:loadBalancerName:GetLoadBalancerMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getLoadBalancerMetricData_loadBalancerName</a> - The name of the
--   load balancer.
--   
--   <a>$sel:metricName:GetLoadBalancerMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getLoadBalancerMetricData_metricName</a> - The metric for which you
--   want to return information.
--   
--   Valid load balancer metric names are listed below, along with the most
--   useful <tt>statistics</tt> to include in your request, and the
--   published <tt>unit</tt> value.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>ClientTLSNegotiationErrorCount</tt></b> - The number of TLS
--   connections initiated by the client that did not establish a session
--   with the load balancer due to a TLS error generated by the load
--   balancer. Possible causes include a mismatch of ciphers or
--   protocols.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>HealthyHostCount</tt></b> - The number of target instances
--   that are considered healthy.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful
--   statistic are <tt>Average</tt>, <tt>Minimum</tt>, and
--   <tt>Maximum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is
--   <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>HTTPCode_Instance_2XX_Count</tt></b> - The number of HTTP
--   2XX response codes generated by the target instances. This does not
--   include any response codes generated by the load
--   balancer.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>. Note that <tt>Minimum</tt>, <tt>Maximum</tt>, and
--   <tt>Average</tt> all return <tt>1</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>HTTPCode_Instance_3XX_Count</tt></b> - The number of HTTP
--   3XX response codes generated by the target instances. This does not
--   include any response codes generated by the load
--   balancer.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>. Note that <tt>Minimum</tt>, <tt>Maximum</tt>, and
--   <tt>Average</tt> all return <tt>1</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>HTTPCode_Instance_4XX_Count</tt></b> - The number of HTTP
--   4XX response codes generated by the target instances. This does not
--   include any response codes generated by the load
--   balancer.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>. Note that <tt>Minimum</tt>, <tt>Maximum</tt>, and
--   <tt>Average</tt> all return <tt>1</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>HTTPCode_Instance_5XX_Count</tt></b> - The number of HTTP
--   5XX response codes generated by the target instances. This does not
--   include any response codes generated by the load
--   balancer.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>. Note that <tt>Minimum</tt>, <tt>Maximum</tt>, and
--   <tt>Average</tt> all return <tt>1</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>HTTPCode_LB_4XX_Count</tt></b> - The number of HTTP 4XX
--   client error codes that originated from the load balancer. Client
--   errors are generated when requests are malformed or incomplete. These
--   requests were not received by the target instance. This count does not
--   include response codes generated by the target
--   instances.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>. Note that <tt>Minimum</tt>, <tt>Maximum</tt>, and
--   <tt>Average</tt> all return <tt>1</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>HTTPCode_LB_5XX_Count</tt></b> - The number of HTTP 5XX
--   server error codes that originated from the load balancer. This does
--   not include any response codes generated by the target instance. This
--   metric is reported if there are no healthy instances attached to the
--   load balancer, or if the request rate exceeds the capacity of the
--   instances (spillover) or the load balancer.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The
--   most useful statistic is <tt>Sum</tt>. Note that <tt>Minimum</tt>,
--   <tt>Maximum</tt>, and <tt>Average</tt> all return
--   <tt>1</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>InstanceResponseTime</tt></b> - The time elapsed, in
--   seconds, after the request leaves the load balancer until a response
--   from the target instance is received.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most
--   useful statistic is <tt>Average</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit
--   is <tt>Seconds</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>RejectedConnectionCount</tt></b> - The number of
--   connections that were rejected because the load balancer had reached
--   its maximum number of connections.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful
--   statistic is <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is
--   <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>RequestCount</tt></b> - The number of requests processed
--   over IPv4. This count includes only the requests with a response
--   generated by a target instance of the load
--   balancer.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>. Note that <tt>Minimum</tt>, <tt>Maximum</tt>, and
--   <tt>Average</tt> all return <tt>1</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>UnhealthyHostCount</tt></b> - The number of target
--   instances that are considered unhealthy.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most
--   useful statistic are <tt>Average</tt>, <tt>Minimum</tt>, and
--   <tt>Maximum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is
--   <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:period:GetLoadBalancerMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getLoadBalancerMetricData_period</a> - The granularity, in seconds,
--   of the returned data points.
--   
--   <a>$sel:startTime:GetLoadBalancerMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getLoadBalancerMetricData_startTime</a> - The start time of the
--   period.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endTime:GetLoadBalancerMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getLoadBalancerMetricData_endTime</a> - The end time of the period.
--   
--   <a>$sel:unit:GetLoadBalancerMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getLoadBalancerMetricData_unit</a> - The unit for the metric data
--   request. Valid units depend on the metric data being requested. For
--   the valid units with each available metric, see the
--   <tt>metricName</tt> parameter.
--   
--   <a>$sel:statistics:GetLoadBalancerMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getLoadBalancerMetricData_statistics</a> - The statistic for the
--   metric.
--   
--   The following statistics are available:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>Minimum</tt> - The lowest value observed during the specified
--   period. Use this value to determine low volumes of activity for your
--   application.</li>
--   <li><tt>Maximum</tt> - The highest value observed during the specified
--   period. Use this value to determine high volumes of activity for your
--   application.</li>
--   <li><tt>Sum</tt> - All values submitted for the matching metric added
--   together. You can use this statistic to determine the total volume of
--   a metric.</li>
--   <li><tt>Average</tt> - The value of Sum / SampleCount during the
--   specified period. By comparing this statistic with the Minimum and
--   Maximum values, you can determine the full scope of a metric and how
--   close the average use is to the Minimum and Maximum values. This
--   comparison helps you to know when to increase or decrease your
--   resources.</li>
--   <li><tt>SampleCount</tt> - The count, or number, of data points used
--   for the statistical calculation.</li>
--   </ul>
newGetLoadBalancerMetricData :: Text -> LoadBalancerMetricName -> Natural -> UTCTime -> UTCTime -> MetricUnit -> GetLoadBalancerMetricData

-- | Returns information about all key pairs in the user's account.
--   
--   This operation returns paginated results.
module Amazonka.Lightsail.GetKeyPairs

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newGetKeyPairs</a> smart constructor.
data GetKeyPairs
GetKeyPairs' :: Maybe Text -> GetKeyPairs

-- | The token to advance to the next page of results from your request.
--   
--   To get a page token, perform an initial <tt>GetKeyPairs</tt> request.
--   If your results are paginated, the response will return a next page
--   token that you can specify as the page token in a subsequent request.
[$sel:pageToken:GetKeyPairs'] :: GetKeyPairs -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>GetKeyPairs</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:pageToken:GetKeyPairs'</a>, <a>getKeyPairs_pageToken</a> - The
--   token to advance to the next page of results from your request.
--   
--   To get a page token, perform an initial <tt>GetKeyPairs</tt> request.
--   If your results are paginated, the response will return a next page
--   token that you can specify as the page token in a subsequent request.
newGetKeyPairs :: GetKeyPairs

-- | The token to advance to the next page of results from your request.
--   
--   To get a page token, perform an initial <tt>GetKeyPairs</tt> request.
--   If your results are paginated, the response will return a next page

instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Amazonka.Lightsail.GetInstanceSnapshot.GetInstanceSnapshot
instance Amazonka.Data.Path.ToPath Amazonka.Lightsail.GetInstanceSnapshot.GetInstanceSnapshot
instance Amazonka.Data.Query.ToQuery Amazonka.Lightsail.GetInstanceSnapshot.GetInstanceSnapshot


-- | Returns the firewall port states for a specific Amazon Lightsail
--   instance, the IP addresses allowed to connect to the instance through
--   the ports, and the protocol.
module Amazonka.Lightsail.GetInstancePortStates

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newGetInstancePortStates</a> smart constructor.
data GetInstancePortStates
GetInstancePortStates' :: Text -> GetInstancePortStates

-- | The name of the instance for which to return firewall port states.
[$sel:instanceName:GetInstancePortStates'] :: GetInstancePortStates -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>GetInstancePortStates</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceName:GetInstancePortStates'</a>,
--   <a>getInstancePortStates_instanceName</a> - The name of the instance
--   for which to return firewall port states.
newGetInstancePortStates :: Text -> GetInstancePortStates

-- | The name of the instance for which to return firewall port states.
getInstancePortStates_instanceName :: Lens' GetInstancePortStates Text

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newGetInstancePortStatesResponse</a> smart constructor.
data GetInstancePortStatesResponse

-- | An array of objects that describe the firewall port states for the
--   specified instance.
[$sel:portStates:GetInstancePortStatesResponse'] :: GetInstancePortStatesResponse -> Maybe [InstancePortState]

[$sel:httpStatus:GetInstancePortStatesResponse'] :: GetInstancePortStatesResponse -> Int

-- | Returns the data points for the specified Amazon Lightsail instance
--   metric, given an instance name.
--   
--   Metrics report the utilization of your resources, and the error counts
--   generated by them. Monitor and collect metric data regularly to
--   maintain the reliability, availability, and performance of your
--   resources.
module Amazonka.Lightsail.GetInstanceMetricData

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newGetInstanceMetricData</a> smart constructor.
data GetInstanceMetricData
GetInstanceMetricData' :: Text -> InstanceMetricName -> Natural -> POSIX -> POSIX -> MetricUnit -> [MetricStatistic] -> GetInstanceMetricData

-- | The name of the instance for which you want to get metrics data.
[$sel:instanceName:GetInstanceMetricData'] :: GetInstanceMetricData -> Text

-- | The metric for which you want to return information.
--   
--   Valid instance metric names are listed below, along with the most
--   useful <tt>statistics</tt> to include in your request, and the
--   published <tt>unit</tt> value.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>BurstCapacityPercentage</tt></b> - The percentage of CPU
--   performance available for your instance to burst above its baseline.
--   Your instance continuously accrues and consumes burst capacity. Burst
--   capacity stops accruing when your instance's
--   <tt>BurstCapacityPercentage</tt> reaches 100%. For more information,
--   see <a>Viewing instance burst capacity in Amazon
--   Lightsail</a>.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistics are
--   <tt>Maximum</tt> and <tt>Average</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>Percent</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>BurstCapacityTime</tt></b> - The available amount of time
--   for your instance to burst at 100% CPU utilization. Your instance
--   continuously accrues and consumes burst capacity. Burst capacity time
--   stops accruing when your instance's <tt>BurstCapacityPercentage</tt>
--   metric reaches 100%.Burst capacity time is consumed at the full rate
--   only when your instance operates at 100% CPU utilization. For example,
--   if your instance operates at 50% CPU utilization in the burstable zone
--   for a 5-minute period, then it consumes CPU burst capacity minutes at
--   a 50% rate in that period. Your instance consumed 2 minutes and 30
--   seconds of CPU burst capacity minutes in the 5-minute period. For more
--   information, see <a>Viewing instance burst capacity in Amazon
--   Lightsail</a>.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistics are
--   <tt>Maximum</tt> and <tt>Average</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>Seconds</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>CPUUtilization</tt></b> - The percentage of allocated
--   compute units that are currently in use on the instance. This metric
--   identifies the processing power to run the applications on the
--   instance. Tools in your operating system can show a lower percentage
--   than Lightsail when the instance is not allocated a full processor
--   core.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistics are
--   <tt>Maximum</tt> and <tt>Average</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>Percent</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>NetworkIn</tt></b> - The number of bytes received on all
--   network interfaces by the instance. This metric identifies the volume
--   of incoming network traffic to the instance. The number reported is
--   the number of bytes received during the period. Because this metric is
--   reported in 5-minute intervals, divide the reported number by 300 to
--   find Bytes/second.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is <tt>Bytes</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>NetworkOut</tt></b> - The number of bytes sent out on all
--   network interfaces by the instance. This metric identifies the volume
--   of outgoing network traffic from the instance. The number reported is
--   the number of bytes sent during the period. Because this metric is
--   reported in 5-minute intervals, divide the reported number by 300 to
--   find Bytes/second.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is <tt>Bytes</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>StatusCheckFailed</tt></b> - Reports whether the instance
--   passed or failed both the instance status check and the system status
--   check. This metric can be either 0 (passed) or 1 (failed). This metric
--   data is available in 1-minute (60 seconds)
--   granularity.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>StatusCheckFailed_Instance</tt></b> - Reports whether the
--   instance passed or failed the instance status check. This metric can
--   be either 0 (passed) or 1 (failed). This metric data is available in
--   1-minute (60 seconds) granularity.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful
--   statistic is <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is
--   <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>StatusCheckFailed_System</tt></b> - Reports whether the
--   instance passed or failed the system status check. This metric can be
--   either 0 (passed) or 1 (failed). This metric data is available in
--   1-minute (60 seconds) granularity.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful
--   statistic is <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is
--   <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:metricName:GetInstanceMetricData'] :: GetInstanceMetricData -> InstanceMetricName

-- | The granularity, in seconds, of the returned data points.
--   
--   The <tt>StatusCheckFailed</tt>, <tt>StatusCheckFailed_Instance</tt>,
--   and <tt>StatusCheckFailed_System</tt> instance metric data is
--   available in 1-minute (60 seconds) granularity. All other instance
--   metric data is available in 5-minute (300 seconds) granularity.
[$sel:period:GetInstanceMetricData'] :: GetInstanceMetricData -> Natural

-- | The start time of the time period.
[$sel:startTime:GetInstanceMetricData'] :: GetInstanceMetricData -> POSIX

-- | The end time of the time period.
[$sel:endTime:GetInstanceMetricData'] :: GetInstanceMetricData -> POSIX

-- | The unit for the metric data request. Valid units depend on the metric
--   data being requested. For the valid units to specify with each
--   available metric, see the <tt>metricName</tt> parameter.
[$sel:unit:GetInstanceMetricData'] :: GetInstanceMetricData -> MetricUnit

-- | The statistic for the metric.
--   
--   The following statistics are available:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>Minimum</tt> - The lowest value observed during the specified
--   period. Use this value to determine low volumes of activity for your
--   application.</li>
--   <li><tt>Maximum</tt> - The highest value observed during the specified
--   period. Use this value to determine high volumes of activity for your
--   application.</li>
--   <li><tt>Sum</tt> - All values submitted for the matching metric added
--   together. You can use this statistic to determine the total volume of
--   a metric.</li>
--   <li><tt>Average</tt> - The value of Sum / SampleCount during the
--   specified period. By comparing this statistic with the Minimum and
--   Maximum values, you can determine the full scope of a metric and how
--   close the average use is to the Minimum and Maximum values. This
--   comparison helps you to know when to increase or decrease your
--   resources.</li>
--   <li><tt>SampleCount</tt> - The count, or number, of data points used
--   for the statistical calculation.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:statistics:GetInstanceMetricData'] :: GetInstanceMetricData -> [MetricStatistic]

-- | Create a value of <a>GetInstanceMetricData</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:

--   1-minute (60 seconds) granularity.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful
--   statistic is <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is
--   <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:period:GetInstanceMetricData'</a>,

--   period. Use this value to determine low volumes of activity for your
--   application.</li>

newGetInstanceMetricData :: Text -> InstanceMetricName -> Natural -> UTCTime -> UTCTime -> MetricUnit -> GetInstanceMetricData

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newGetInstanceMetricDataResponse</a> smart constructor.
data GetInstanceMetricDataResponse
GetInstanceMetricDataResponse' :: Maybe InstanceMetricName -> Maybe [MetricDatapoint] -> Int -> GetInstanceMetricDataResponse

-- | The name of the metric returned.
[$sel:metricName:GetInstanceMetricDataResponse'] :: GetInstanceMetricDataResponse -> Maybe InstanceMetricName

-- | An array of objects that describe the metric data returned.
[$sel:metricData:GetInstanceMetricDataResponse'] :: GetInstanceMetricDataResponse -> Maybe [MetricDatapoint]

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:GetInstanceMetricDataResponse'] :: GetInstanceMetricDataResponse -> Int

-- | Create a value of <a>GetInstanceMetricDataResponse</a> with all
--   optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:metricName:GetInstanceMetricData'</a>,

-- | Returns information about one or more of your Amazon Lightsail content
--   delivery network (CDN) distributions.

data GetDistributions

--

--   fields.

--   AWS Region where the request is made.

--   next page token that you can specify as the page token in a subsequent
--   request.

-- | Returns the data points of a specific metric for an Amazon Lightsail
--   content delivery network (CDN) distribution.
--   
--   Metrics report the utilization of your resources, and the error counts
--   generated by them. Monitor and collect metric data regularly to
--   maintain the reliability, availability, and performance of your
--   resources.
module Amazonka.Lightsail.GetDistributionMetricData

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newGetDistributionMetricData</a> smart constructor.
data GetDistributionMetricData
GetDistributionMetricData' :: Text -> DistributionMetricName -> POSIX -> POSIX -> Natural -> MetricUnit -> [MetricStatistic] -> GetDistributionMetricData

-- | The name of the distribution for which to get metric data.
--   
--   Use the <tt>GetDistributions</tt> action to get a list of distribution
--   names that you can specify.
[$sel:distributionName:GetDistributionMetricData'] :: GetDistributionMetricData -> Text

-- | The metric for which you want to return information.
--   
--   Valid distribution metric names are listed below, along with the most
--   useful <tt>statistics</tt> to include in your request, and the
--   published <tt>unit</tt> value.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>Requests</tt></b> - The total number of viewer requests
--   received by your Lightsail distribution, for all HTTP methods, and for
--   both HTTP and HTTPS requests.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful
--   statistic is <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is
--   <tt>None</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>BytesDownloaded</tt></b> - The number of bytes downloaded
--   by viewers for GET, HEAD, and OPTIONS requests.<tt>Statistics</tt>:
--   The most useful statistic is <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>None</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>BytesUploaded </tt></b> - The number of bytes uploaded to
--   your origin by your Lightsail distribution, using POST and PUT
--   requests.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is <tt>None</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>TotalErrorRate</tt></b> - The percentage of all viewer
--   requests for which the response's HTTP status code was 4xx or
--   5xx.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Average</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is
--   <tt>Percent</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>4xxErrorRate</tt></b> - The percentage of all viewer
--   requests for which the response's HTTP status cod was 4xx. In these
--   cases, the client or client viewer may have made an error. For
--   example, a status code of 404 (Not Found) means that the client
--   requested an object that could not be found.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The
--   most useful statistic is <tt>Average</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>Percent</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>5xxErrorRate</tt></b> - The percentage of all viewer
--   requests for which the response's HTTP status code was 5xx. In these
--   cases, the origin server did not satisfy the requests. For example, a
--   status code of 503 (Service Unavailable) means that the origin server
--   is currently unavailable.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful
--   statistic is <tt>Average</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is
--   <tt>Percent</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:metricName:GetDistributionMetricData'] :: GetDistributionMetricData -> DistributionMetricName

-- | The start of the time interval for which to get metric data.
--   
--   Constraints:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Specified in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).</li>
--   <li>Specified in the Unix time format.For example, if you wish to use
--   a start time of October 1, 2018, at 8 PM UTC, specify
--   <tt>1538424000</tt> as the start time.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   You can convert a human-friendly time to Unix time format using a
--   converter like <a>Epoch converter</a>.
[$sel:startTime:GetDistributionMetricData'] :: GetDistributionMetricData -> POSIX

-- | The end of the time interval for which to get metric data.
--   
--   Constraints:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Specified in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).</li>
--   <li>Specified in the Unix time format.For example, if you wish to use
--   an end time of October 1, 2018, at 9 PM UTC, specify
--   <tt>1538427600</tt> as the end time.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   You can convert a human-friendly time to Unix time format using a
--   converter like <a>Epoch converter</a>.
[$sel:endTime:GetDistributionMetricData'] :: GetDistributionMetricData -> POSIX

-- | The granularity, in seconds, for the metric data points that will be
--   returned.
[$sel:period:GetDistributionMetricData'] :: GetDistributionMetricData -> Natural

-- | The unit for the metric data request.
--   
--   Valid units depend on the metric data being requested. For the valid
--   units with each available metric, see the <tt>metricName</tt>
--   parameter.
[$sel:unit:GetDistributionMetricData'] :: GetDistributionMetricData -> MetricUnit

-- | The statistic for the metric.
--   
--   The following statistics are available:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>Minimum</tt> - The lowest value observed during the specified
--   period. Use this value to determine low volumes of activity for your
--   application.</li>
--   <li><tt>Maximum</tt> - The highest value observed during the specified
--   period. Use this value to determine high volumes of activity for your
--   application.</li>
--   <li><tt>Sum</tt> - All values submitted for the matching metric added
--   together. You can use this statistic to determine the total volume of
--   a metric.</li>
--   <li><tt>Average</tt> - The value of Sum / SampleCount during the
--   specified period. By comparing this statistic with the Minimum and
--   Maximum values, you can determine the full scope of a metric and how
--   close the average use is to the Minimum and Maximum values. This
--   comparison helps you to know when to increase or decrease your
--   resources.</li>
--   <li><tt>SampleCount</tt> - The count, or number, of data points used
--   for the statistical calculation.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:statistics:GetDistributionMetricData'] :: GetDistributionMetricData -> [MetricStatistic]

-- | Create a value of <a>GetDistributionMetricData</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional

-- | Returns the timestamp and status of the last cache reset of a specific
--   Amazon Lightsail content delivery network (CDN) distribution.
module Amazonka.Lightsail.GetDistributionLatestCacheReset

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newGetDistributionLatestCacheReset</a> smart
--   constructor.

-- | Returns the data points of a specific metric of your Amazon Lightsail
--   container service.
--   
--   Metrics report the utilization of your resources. Monitor and collect
--   metric data regularly to maintain the reliability, availability, and
--   performance of your resources.
module Amazonka.Lightsail.GetContainerServiceMetricData

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newGetContainerServiceMetricData</a> smart constructor.
data GetContainerServiceMetricData
GetContainerServiceMetricData' :: Text -> ContainerServiceMetricName -> POSIX -> POSIX -> Natural -> [MetricStatistic] -> GetContainerServiceMetricData

-- | The name of the container service for which to get metric data.
[$sel:serviceName:GetContainerServiceMetricData'] :: GetContainerServiceMetricData -> Text

-- | The metric for which you want to return information.
--   
--   Valid container service metric names are listed below, along with the
--   most useful statistics to include in your request, and the published
--   unit value.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>CPUUtilization</tt> - The average percentage of compute units
--   that are currently in use across all nodes of the container service.
--   This metric identifies the processing power required to run containers
--   on each node of the container service.Statistics: The most useful
--   statistics are <tt>Maximum</tt> and <tt>Average</tt>.Unit: The
--   published unit is <tt>Percent</tt>.</li>
--   <li><tt>MemoryUtilization</tt> - The average percentage of available
--   memory that is currently in use across all nodes of the container
--   service. This metric identifies the memory required to run containers
--   on each node of the container service.Statistics: The most useful
--   statistics are <tt>Maximum</tt> and <tt>Average</tt>.Unit: The
--   published unit is <tt>Percent</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:metricName:GetContainerServiceMetricData'] :: GetContainerServiceMetricData -> ContainerServiceMetricName

-- | The start time of the time period.
[$sel:startTime:GetContainerServiceMetricData'] :: GetContainerServiceMetricData -> POSIX

-- | The end time of the time period.
[$sel:endTime:GetContainerServiceMetricData'] :: GetContainerServiceMetricData -> POSIX

-- | The granularity, in seconds, of the returned data points.
--   
--   All container service metric data is available in 5-minute (300
--   seconds) granularity.
[$sel:period:GetContainerServiceMetricData'] :: GetContainerServiceMetricData -> Natural

-- | The statistic for the metric.
--   
--   The following statistics are available:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>Minimum</tt> - The lowest value observed during the specified
--   period. Use this value to determine low volumes of activity for your
--   application.</li>
--   <li><tt>Maximum</tt> - The highest value observed during the specified
--   period. Use this value to determine high volumes of activity for your
--   application.</li>
--   <li><tt>Sum</tt> - All values submitted for the matching metric added
--   together. You can use this statistic to determine the total volume of
--   a metric.</li>
--   <li><tt>Average</tt> - The value of <tt>Sum</tt> /
--   <tt>SampleCount</tt> during the specified period. By comparing this
--   statistic with the <tt>Minimum</tt> and <tt>Maximum</tt> values, you
--   can determine the full scope of a metric and how close the average use
--   is to the <tt>Minimum</tt> and <tt>Maximum</tt> values. This
--   comparison helps you to know when to increase or decrease your
--   resources.</li>
--   <li><tt>SampleCount</tt> - The count, or number, of data points used
--   for the statistical calculation.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:statistics:GetContainerServiceMetricData'] :: GetContainerServiceMetricData -> [MetricStatistic]

-- | Create a value of <a>GetContainerServiceMetricData</a> with all
--   optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:serviceName:GetContainerServiceMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getContainerServiceMetricData_serviceName</a> - The name of the
--   container service for which to get metric data.
--   
--   <a>$sel:metricName:GetContainerServiceMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getContainerServiceMetricData_metricName</a> - The metric for which
--   you want to return information.
--   
--   Valid container service metric names are listed below, along with the
--   most useful statistics to include in your request, and the published

--   <li><tt>CPUUtilization</tt> - The average percentage of compute units

--   statistics are <tt>Maximum</tt> and <tt>Average</tt>.Unit: The
--   published unit is <tt>Percent</tt>.</li>
--   <li><tt>MemoryUtilization</tt> - The average percentage of available

--   </ul>

--   time period.

--   time period.

--   resources.</li>

-- | Returns the deployments for your Amazon Lightsail container service
--   
--   A deployment specifies the settings, such as the ports and launch
--   command, of containers that are deployed to your container service.
--   
--   The deployments are ordered by version in ascending order. The newest
--   version is listed at the top of the response.
--   
--   A set number of deployments are kept before the oldest one is replaced
--   with the newest one. For more information, see <a>Amazon Lightsail
--   endpoints and quotas</a> in the <i>AWS General Reference</i>.
module Amazonka.Lightsail.GetContainerServiceDeployments

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newGetContainerServiceDeployments</a> smart
--   constructor.

--   container service for which to return deployments.

instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Amazonka.Lightsail.GetContainerServiceDeployments.GetContainerServiceDeployments
