-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newGetDistributionMetricData</a> smart constructor.
data GetDistributionMetricData
GetDistributionMetricData' :: Text -> DistributionMetricName -> POSIX -> POSIX -> Natural -> MetricUnit -> [MetricStatistic] -> GetDistributionMetricData

-- | Create a value of <a>GetDistributionMetricData</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:distributionName:GetDistributionMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getDistributionMetricData_distributionName</a> - The name of the
--   distribution for which to get metric data.
--   
--   Use the <tt>GetDistributions</tt> action to get a list of distribution
--   names that you can specify.
--   
--   <a>$sel:metricName:GetDistributionMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getDistributionMetricData_metricName</a> - The metric for which you
--   want to return information.
--   
--   Valid distribution metric names are listed below, along with the most
--   useful <tt>statistics</tt> to include in your request, and the
--   published <tt>unit</tt> value.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>Requests</tt></b> - The total number of viewer requests
--   received by your Lightsail distribution, for all HTTP methods, and for
--   both HTTP and HTTPS requests.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful
--   statistic is <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is
--   <tt>None</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>BytesDownloaded</tt></b> - The number of bytes downloaded
--   by viewers for GET, HEAD, and OPTIONS requests.<tt>Statistics</tt>:
--   The most useful statistic is <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>None</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>BytesUploaded </tt></b> - The number of bytes uploaded to
--   your origin by your Lightsail distribution, using POST and PUT
--   requests.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is <tt>None</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>TotalErrorRate</tt></b> - The percentage of all viewer
--   requests for which the response's HTTP status code was 4xx or
--   5xx.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Average</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is
--   <tt>Percent</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>4xxErrorRate</tt></b> - The percentage of all viewer
--   requests for which the response's HTTP status cod was 4xx. In these
--   cases, the client or client viewer may have made an error. For
--   example, a status code of 404 (Not Found) means that the client
--   requested an object that could not be found.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The
--   most useful statistic is <tt>Average</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>Percent</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>5xxErrorRate</tt></b> - The percentage of all viewer
--   requests for which the response's HTTP status code was 5xx. In these
--   cases, the origin server did not satisfy the requests. For example, a
--   status code of 503 (Service Unavailable) means that the origin server
--   is currently unavailable.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful
--   statistic is <tt>Average</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is
--   <tt>Percent</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:startTime:GetDistributionMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getDistributionMetricData_startTime</a> - The start of the time
--   interval for which to get metric data.
--   
--   Constraints:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Specified in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).</li>
--   <li>Specified in the Unix time format.For example, if you wish to use
--   a start time of October 1, 2018, at 8 PM UTC, specify
--   <tt>1538424000</tt> as the start time.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   You can convert a human-friendly time to Unix time format using a
--   converter like <a>Epoch converter</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endTime:GetDistributionMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getDistributionMetricData_endTime</a> - The end of the time
--   interval for which to get metric data.
--   
--   Constraints:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Specified in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).</li>
--   <li>Specified in the Unix time format.For example, if you wish to use
--   an end time of October 1, 2018, at 9 PM UTC, specify
--   <tt>1538427600</tt> as the end time.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   You can convert a human-friendly time to Unix time format using a
--   converter like <a>Epoch converter</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:period:GetDistributionMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getDistributionMetricData_period</a> - The granularity, in seconds,
--   for the metric data points that will be returned.
--   
--   <a>$sel:unit:GetDistributionMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getDistributionMetricData_unit</a> - The unit for the metric data
--   request.
--   
--   Valid units depend on the metric data being requested. For the valid
--   units with each available metric, see the <tt>metricName</tt>
--   parameter.
--   
--   <a>$sel:statistics:GetDistributionMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getDistributionMetricData_statistics</a> - The statistic for the
--   metric.
--   
--   The following statistics are available:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>Minimum</tt> - The lowest value observed during the specified
--   period. Use this value to determine low volumes of activity for your
--   application.</li>
--   <li><tt>Maximum</tt> - The highest value observed during the specified
--   period. Use this value to determine high volumes of activity for your
--   application.</li>
--   <li><tt>Sum</tt> - All values submitted for the matching metric added
--   together. You can use this statistic to determine the total volume of
--   a metric.</li>
--   <li><tt>Average</tt> - The value of Sum / SampleCount during the
--   specified period. By comparing this statistic with the Minimum and
--   Maximum values, you can determine the full scope of a metric and how
--   close the average use is to the Minimum and Maximum values. This
--   comparison helps you to know when to increase or decrease your
--   resources.</li>
--   <li><tt>SampleCount</tt> - The count, or number, of data points used
--   for the statistical calculation.</li>
--   </ul>
newGetDistributionMetricData :: Text -> DistributionMetricName -> UTCTime -> UTCTime -> Natural -> MetricUnit -> GetDistributionMetricData

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateDiskFromSnapshot</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.

--   Boolean value to indicate whether to use the latest available
--   automatic snapshot.
--   
--   Constraints:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>This parameter cannot be defined together with the <tt>restore
--   date</tt> parameter. The <tt>use latest restorable auto snapshot</tt>
--   and <tt>restore date</tt> parameters are mutually exclusive.</li>
--   <li>Define this parameter only when creating a new disk from an
--   automatic snapshot. For more information, see the <a>Amazon Lightsail
--   Developer Guide</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:sourceDiskName:CreateDiskFromSnapshot'</a>,

--   automatic snapshot. For more information, see the <a>Amazon Lightsail
--   Developer Guide</a>.</li>
--   </ul>

--   <a>$sel:addOns:CreateDiskFromSnapshot'</a>,
--   <a>createDiskFromSnapshot_addOns</a> - An array of objects that
--   represent the add-ons to enable for the new disk.

--   snapshot (e.g., <tt>my-snapshot</tt>) from which to create the new
--   storage disk.

--   name</tt> parameter. The <tt>disk snapshot name</tt> and <tt>source

--   operation to identify the dates of the available automatic snapshots.
--

--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Must be specified in <tt>YYYY-MM-DD</tt> format.</li>
--   <li>This parameter cannot be defined together with the <tt>use latest
--   restorable auto snapshot</tt> parameter. The <tt>restore date</tt> and
--   <tt>use latest restorable auto snapshot</tt> parameters are mutually
--   exclusive.</li>
--   <li>Define this parameter only when creating a new disk from an
--   automatic snapshot. For more information, see the <a>Amazon Lightsail
--   Developer Guide</a>.</li>

--

--   created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:diskName:CreateDiskFromSnapshot'</a>,

--   name (e.g., <tt>my-disk</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:availabilityZone:CreateDiskFromSnapshot'</a>,
--   <a>createDiskFromSnapshot_availabilityZone</a> - The Availability Zone
--   where you want to create the disk (e.g., <tt>us-east-2a</tt>). Choose
--   the same Availability Zone as the Lightsail instance where you want to
--   create the disk.
--   
--   Use the GetRegions operation to list the Availability Zones where
--   Lightsail is currently available.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sizeInGb:CreateDiskFromSnapshot'</a>,
--   <a>createDiskFromSnapshot_sizeInGb</a> - The size of the disk in GB
--   (e.g., <tt>32</tt>).

data GetRelationalDatabaseLogEvents
GetRelationalDatabaseLogEvents' :: Maybe POSIX -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe Text -> Text -> Text -> GetRelationalDatabaseLogEvents

-- | Create a value of <a>GetRelationalDatabaseLogEvents</a> with all
--   optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional

--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:startTime:GetRelationalDatabaseLogEvents'</a>,
--   <a>getRelationalDatabaseLogEvents_startTime</a> - The start of the
--   time interval from which to get log events.
--   
--   Constraints:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Specified in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).</li>
--   <li>Specified in the Unix time format.For example, if you wish to use
--   a start time of October 1, 2018, at 8 PM UTC, then you input
--   <tt>1538424000</tt> as the start time.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:startFromHead:GetRelationalDatabaseLogEvents'</a>,
--   <a>getRelationalDatabaseLogEvents_startFromHead</a> - Parameter to
--   specify if the log should start from head or tail. If <tt>true</tt> is
--   specified, the log event starts from the head of the log. If
--   <tt>false</tt> is specified, the log event starts from the tail of the
--   log.
--   
--   For PostgreSQL, the default value of <tt>false</tt> is the only option
--   available.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endTime:GetRelationalDatabaseLogEvents'</a>,
--   <a>getRelationalDatabaseLogEvents_endTime</a> - The end of the time
--   interval from which to get log events.
--   
--   Constraints:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Specified in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).</li>
--   <li>Specified in the Unix time format.For example, if you wish to use
--   an end time of October 1, 2018, at 8 PM UTC, then you input
--   <tt>1538424000</tt> as the end time.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:pageToken:GetRelationalDatabaseLogEvents'</a>,
--   <a>getRelationalDatabaseLogEvents_pageToken</a> - The token to advance
--   to the next or previous page of results from your request.
--   
--   To get a page token, perform an initial
--   <tt>GetRelationalDatabaseLogEvents</tt> request. If your results are
--   paginated, the response will return a next forward token and/or next
--   backward token that you can specify as the page token in a subsequent
--   request.

--   <a>$sel:relationalDatabaseName:GetRelationalDatabaseLogEvents'</a>,

--   name of your database for which to get log events.

--   log stream.

data CreateContactMethod
CreateContactMethod' :: ContactProtocol -> Text -> CreateContactMethod

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateContactMethod</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocol:CreateContactMethod'</a>,
--   <a>createContactMethod_protocol</a> - The protocol of the contact
--   method, such as <tt>Email</tt> or <tt>SMS</tt> (text messaging).
--   
--   The <tt>SMS</tt> protocol is supported only in the following AWS
--   Regions.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>US East (N. Virginia) (<tt>us-east-1</tt>)</li>
--   <li>US West (Oregon) (<tt>us-west-2</tt>)</li>
--   <li>Europe (Ireland) (<tt>eu-west-1</tt>)</li>
--   <li>Asia Pacific (Tokyo) (<tt>ap-northeast-1</tt>)</li>
--   <li>Asia Pacific (Singapore) (<tt>ap-southeast-1</tt>)</li>
--   <li>Asia Pacific (Sydney) (<tt>ap-southeast-2</tt>)</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For a list of countries/regions where SMS text messages can be sent,
--   and the latest AWS Regions where SMS text messaging is supported, see
--   <a>Supported Regions and Countries</a> in the <i>Amazon SNS Developer
--   Guide</i>.
--   
--   For more information about notifications in Amazon Lightsail, see
--   <a>Notifications in Amazon Lightsail</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:contactEndpoint:CreateContactMethod'</a>,
--   <a>createContactMethod_contactEndpoint</a> - The destination of the
--   contact method, such as an email address or a mobile phone number.
--   
--   Use the E.164 format when specifying a mobile phone number. E.164 is a
--   standard for the phone number structure used for international
--   telecommunication. Phone numbers that follow this format can have a
--   maximum of 15 digits, and they are prefixed with the plus character
--   (+) and the country code. For example, a U.S. phone number in E.164
--   format would be specified as +1XXX5550100. For more information, see
--   <a>E.164</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
newCreateContactMethod :: ContactProtocol -> Text -> CreateContactMethod

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateDistribution</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:cacheBehaviorSettings:CreateDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>createDistribution_cacheBehaviorSettings</a> - An object that
--   describes the cache behavior settings for the distribution.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipAddressType:CreateDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>createDistribution_ipAddressType</a> - The IP address type for the
--   distribution.
--   
--   The possible values are <tt>ipv4</tt> for IPv4 only, and
--   <tt>dualstack</tt> for IPv4 and IPv6.
--   
--   The default value is <tt>dualstack</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:cacheBehaviors:CreateDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>createDistribution_cacheBehaviors</a> - An array of objects that
--   describe the per-path cache behavior for the distribution.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:CreateDistribution'</a>, <a>createDistribution_tags</a> -
--   The tag keys and optional values to add to the distribution during
--   create.
--   
--   Use the <tt>TagResource</tt> action to tag a resource after it's
--   created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:distributionName:CreateDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>createDistribution_distributionName</a> - The name for the
--   distribution.
--   
--   <a>$sel:origin:CreateDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>createDistribution_origin</a> - An object that describes the origin
--   resource for the distribution, such as a Lightsail instance or load
--   balancer.
--   
--   The distribution pulls, caches, and serves content from the origin.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultCacheBehavior:CreateDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>createDistribution_defaultCacheBehavior</a> - An object that
--   describes the default cache behavior for the distribution.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bundleId:CreateDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>createDistribution_bundleId</a> - The bundle ID to use for the
--   distribution.
--   
--   A distribution bundle describes the specifications of your
--   distribution, such as the monthly cost and monthly network transfer
--   quota.
--   
--   Use the <tt>GetDistributionBundles</tt> action to get a list of
--   distribution bundle IDs that you can specify.
newCreateDistribution :: Text -> InputOrigin -> CacheBehavior -> Text -> CreateDistribution

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateRelationalDatabaseSnapshot</a> smart
--   constructor.
data CreateRelationalDatabaseSnapshot
CreateRelationalDatabaseSnapshot' :: Maybe [Tag] -> Text -> Text -> CreateRelationalDatabaseSnapshot

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateRelationalDatabaseSnapshot</a> with all
--   optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:CreateRelationalDatabaseSnapshot'</a>,
--   <a>createRelationalDatabaseSnapshot_tags</a> - The tag keys and
--   optional values to add to the resource during create.
--   
--   Use the <tt>TagResource</tt> action to tag a resource after it's
--   created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:relationalDatabaseName:CreateRelationalDatabaseSnapshot'</a>,
--   <a>createRelationalDatabaseSnapshot_relationalDatabaseName</a> - The
--   name of the database on which to base your new snapshot.
--   
--   
--   <a>$sel:relationalDatabaseSnapshotName:CreateRelationalDatabaseSnapshot'</a>,
--   <a>createRelationalDatabaseSnapshot_relationalDatabaseSnapshotName</a>
--   - The name for your new database snapshot.
--   
--   Constraints:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Must contain from 2 to 255 alphanumeric characters, or
--   hyphens.</li>
--   <li>The first and last character must be a letter or number.</li>
--   </ul>

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateContainerService</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:publicDomainNames:CreateContainerService'</a>,
--   <a>createContainerService_publicDomainNames</a> - The public domain
--   names to use with the container service, such as <tt>example.com</tt>
--   and <tt>www.example.com</tt>.
--   
--   You can specify up to four public domain names for a container
--   service. The domain names that you specify are used when you create a
--   deployment with a container configured as the public endpoint of your
--   container service.
--   
--   If you don't specify public domain names, then you can use the default
--   domain of the container service.
--   
--   You must create and validate an SSL/TLS certificate before you can use
--   public domain names with your container service. Use the
--   <tt>CreateCertificate</tt> action to create a certificate for the
--   public domain names you want to use with your container service.
--   
--   You can specify public domain names using a string to array map as
--   shown in the example later on this page.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:CreateContainerService'</a>,
--   <a>createContainerService_tags</a> - The tag keys and optional values
--   to add to the certificate during create.
--   
--   Use the <tt>TagResource</tt> action to tag a resource after it's
--   created.
--   
--   For more information about tags in Lightsail, see the <a>Amazon
--   Lightsail Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:deployment:CreateContainerService'</a>,
--   <a>createContainerService_deployment</a> - An object that describes a
--   deployment for the container service.
--   
--   A deployment specifies the containers that will be launched on the
--   container service and their settings, such as the ports to open, the
--   environment variables to apply, and the launch command to run. It also
--   specifies the container that will serve as the public endpoint of the
--   deployment and its settings, such as the HTTP or HTTPS port to use,
--   and the health check configuration.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serviceName:CreateContainerService'</a>,
--   <a>createContainerService_serviceName</a> - The name for the container
--   service.
--   
--   The name that you specify for your container service will make up part
--   of its default domain. The default domain of a container service is
--   typically
--   <tt>https://&lt;ServiceName&gt;.&lt;RandomGUID&gt;.&lt;AWSRegion&gt;.cs.amazonlightsail.com</tt>.
--   If the name of your container service is <tt>container-service-1</tt>,
--   and it's located in the US East (Ohio) AWS region
--   (<tt>us-east-2</tt>), then the domain for your container service will
--   be like the following example:
--   <tt>https://container-service-1.ur4EXAMPLE2uq.us-east-2.cs.amazonlightsail.com</tt>
--   
--   The following are the requirements for container service names:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Must be unique within each AWS Region in your Lightsail
--   account.</li>
--   <li>Must contain 1 to 63 characters.</li>
--   <li>Must contain only alphanumeric characters and hyphens.</li>
--   <li>A hyphen (-) can separate words but cannot be at the start or end
--   of the name.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:power:CreateContainerService'</a>,
--   <a>createContainerService_power</a> - The power specification for the
--   container service.
--   
--   The power specifies the amount of memory, vCPUs, and base monthly cost
--   of each node of the container service. The <tt>power</tt> and
--   <tt>scale</tt> of a container service makes up its configured
--   capacity. To determine the monthly price of your container service,
--   multiply the base price of the <tt>power</tt> with the <tt>scale</tt>
--   (the number of nodes) of the service.
--   
--   Use the <tt>GetContainerServicePowers</tt> action to get a list of
--   power options that you can specify using this parameter, and their
--   base monthly cost.
--   
--   <a>$sel:scale:CreateContainerService'</a>,
--   <a>createContainerService_scale</a> - The scale specification for the
--   container service.
--   
--   The scale specifies the allocated compute nodes of the container
--   service. The <tt>power</tt> and <tt>scale</tt> of a container service
--   makes up its configured capacity. To determine the monthly price of
--   your container service, multiply the base price of the <tt>power</tt>
--   with the <tt>scale</tt> (the number of nodes) of the service.
newCreateContainerService :: Text -> ContainerServicePowerName -> Natural -> CreateContainerService

--   fields omitted.

--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.

--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:serviceName:RegisterContainerImage'</a>,
--   <a>registerContainerImage_serviceName</a> - The name of the container
--   service for which to register a container image.
--   
--   <a>$sel:label:RegisterContainerImage'</a>,
--   <a>registerContainerImage_label</a> - The label for the container
--   image when it's registered to the container service.
--   
--   Use a descriptive label that you can use to track the different
--   versions of your registered container images.
--   
--   Use the <tt>GetContainerImages</tt> action to return the container
--   images registered to a Lightsail container service. The label is the
--   <tt>&lt;imagelabel&gt;</tt> portion of the following image name
--   example:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><pre>:container-service-1.&lt;imagelabel&gt;.1</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If the name of your container service is <tt>mycontainerservice</tt>,
--   and the label that you specify is <tt>mystaticwebsite</tt>, then the
--   name of the registered container image will be
--   <tt>:mycontainerservice.mystaticwebsite.1</tt>.
--   
--   The number at the end of these image name examples represents the
--   version of the registered container image. If you push and register
--   another container image to the same Lightsail container service, with
--   the same label, then the version number for the new registered
--   container image will be <tt>2</tt>. If you push and register another
--   container image, the version number will be <tt>3</tt>, and so on.
--   
--   <a>$sel:digest:RegisterContainerImage'</a>,
--   <a>registerContainerImage_digest</a> - The digest of the container
--   image to be registered.
newRegisterContainerImage :: Text -> Text -> Text -> RegisterContainerImage

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCopySnapshot</a> smart constructor.
data CopySnapshot
CopySnapshot' :: Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Text -> RegionName -> CopySnapshot

-- | Create a value of <a>CopySnapshot</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:useLatestRestorableAutoSnapshot:CopySnapshot'</a>,
--   <a>copySnapshot_useLatestRestorableAutoSnapshot</a> - A Boolean value
--   to indicate whether to use the latest available automatic snapshot of
--   the specified source instance or disk.
--   
--   Constraints:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>This parameter cannot be defined together with the <tt>restore
--   date</tt> parameter. The <tt>use latest restorable auto snapshot</tt>
--   and <tt>restore date</tt> parameters are mutually exclusive.</li>
--   <li>Define this parameter only when copying an automatic snapshot as a
--   manual snapshot. For more information, see the <a>Amazon Lightsail
--   Developer Guide</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:restoreDate:CopySnapshot'</a>, <a>copySnapshot_restoreDate</a>
--   - The date of the source automatic snapshot to copy. Use the <tt>get
--   auto snapshots</tt> operation to identify the dates of the available
--   automatic snapshots.
--   
--   Constraints:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Must be specified in <tt>YYYY-MM-DD</tt> format.</li>
--   <li>This parameter cannot be defined together with the <tt>use latest
--   restorable auto snapshot</tt> parameter. The <tt>restore date</tt> and
--   <tt>use latest restorable auto snapshot</tt> parameters are mutually
--   exclusive.</li>
--   <li>Define this parameter only when copying an automatic snapshot as a
--   manual snapshot. For more information, see the <a>Amazon Lightsail
--   Developer Guide</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:sourceResourceName:CopySnapshot'</a>,
--   <a>copySnapshot_sourceResourceName</a> - The name of the source
--   instance or disk from which the source automatic snapshot was created.
--   
--   Constraint:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Define this parameter only when copying an automatic snapshot as a
--   manual snapshot. For more information, see the <a>Amazon Lightsail
--   Developer Guide</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:sourceSnapshotName:CopySnapshot'</a>,
--   <a>copySnapshot_sourceSnapshotName</a> - The name of the source manual
--   snapshot to copy.
--   
--   Constraint:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Define this parameter only when copying a manual snapshot as
--   another manual snapshot.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:targetSnapshotName:CopySnapshot'</a>,
--   <a>copySnapshot_targetSnapshotName</a> - The name of the new manual
--   snapshot to be created as a copy.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sourceRegion:CopySnapshot'</a>,
--   <a>copySnapshot_sourceRegion</a> - The AWS Region where the source
--   manual or automatic snapshot is located.
newCopySnapshot :: Text -> RegionName -> CopySnapshot

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newGetBucketMetricData</a> smart constructor.
data GetBucketMetricData
GetBucketMetricData' :: Text -> BucketMetricName -> POSIX -> POSIX -> Natural -> [MetricStatistic] -> MetricUnit -> GetBucketMetricData

-- | Create a value of <a>GetBucketMetricData</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:bucketName:GetBucketMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getBucketMetricData_bucketName</a> - The name of the bucket for
--   which to get metric data.
--   
--   <a>$sel:metricName:GetBucketMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getBucketMetricData_metricName</a> - The metric for which you want
--   to return information.
--   
--   Valid bucket metric names are listed below, along with the most useful
--   statistics to include in your request, and the published unit value.
--   
--   These bucket metrics are reported once per day.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>BucketSizeBytes</tt></b> - The amount of data in bytes
--   stored in a bucket. This value is calculated by summing the size of
--   all objects in the bucket (including object versions), including the
--   size of all parts for all incomplete multipart uploads to the
--   bucket.Statistics: The most useful statistic is <tt>Maximum</tt>.Unit:
--   The published unit is <tt>Bytes</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>NumberOfObjects</tt></b> - The total number of objects
--   stored in a bucket. This value is calculated by counting all objects
--   in the bucket (including object versions) and the total number of
--   parts for all incomplete multipart uploads to the bucket.Statistics:
--   The most useful statistic is <tt>Average</tt>.Unit: The published unit
--   is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:startTime:GetBucketMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getBucketMetricData_startTime</a> - The timestamp indicating the
--   earliest data to be returned.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endTime:GetBucketMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getBucketMetricData_endTime</a> - The timestamp indicating the
--   latest data to be returned.
--   
--   <a>$sel:period:GetBucketMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getBucketMetricData_period</a> - The granularity, in seconds, of
--   the returned data points.
--   
--   Bucket storage metrics are reported once per day. Therefore, you
--   should specify a period of 86400 seconds, which is the number of
--   seconds in a day.
--   
--   <a>$sel:statistics:GetBucketMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getBucketMetricData_statistics</a> - The statistic for the metric.
--   
--   The following statistics are available:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>Minimum</tt> - The lowest value observed during the specified
--   period. Use this value to determine low volumes of activity for your
--   application.</li>
--   <li><tt>Maximum</tt> - The highest value observed during the specified
--   period. Use this value to determine high volumes of activity for your
--   application.</li>
--   <li><tt>Sum</tt> - The sum of all values submitted for the matching
--   metric. You can use this statistic to determine the total volume of a
--   metric.</li>
--   <li><tt>Average</tt> - The value of <tt>Sum</tt> /
--   <tt>SampleCount</tt> during the specified period. By comparing this
--   statistic with the <tt>Minimum</tt> and <tt>Maximum</tt> values, you
--   can determine the full scope of a metric and how close the average use
--   is to the <tt>Minimum</tt> and <tt>Maximum</tt> values. This
--   comparison helps you to know when to increase or decrease your
--   resources.</li>
--   <li><tt>SampleCount</tt> - The count, or number, of data points used
--   for the statistical calculation.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:unit:GetBucketMetricData'</a>, <a>getBucketMetricData_unit</a>
--   - The unit for the metric data request.
--   
--   Valid units depend on the metric data being requested. For the valid
--   units with each available metric, see the <tt>metricName</tt>
--   parameter.
newGetBucketMetricData :: Text -> BucketMetricName -> UTCTime -> UTCTime -> Natural -> MetricUnit -> GetBucketMetricData

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newGetBucketMetricDataResponse</a> smart constructor.
data GetBucketMetricDataResponse

--   returned.

data DeleteRelationalDatabase
DeleteRelationalDatabase' :: Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Text -> DeleteRelationalDatabase

-- | Create a value of <a>DeleteRelationalDatabase</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:skipFinalSnapshot:DeleteRelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>deleteRelationalDatabase_skipFinalSnapshot</a> - Determines whether
--   a final database snapshot is created before your database is deleted.
--   If <tt>true</tt> is specified, no database snapshot is created. If
--   <tt>false</tt> is specified, a database snapshot is created before
--   your database is deleted.
--   
--   You must specify the <tt>final relational database snapshot name</tt>
--   parameter if the <tt>skip final snapshot</tt> parameter is
--   <tt>false</tt>.
--   
--   Default: <tt>false</tt>
--   
--   
--   <a>$sel:finalRelationalDatabaseSnapshotName:DeleteRelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>deleteRelationalDatabase_finalRelationalDatabaseSnapshotName</a> -
--   The name of the database snapshot created if <tt>skip final
--   snapshot</tt> is <tt>false</tt>, which is the default value for that
--   parameter.
--   
--   Specifying this parameter and also specifying the <tt>skip final
--   snapshot</tt> parameter to <tt>true</tt> results in an error.
--   
--   Constraints:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Must contain from 2 to 255 alphanumeric characters, or
--   hyphens.</li>
--   <li>The first and last character must be a letter or number.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:relationalDatabaseName:DeleteRelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>deleteRelationalDatabase_relationalDatabaseName</a> - The name of
--   the database that you are deleting.
newDeleteRelationalDatabase :: Text -> DeleteRelationalDatabase

-- | Create a value of <a>GetDiskSnapshot</a> with all optional fields

--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional

--   <a>getDiskSnapshot_diskSnapshotName</a> - The name of the disk
--   snapshot (e.g., <tt>my-disk-snapshot</tt>).
newGetDiskSnapshot :: Text -> GetDiskSnapshot

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateRelationalDatabase</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateRelationalDatabase
UpdateRelationalDatabase' :: Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Bool -> Text -> UpdateRelationalDatabase

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateRelationalDatabase</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:masterUserPassword:UpdateRelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>updateRelationalDatabase_masterUserPassword</a> - The password for
--   the master user. The password can include any printable ASCII
--   character except "/", """, or "@".
--   
--   My<b>SQL</b>
--   
--   Constraints: Must contain from 8 to 41 characters.
--   
--   <b>PostgreSQL</b>
--   
--   Constraints: Must contain from 8 to 128 characters.
--   
--   <a>$sel:publiclyAccessible:UpdateRelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>updateRelationalDatabase_publiclyAccessible</a> - Specifies the
--   accessibility options for your database. A value of <tt>true</tt>
--   specifies a database that is available to resources outside of your
--   Lightsail account. A value of <tt>false</tt> specifies a database that
--   is available only to your Lightsail resources in the same region as
--   your database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:enableBackupRetention:UpdateRelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>updateRelationalDatabase_enableBackupRetention</a> - When
--   <tt>true</tt>, enables automated backup retention for your database.
--   
--   Updates are applied during the next maintenance window because this
--   can result in an outage.
--   
--   <a>$sel:preferredMaintenanceWindow:UpdateRelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>updateRelationalDatabase_preferredMaintenanceWindow</a> - The
--   weekly time range during which system maintenance can occur on your
--   database.
--   
--   The default is a 30-minute window selected at random from an 8-hour
--   block of time for each AWS Region, occurring on a random day of the
--   week.
--   
--   Constraints:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Must be in the <tt>ddd:hh24:mi-ddd:hh24:mi</tt> format.</li>
--   <li>Valid days: Mon, Tue, Wed, Thu, Fri, Sat, Sun.</li>
--   <li>Must be at least 30 minutes.</li>
--   <li>Specified in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).</li>
--   <li>Example: <tt>Tue:17:00-Tue:17:30</tt></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:caCertificateIdentifier:UpdateRelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>updateRelationalDatabase_caCertificateIdentifier</a> - Indicates
--   the certificate that needs to be associated with the database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:preferredBackupWindow:UpdateRelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>updateRelationalDatabase_preferredBackupWindow</a> - The daily time
--   range during which automated backups are created for your database if
--   automated backups are enabled.
--   
--   Constraints:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Must be in the <tt>hh24:mi-hh24:mi</tt> format.Example:
--   <tt>16:00-16:30</tt></li>
--   <li>Specified in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).</li>
--   <li>Must not conflict with the preferred maintenance window.</li>
--   <li>Must be at least 30 minutes.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:applyImmediately:UpdateRelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>updateRelationalDatabase_applyImmediately</a> - When <tt>true</tt>,
--   applies changes immediately. When <tt>false</tt>, applies changes
--   during the preferred maintenance window. Some changes may cause an
--   outage.
--   
--   Default: <tt>false</tt>
--   
--   <a>$sel:rotateMasterUserPassword:UpdateRelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>updateRelationalDatabase_rotateMasterUserPassword</a> - When
--   <tt>true</tt>, the master user password is changed to a new strong
--   password generated by Lightsail.
--   
--   Use the <tt>get relational database master user password</tt>
--   operation to get the new password.
--   
--   <a>$sel:disableBackupRetention:UpdateRelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>updateRelationalDatabase_disableBackupRetention</a> - When
--   <tt>true</tt>, disables automated backup retention for your database.
--   
--   Disabling backup retention deletes all automated database backups.
--   Before disabling this, you may want to create a snapshot of your
--   database using the <tt>create relational database snapshot</tt>
--   operation.
--   
--   Updates are applied during the next maintenance window because this
--   can result in an outage.
--   
--   <a>$sel:relationalDatabaseName:UpdateRelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>updateRelationalDatabase_relationalDatabaseName</a> - The name of
--   your Lightsail database resource to update.
newUpdateRelationalDatabase :: Text -> UpdateRelationalDatabase

--   or previous passwords respectively. Specifying <tt>PENDING</tt>

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newPutAlarm</a> smart constructor.
data PutAlarm
PutAlarm' :: Maybe TreatMissingData -> Maybe [ContactProtocol] -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe [AlarmState] -> Text -> MetricName -> Text -> ComparisonOperator -> Double -> Int -> PutAlarm

-- | Create a value of <a>PutAlarm</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:treatMissingData:PutAlarm'</a>,
--   <a>putAlarm_treatMissingData</a> - Sets how this alarm will handle
--   missing data points.
--   
--   An alarm can treat missing data in the following ways:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>breaching</tt> - Assume the missing data is not within the
--   threshold. Missing data counts towards the number of times the metric
--   is not within the threshold.</li>
--   <li><tt>notBreaching</tt> - Assume the missing data is within the
--   threshold. Missing data does not count towards the number of times the
--   metric is not within the threshold.</li>
--   <li><tt>ignore</tt> - Ignore the missing data. Maintains the current
--   alarm state.</li>
--   <li><tt>missing</tt> - Missing data is treated as missing.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If <tt>treatMissingData</tt> is not specified, the default behavior of
--   <tt>missing</tt> is used.
--   
--   <a>$sel:contactProtocols:PutAlarm'</a>,
--   <a>putAlarm_contactProtocols</a> - The contact protocols to use for
--   the alarm, such as <tt>Email</tt>, <tt>SMS</tt> (text messaging), or
--   both.
--   
--   A notification is sent via the specified contact protocol if
--   notifications are enabled for the alarm, and when the alarm is
--   triggered.
--   
--   A notification is not sent if a contact protocol is not specified, if
--   the specified contact protocol is not configured in the AWS Region, or
--   if notifications are not enabled for the alarm using the
--   <tt>notificationEnabled</tt> paramater.
--   
--   Use the <tt>CreateContactMethod</tt> action to configure a contact
--   protocol in an AWS Region.
--   
--   <a>$sel:datapointsToAlarm:PutAlarm'</a>,
--   <a>putAlarm_datapointsToAlarm</a> - The number of data points that
--   must be not within the specified threshold to trigger the alarm. If
--   you are setting an "M out of N" alarm, this value
--   (<tt>datapointsToAlarm</tt>) is the M.
--   
--   <a>$sel:notificationEnabled:PutAlarm'</a>,
--   <a>putAlarm_notificationEnabled</a> - Indicates whether the alarm is
--   enabled.
--   
--   Notifications are enabled by default if you don't specify this
--   parameter.
--   
--   <a>$sel:notificationTriggers:PutAlarm'</a>,
--   <a>putAlarm_notificationTriggers</a> - The alarm states that trigger a
--   notification.
--   
--   An alarm has the following possible states:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>ALARM</tt> - The metric is outside of the defined
--   threshold.</li>
--   <li><tt>INSUFFICIENT_DATA</tt> - The alarm has just started, the
--   metric is not available, or not enough data is available for the
--   metric to determine the alarm state.</li>
--   <li><tt>OK</tt> - The metric is within the defined threshold.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   When you specify a notification trigger, the <tt>ALARM</tt> state must
--   be specified. The <tt>INSUFFICIENT_DATA</tt> and <tt>OK</tt> states
--   can be specified in addition to the <tt>ALARM</tt> state.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>If you specify <tt>OK</tt> as an alarm trigger, a notification is
--   sent when the alarm switches from an <tt>ALARM</tt> or
--   <tt>INSUFFICIENT_DATA</tt> alarm state to an <tt>OK</tt> state. This
--   can be thought of as an <i>all clear</i> alarm notification.</li>
--   <li>If you specify <tt>INSUFFICIENT_DATA</tt> as the alarm trigger, a
--   notification is sent when the alarm switches from an <tt>OK</tt> or
--   <tt>ALARM</tt> alarm state to an <tt>INSUFFICIENT_DATA</tt>
--   state.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   The notification trigger defaults to <tt>ALARM</tt> if you don't
--   specify this parameter.
--   
--   <a>$sel:alarmName:PutAlarm'</a>, <a>putAlarm_alarmName</a> - The name
--   for the alarm. Specify the name of an existing alarm to update, and
--   overwrite the previous configuration of the alarm.
--   
--   <a>$sel:metricName:PutAlarm'</a>, <a>putAlarm_metricName</a> - The
--   name of the metric to associate with the alarm.
--   
--   You can configure up to two alarms per metric.
--   
--   The following metrics are available for each resource type:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b>Instances</b>: <tt>BurstCapacityPercentage</tt>,
--   <tt>BurstCapacityTime</tt>, <tt>CPUUtilization</tt>,
--   <tt>NetworkIn</tt>, <tt>NetworkOut</tt>, <tt>StatusCheckFailed</tt>,
--   <tt>StatusCheckFailed_Instance</tt>, and
--   <tt>StatusCheckFailed_System</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b>Load balancers</b>: <tt>ClientTLSNegotiationErrorCount</tt>,
--   <tt>HealthyHostCount</tt>, <tt>UnhealthyHostCount</tt>,
--   <tt>HTTPCode_LB_4XX_Count</tt>, <tt>HTTPCode_LB_5XX_Count</tt>,
--   <tt>HTTPCode_Instance_2XX_Count</tt>,
--   <tt>HTTPCode_Instance_3XX_Count</tt>,
--   <tt>HTTPCode_Instance_4XX_Count</tt>,
--   <tt>HTTPCode_Instance_5XX_Count</tt>, <tt>InstanceResponseTime</tt>,
--   <tt>RejectedConnectionCount</tt>, and <tt>RequestCount</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b>Relational databases</b>: <tt>CPUUtilization</tt>,
--   <tt>DatabaseConnections</tt>, <tt>DiskQueueDepth</tt>,
--   <tt>FreeStorageSpace</tt>, <tt>NetworkReceiveThroughput</tt>, and
--   <tt>NetworkTransmitThroughput</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about these metrics, see <a>Metrics available in
--   Lightsail</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:monitoredResourceName:PutAlarm'</a>,
--   <a>putAlarm_monitoredResourceName</a> - The name of the Lightsail
--   resource that will be monitored.
--   
--   Instances, load balancers, and relational databases are the only
--   Lightsail resources that can currently be monitored by alarms.
--   
--   <a>$sel:comparisonOperator:PutAlarm'</a>,
--   <a>putAlarm_comparisonOperator</a> - The arithmetic operation to use
--   when comparing the specified statistic to the threshold. The specified
--   statistic value is used as the first operand.
--   
--   <a>$sel:threshold:PutAlarm'</a>, <a>putAlarm_threshold</a> - The value
--   against which the specified statistic is compared.
--   
--   <a>$sel:evaluationPeriods:PutAlarm'</a>,
--   <a>putAlarm_evaluationPeriods</a> - The number of most recent periods
--   over which data is compared to the specified threshold. If you are
--   setting an "M out of N" alarm, this value (<tt>evaluationPeriods</tt>)
--   is the N.
--   
--   If you are setting an alarm that requires that a number of consecutive
--   data points be breaching to trigger the alarm, this value specifies
--   the rolling period of time in which data points are evaluated.
--   
--   Each evaluation period is five minutes long. For example, specify an
--   evaluation period of 24 to evaluate a metric over a rolling period of
--   two hours.
--   
--   You can specify a minimum valuation period of 1 (5 minutes), and a
--   maximum evaluation period of 288 (24 hours).
newPutAlarm :: Text -> MetricName -> Text -> ComparisonOperator -> Double -> Int -> PutAlarm

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newPutAlarmResponse</a> smart constructor.
data PutAlarmResponse
PutAlarmResponse' :: Maybe [Operation] -> Int -> PutAlarmResponse

-- | Create a value of <a>PutAlarmResponse</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:operations:PutAlarmResponse'</a>,
--   <a>putAlarmResponse_operations</a> - An array of objects that describe
--   the result of the action, such as the status of the request, the
--   timestamp of the request, and the resources affected by the request.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:PutAlarmResponse'</a>,
--   <a>putAlarmResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http status code.
newPutAlarmResponse :: Int -> PutAlarmResponse

--   instance or disk from which to delete the automatic snapshot.
--   
--   <a>$sel:date:DeleteAutoSnapshot'</a>, <a>deleteAutoSnapshot_date</a> -
--   The date of the automatic snapshot to delete in <tt>YYYY-MM-DD</tt>
--   format. Use the <tt>get auto snapshots</tt> operation to get the
--   available automatic snapshots for a resource.
newDeleteAutoSnapshot :: Text -> Text -> DeleteAutoSnapshot

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateRelationalDatabase</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--

--   <a>createRelationalDatabase_masterUserPassword</a> - The password for
--   the master user. The password can include any printable ASCII
--   character except "/", """, or "@". It cannot contain spaces.
--   
--   <b>MySQL</b>
--   
--   Constraints: Must contain from 8 to 41 characters.
--   
--   <b>PostgreSQL</b>
--   
--   Constraints: Must contain from 8 to 128 characters.
--   
--   <a>$sel:publiclyAccessible:CreateRelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>createRelationalDatabase_publiclyAccessible</a> - Specifies the
--   accessibility options for your new database. A value of <tt>true</tt>
--   specifies a database that is available to resources outside of your
--   Lightsail account. A value of <tt>false</tt> specifies a database that
--   is available only to your Lightsail resources in the same region as
--   your database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:preferredMaintenanceWindow:CreateRelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>createRelationalDatabase_preferredMaintenanceWindow</a> - The
--   weekly time range during which system maintenance can occur on your
--   new database.
--   
--   The default is a 30-minute window selected at random from an 8-hour
--   block of time for each AWS Region, occurring on a random day of the
--   week.
--   
--   Constraints:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Must be in the <tt>ddd:hh24:mi-ddd:hh24:mi</tt> format.</li>
--   <li>Valid days: Mon, Tue, Wed, Thu, Fri, Sat, Sun.</li>
--   <li>Must be at least 30 minutes.</li>
--   <li>Specified in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).</li>
--   <li>Example: <tt>Tue:17:00-Tue:17:30</tt></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:preferredBackupWindow:CreateRelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>createRelationalDatabase_preferredBackupWindow</a> - The daily time
--   range during which automated backups are created for your new database
--   if automated backups are enabled.
--   
--   The default is a 30-minute window selected at random from an 8-hour
--   block of time for each AWS Region. For more information about the
--   preferred backup window time blocks for each region, see the
--   <a>Working With Backups</a> guide in the Amazon Relational Database
--   Service (Amazon RDS) documentation.
--   
--   Constraints:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Must be in the <tt>hh24:mi-hh24:mi</tt> format.Example:
--   <tt>16:00-16:30</tt></li>
--   <li>Specified in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).</li>
--   <li>Must not conflict with the preferred maintenance window.</li>
--   <li>Must be at least 30 minutes.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:availabilityZone:CreateRelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>createRelationalDatabase_availabilityZone</a> - The Availability
--   Zone in which to create your new database. Use the <tt>us-east-2a</tt>
--   case-sensitive format.
--   
--   You can get a list of Availability Zones by using the <tt>get
--   regions</tt> operation. Be sure to add the <tt>include relational
--   database Availability Zones</tt> parameter to your request.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:CreateRelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>createRelationalDatabase_tags</a> - The tag keys and optional
--   values to add to the resource during create.
--   
--   Use the <tt>TagResource</tt> action to tag a resource after it's
--   created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:relationalDatabaseName:CreateRelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>createRelationalDatabase_relationalDatabaseName</a> - The name to
--   use for your new Lightsail database resource.
--   
--   Constraints:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Must contain from 2 to 255 alphanumeric characters, or
--   hyphens.</li>
--   <li>The first and last character must be a letter or number.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:relationalDatabaseBlueprintId:CreateRelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>createRelationalDatabase_relationalDatabaseBlueprintId</a> - The
--   blueprint ID for your new database. A blueprint describes the major
--   engine version of a database.
--   
--   You can get a list of database blueprints IDs by using the <tt>get
--   relational database blueprints</tt> operation.
--   
--   <a>$sel:relationalDatabaseBundleId:CreateRelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>createRelationalDatabase_relationalDatabaseBundleId</a> - The
--   bundle ID for your new database. A bundle describes the performance
--   specifications for your database.
--   
--   You can get a list of database bundle IDs by using the <tt>get
--   relational database bundles</tt> operation.
--   
--   <a>$sel:masterDatabaseName:CreateRelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>createRelationalDatabase_masterDatabaseName</a> - The meaning of
--   this parameter differs according to the database engine you use.
--   
--   <b>MySQL</b>
--   
--   The name of the database to create when the Lightsail database
--   resource is created. If this parameter isn't specified, no database is
--   created in the database resource.
--   
--   Constraints:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Must contain 1 to 64 letters or numbers.</li>
--   <li>Must begin with a letter. Subsequent characters can be letters,
--   underscores, or digits (0- 9).</li>
--   <li>Can't be a word reserved by the specified database engine.For more
--   information about reserved words in MySQL, see the Keywords and
--   Reserved Words articles for <a>MySQL 5.6</a>, <a>MySQL 5.7</a>, and
--   <a>MySQL 8.0</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>PostgreSQL</b>
--   
--   The name of the database to create when the Lightsail database
--   resource is created. If this parameter isn't specified, a database
--   named <tt>postgres</tt> is created in the database resource.
--   
--   Constraints:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Must contain 1 to 63 letters or numbers.</li>
--   <li>Must begin with a letter. Subsequent characters can be letters,
--   underscores, or digits (0- 9).</li>
--   <li>Can't be a word reserved by the specified database engine.For more
--   information about reserved words in PostgreSQL, see the SQL Key Words
--   articles for <a>PostgreSQL 9.6</a>, <a>PostgreSQL 10</a>,
--   <a>PostgreSQL 11</a>, and <a>PostgreSQL 12</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:masterUsername:CreateRelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>createRelationalDatabase_masterUsername</a> - The name for the
--   master user.
--   
--   <b>MySQL</b>
--   
--   Constraints:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Required for MySQL.</li>
--   <li>Must be 1 to 16 letters or numbers. Can contain underscores.</li>
--   <li>First character must be a letter.</li>
--   <li>Can't be a reserved word for the chosen database engine.For more
--   information about reserved words in MySQL 5.6 or 5.7, see the Keywords
--   and Reserved Words articles for <a>MySQL 5.6</a>, <a>MySQL 5.7</a>, or
--   <a>MySQL 8.0</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>PostgreSQL</b>
--   
--   Constraints:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Required for PostgreSQL.</li>
--   <li>Must be 1 to 63 letters or numbers. Can contain underscores.</li>
--   <li>First character must be a letter.</li>
--   <li>Can't be a reserved word for the chosen database engine.For more

--   request.

--   <a>getContainerLog_filterPattern</a> - The pattern to use to filter
--   the returned log events to a specific term.
--   
--   The following are a few examples of filter patterns that you can
--   specify:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>To return all log events, specify a filter pattern of
--   <tt>""</tt>.</li>
--   <li>To exclude log events that contain the <tt>ERROR</tt> term, and
--   return all other log events, specify a filter pattern of
--   <tt>"-ERROR"</tt>.</li>
--   <li>To return log events that contain the <tt>ERROR</tt> term, specify
--   a filter pattern of <tt>"ERROR"</tt>.</li>
--   <li>To return log events that contain both the <tt>ERROR</tt> and
--   <tt>Exception</tt> terms, specify a filter pattern of <tt>"ERROR
--   Exception"</tt>.</li>
--   <li>To return log events that contain the <tt>ERROR</tt> <i>or</i> the
--   <tt>Exception</tt> term, specify a filter pattern of <tt>"?ERROR
--   ?Exception"</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:serviceName:GetContainerLog'</a>,

--   for which to get a container log.
--   
--   <a>$sel:containerName:GetContainerLog'</a>,
--   <a>getContainerLog_containerName</a> - The name of the container that
--   is either running or previously ran on the container service for which

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newGetLoadBalancerMetricData</a> smart constructor.
data GetLoadBalancerMetricData
GetLoadBalancerMetricData' :: Text -> LoadBalancerMetricName -> Natural -> POSIX -> POSIX -> MetricUnit -> [MetricStatistic] -> GetLoadBalancerMetricData

-- | Create a value of <a>GetLoadBalancerMetricData</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:loadBalancerName:GetLoadBalancerMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getLoadBalancerMetricData_loadBalancerName</a> - The name of the
--   load balancer.
--   
--   <a>$sel:metricName:GetLoadBalancerMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getLoadBalancerMetricData_metricName</a> - The metric for which you
--   want to return information.
--   
--   Valid load balancer metric names are listed below, along with the most
--   useful <tt>statistics</tt> to include in your request, and the
--   published <tt>unit</tt> value.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>ClientTLSNegotiationErrorCount</tt></b> - The number of TLS
--   connections initiated by the client that did not establish a session
--   with the load balancer due to a TLS error generated by the load
--   balancer. Possible causes include a mismatch of ciphers or
--   protocols.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>HealthyHostCount</tt></b> - The number of target instances
--   that are considered healthy.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful
--   statistic are <tt>Average</tt>, <tt>Minimum</tt>, and
--   <tt>Maximum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is
--   <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>HTTPCode_Instance_2XX_Count</tt></b> - The number of HTTP
--   2XX response codes generated by the target instances. This does not
--   include any response codes generated by the load
--   balancer.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>. Note that <tt>Minimum</tt>, <tt>Maximum</tt>, and
--   <tt>Average</tt> all return <tt>1</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>HTTPCode_Instance_3XX_Count</tt></b> - The number of HTTP
--   3XX response codes generated by the target instances. This does not
--   include any response codes generated by the load
--   balancer.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>. Note that <tt>Minimum</tt>, <tt>Maximum</tt>, and
--   <tt>Average</tt> all return <tt>1</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>HTTPCode_Instance_4XX_Count</tt></b> - The number of HTTP
--   4XX response codes generated by the target instances. This does not
--   include any response codes generated by the load
--   balancer.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>. Note that <tt>Minimum</tt>, <tt>Maximum</tt>, and
--   <tt>Average</tt> all return <tt>1</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>HTTPCode_Instance_5XX_Count</tt></b> - The number of HTTP
--   5XX response codes generated by the target instances. This does not
--   include any response codes generated by the load
--   balancer.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>. Note that <tt>Minimum</tt>, <tt>Maximum</tt>, and
--   <tt>Average</tt> all return <tt>1</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>HTTPCode_LB_4XX_Count</tt></b> - The number of HTTP 4XX
--   client error codes that originated from the load balancer. Client
--   errors are generated when requests are malformed or incomplete. These
--   requests were not received by the target instance. This count does not
--   include response codes generated by the target
--   instances.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>. Note that <tt>Minimum</tt>, <tt>Maximum</tt>, and
--   <tt>Average</tt> all return <tt>1</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>HTTPCode_LB_5XX_Count</tt></b> - The number of HTTP 5XX
--   server error codes that originated from the load balancer. This does
--   not include any response codes generated by the target instance. This
--   metric is reported if there are no healthy instances attached to the
--   load balancer, or if the request rate exceeds the capacity of the
--   instances (spillover) or the load balancer.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The
--   most useful statistic is <tt>Sum</tt>. Note that <tt>Minimum</tt>,
--   <tt>Maximum</tt>, and <tt>Average</tt> all return
--   <tt>1</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>InstanceResponseTime</tt></b> - The time elapsed, in
--   seconds, after the request leaves the load balancer until a response
--   from the target instance is received.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most
--   useful statistic is <tt>Average</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit
--   is <tt>Seconds</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>RejectedConnectionCount</tt></b> - The number of
--   connections that were rejected because the load balancer had reached
--   its maximum number of connections.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful
--   statistic is <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is
--   <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>RequestCount</tt></b> - The number of requests processed
--   over IPv4. This count includes only the requests with a response
--   generated by a target instance of the load
--   balancer.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>. Note that <tt>Minimum</tt>, <tt>Maximum</tt>, and
--   <tt>Average</tt> all return <tt>1</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>UnhealthyHostCount</tt></b> - The number of target
--   instances that are considered unhealthy.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most
--   useful statistic are <tt>Average</tt>, <tt>Minimum</tt>, and
--   <tt>Maximum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is
--   <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:period:GetLoadBalancerMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getLoadBalancerMetricData_period</a> - The granularity, in seconds,
--   of the returned data points.
--   
--   <a>$sel:startTime:GetLoadBalancerMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getLoadBalancerMetricData_startTime</a> - The start time of the
--   period.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endTime:GetLoadBalancerMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getLoadBalancerMetricData_endTime</a> - The end time of the period.
--   
--   <a>$sel:unit:GetLoadBalancerMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getLoadBalancerMetricData_unit</a> - The unit for the metric data
--   request. Valid units depend on the metric data being requested. For
--   the valid units with each available metric, see the
--   <tt>metricName</tt> parameter.
--   
--   <a>$sel:statistics:GetLoadBalancerMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getLoadBalancerMetricData_statistics</a> - The statistic for the
--   metric.
--   
--   The following statistics are available:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>Minimum</tt> - The lowest value observed during the specified
--   period. Use this value to determine low volumes of activity for your
--   application.</li>
--   <li><tt>Maximum</tt> - The highest value observed during the specified
--   period. Use this value to determine high volumes of activity for your
--   application.</li>
--   <li><tt>Sum</tt> - All values submitted for the matching metric added
--   together. You can use this statistic to determine the total volume of
--   a metric.</li>
--   <li><tt>Average</tt> - The value of Sum / SampleCount during the
--   specified period. By comparing this statistic with the Minimum and
--   Maximum values, you can determine the full scope of a metric and how
--   close the average use is to the Minimum and Maximum values. This
--   comparison helps you to know when to increase or decrease your
--   resources.</li>
--   <li><tt>SampleCount</tt> - The count, or number, of data points used
--   for the statistical calculation.</li>
--   </ul>
newGetLoadBalancerMetricData :: Text -> LoadBalancerMetricName -> Natural -> UTCTime -> UTCTime -> MetricUnit -> GetLoadBalancerMetricData

--   fields.

--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:loadBalancerName:AttachInstancesToLoadBalancer'</a>,
--   <a>attachInstancesToLoadBalancer_loadBalancerName</a> - The name of
--   the load balancer.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceNames:AttachInstancesToLoadBalancer'</a>,
--   <a>attachInstancesToLoadBalancer_instanceNames</a> - An array of
--   strings representing the instance name(s) you want to attach to your
--   load balancer.
--   
--   An instance must be <tt>running</tt> before you can attach it to your
--   load balancer.
--   
--   There are no additional limits on the number of instances you can
--   attach to your load balancer, aside from the limit of Lightsail
--   instances you can create in your account (20).
newAttachInstancesToLoadBalancer :: Text -> AttachInstancesToLoadBalancer

data UpdateContainerService
UpdateContainerService' :: Maybe Natural -> Maybe ContainerServicePowerName -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe (HashMap Text [Text]) -> Text -> UpdateContainerService

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateContainerService</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:scale:UpdateContainerService'</a>,
--   <a>updateContainerService_scale</a> - The scale for the container
--   service.
--   
--   The scale specifies the allocated compute nodes of the container
--   service. The <tt>power</tt> and <tt>scale</tt> of a container service
--   makes up its configured capacity. To determine the monthly price of
--   your container service, multiply the base price of the <tt>power</tt>
--   with the <tt>scale</tt> (the number of nodes) of the service.
--   
--   <a>$sel:power:UpdateContainerService'</a>,
--   <a>updateContainerService_power</a> - The power for the container
--   service.
--   
--   The power specifies the amount of memory, vCPUs, and base monthly cost
--   of each node of the container service. The <tt>power</tt> and
--   <tt>scale</tt> of a container service makes up its configured
--   capacity. To determine the monthly price of your container service,
--   multiply the base price of the <tt>power</tt> with the <tt>scale</tt>
--   (the number of nodes) of the service.
--   
--   Use the <tt>GetContainerServicePowers</tt> action to view the
--   specifications of each power option.
--   
--   <a>$sel:isDisabled:UpdateContainerService'</a>,
--   <a>updateContainerService_isDisabled</a> - A Boolean value to indicate
--   whether the container service is disabled.
--   
--   <a>$sel:publicDomainNames:UpdateContainerService'</a>,
--   <a>updateContainerService_publicDomainNames</a> - The public domain
--   names to use with the container service, such as <tt>example.com</tt>
--   and <tt>www.example.com</tt>.
--   
--   You can specify up to four public domain names for a container
--   service. The domain names that you specify are used when you create a
--   deployment with a container configured as the public endpoint of your
--   container service.
--   
--   If you don't specify public domain names, then you can use the default
--   domain of the container service.
--   
--   You must create and validate an SSL/TLS certificate before you can use
--   public domain names with your container service. Use the
--   <tt>CreateCertificate</tt> action to create a certificate for the
--   public domain names you want to use with your container service.
--   
--   You can specify public domain names using a string to array map as
--   shown in the example later on this page.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serviceName:UpdateContainerService'</a>,
--   <a>updateContainerService_serviceName</a> - The name of the container
--   service to update.
newUpdateContainerService :: Text -> UpdateContainerService

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newGetInstanceMetricData</a> smart constructor.
data GetInstanceMetricData
GetInstanceMetricData' :: Text -> InstanceMetricName -> Natural -> POSIX -> POSIX -> MetricUnit -> [MetricStatistic] -> GetInstanceMetricData

-- | Create a value of <a>GetInstanceMetricData</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceName:GetInstanceMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getInstanceMetricData_instanceName</a> - The name of the instance
--   for which you want to get metrics data.
--   
--   <a>$sel:metricName:GetInstanceMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getInstanceMetricData_metricName</a> - The metric for which you
--   want to return information.
--   
--   Valid instance metric names are listed below, along with the most
--   useful <tt>statistics</tt> to include in your request, and the
--   published <tt>unit</tt> value.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>BurstCapacityPercentage</tt></b> - The percentage of CPU
--   performance available for your instance to burst above its baseline.
--   Your instance continuously accrues and consumes burst capacity. Burst
--   capacity stops accruing when your instance's
--   <tt>BurstCapacityPercentage</tt> reaches 100%. For more information,
--   see <a>Viewing instance burst capacity in Amazon
--   Lightsail</a>.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistics are
--   <tt>Maximum</tt> and <tt>Average</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>Percent</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>BurstCapacityTime</tt></b> - The available amount of time
--   for your instance to burst at 100% CPU utilization. Your instance
--   continuously accrues and consumes burst capacity. Burst capacity time
--   stops accruing when your instance's <tt>BurstCapacityPercentage</tt>
--   metric reaches 100%.Burst capacity time is consumed at the full rate
--   only when your instance operates at 100% CPU utilization. For example,
--   if your instance operates at 50% CPU utilization in the burstable zone
--   for a 5-minute period, then it consumes CPU burst capacity minutes at
--   a 50% rate in that period. Your instance consumed 2 minutes and 30
--   seconds of CPU burst capacity minutes in the 5-minute period. For more
--   information, see <a>Viewing instance burst capacity in Amazon
--   Lightsail</a>.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistics are
--   <tt>Maximum</tt> and <tt>Average</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>Seconds</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>CPUUtilization</tt></b> - The percentage of allocated
--   compute units that are currently in use on the instance. This metric
--   identifies the processing power to run the applications on the
--   instance. Tools in your operating system can show a lower percentage
--   than Lightsail when the instance is not allocated a full processor
--   core.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistics are
--   <tt>Maximum</tt> and <tt>Average</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published
--   unit is <tt>Percent</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>NetworkIn</tt></b> - The number of bytes received on all
--   network interfaces by the instance. This metric identifies the volume
--   of incoming network traffic to the instance. The number reported is
--   the number of bytes received during the period. Because this metric is
--   reported in 5-minute intervals, divide the reported number by 300 to
--   find Bytes/second.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is <tt>Bytes</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>NetworkOut</tt></b> - The number of bytes sent out on all
--   network interfaces by the instance. This metric identifies the volume
--   of outgoing network traffic from the instance. The number reported is
--   the number of bytes sent during the period. Because this metric is
--   reported in 5-minute intervals, divide the reported number by 300 to
--   find Bytes/second.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is <tt>Bytes</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>StatusCheckFailed</tt></b> - Reports whether the instance
--   passed or failed both the instance status check and the system status
--   check. This metric can be either 0 (passed) or 1 (failed). This metric
--   data is available in 1-minute (60 seconds)
--   granularity.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful statistic is
--   <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>StatusCheckFailed_Instance</tt></b> - Reports whether the
--   instance passed or failed the instance status check. This metric can
--   be either 0 (passed) or 1 (failed). This metric data is available in
--   1-minute (60 seconds) granularity.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful
--   statistic is <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is
--   <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>StatusCheckFailed_System</tt></b> - Reports whether the
--   instance passed or failed the system status check. This metric can be
--   either 0 (passed) or 1 (failed). This metric data is available in
--   1-minute (60 seconds) granularity.<tt>Statistics</tt>: The most useful
--   statistic is <tt>Sum</tt>.<tt>Unit</tt>: The published unit is
--   <tt>Count</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:period:GetInstanceMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getInstanceMetricData_period</a> - The granularity, in seconds, of
--   the returned data points.
--   
--   The <tt>StatusCheckFailed</tt>, <tt>StatusCheckFailed_Instance</tt>,
--   and <tt>StatusCheckFailed_System</tt> instance metric data is
--   available in 1-minute (60 seconds) granularity. All other instance
--   metric data is available in 5-minute (300 seconds) granularity.
--   
--   <a>$sel:startTime:GetInstanceMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getInstanceMetricData_startTime</a> - The start time of the time
--   period.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endTime:GetInstanceMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getInstanceMetricData_endTime</a> - The end time of the time
--   period.
--   
--   <a>$sel:unit:GetInstanceMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getInstanceMetricData_unit</a> - The unit for the metric data
--   request. Valid units depend on the metric data being requested. For
--   the valid units to specify with each available metric, see the
--   <tt>metricName</tt> parameter.
--   
--   <a>$sel:statistics:GetInstanceMetricData'</a>,
--   <a>getInstanceMetricData_statistics</a> - The statistic for the
--   metric.
--   
--   The following statistics are available:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>Minimum</tt> - The lowest value observed during the specified
--   period. Use this value to determine low volumes of activity for your
--   application.</li>
--   <li><tt>Maximum</tt> - The highest value observed during the specified
--   period. Use this value to determine high volumes of activity for your
--   application.</li>
--   <li><tt>Sum</tt> - All values submitted for the matching metric added
--   together. You can use this statistic to determine the total volume of
--   a metric.</li>
--   <li><tt>Average</tt> - The value of Sum / SampleCount during the
--   specified period. By comparing this statistic with the Minimum and
--   Maximum values, you can determine the full scope of a metric and how
--   close the average use is to the Minimum and Maximum values. This
--   comparison helps you to know when to increase or decrease your
--   resources.</li>
--   <li><tt>SampleCount</tt> - The count, or number, of data points used
--   for the statistical calculation.</li>
--   </ul>
newGetInstanceMetricData :: Text -> InstanceMetricName -> Natural -> UTCTime -> UTCTime -> MetricUnit -> GetInstanceMetricData

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newGetInstanceMetricDataResponse</a> smart constructor.
data GetInstanceMetricDataResponse

--   perform the load balancer health check. If you didn't specify a health
--   check path, Lightsail uses the root path of your website (e.g.,
--   <tt>"/"</tt>).
--   
--   You may want to specify a custom health check path other than the root
--   of your application if your home page loads slowly or has a lot of
--   media or scripting on it.

--   <a>$sel:certificateName:CreateLoadBalancer'</a>,

--   alternative domains and subdomains to use with your SSL/TLS
--   certificate (e.g., <tt>www.example.com</tt>, <tt>example.com</tt>,

--   load balancer.

--   <tt>dualstack</tt> for IPv4 and IPv6.

--   balancer.
