-- | Describes the request headers that a Lightsail distribution bases
--   caching on.
--   
--   For the headers that you specify, your distribution caches separate
--   versions of the specified content based on the header values in viewer
--   requests. For example, suppose viewer requests for <tt>logo.jpg</tt>
--   contain a custom <tt>product</tt> header that has a value of either
--   <tt>acme</tt> or <tt>apex</tt>, and you configure your distribution to
--   cache your content based on values in the <tt>product</tt> header.
--   Your distribution forwards the <tt>product</tt> header to the origin
--   and caches the response from the origin once for each header value.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newHeaderObject</a> smart constructor.
data HeaderObject
HeaderObject' :: Maybe [HeaderEnum] -> Maybe ForwardValues -> HeaderObject

-- | Create a value of <a>HeaderObject</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:headersAllowList:HeaderObject'</a>,
--   <a>headerObject_headersAllowList</a> - The specific headers to forward
--   to your distribution's origin.
--   
--   <a>$sel:option:HeaderObject'</a>, <a>headerObject_option</a> - The
--   headers that you want your distribution to forward to your origin and
--   base caching on.
--   
--   You can configure your distribution to do one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>all</tt></b> - Forward all headers to your origin.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>none</tt></b> - Forward only the default headers.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>allow-list</tt></b> - Forward only the headers you specify
--   using the <tt>headersAllowList</tt> parameter.</li>
--   </ul>
newHeaderObject :: HeaderObject

-- | Describes the public SSH host keys or the RDP certificate.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newHostKeyAttributes</a> smart constructor.
data HostKeyAttributes
HostKeyAttributes' :: Maybe POSIX -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe Text -> HostKeyAttributes

-- | Create a value of <a>HostKeyAttributes</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:notValidAfter:HostKeyAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>hostKeyAttributes_notValidAfter</a> - The returned RDP certificate
--   is not valid after this point in time.
--   
--   This value is listed only for RDP certificates.
--   
--   <a>$sel:notValidBefore:HostKeyAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>hostKeyAttributes_notValidBefore</a> - The returned RDP certificate
--   is valid after this point in time.
--   
--   This value is listed only for RDP certificates.
--   
--   <a>$sel:fingerprintSHA1:HostKeyAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>hostKeyAttributes_fingerprintSHA1</a> - The SHA-1 fingerprint of
--   the returned SSH host key or RDP certificate.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Example of an SHA-1 SSH
--   fingerprint:<pre>SHA1:1CHH6FaAaXjtFOsR/t83vf91SR0</pre></li>
--   <li>Example of an SHA-1 RDP
--   fingerprint:<pre>af:34:51:fe:09:f0:e0:da:b8:4e:56:ca:60:c2:10:ff:38:06:db:45</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:publicKey:HostKeyAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>hostKeyAttributes_publicKey</a> - The public SSH host key or the
--   RDP certificate.
--   
--   <a>$sel:algorithm:HostKeyAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>hostKeyAttributes_algorithm</a> - The SSH host key algorithm or the
--   RDP certificate format.
--   
--   For SSH host keys, the algorithm may be <tt>ssh-rsa</tt>,
--   <tt>ecdsa-sha2-nistp256</tt>, <tt>ssh-ed25519</tt>, etc. For RDP
--   certificates, the algorithm is always <tt>x509-cert</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:witnessedAt:HostKeyAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>hostKeyAttributes_witnessedAt</a> - The time that the SSH host key
--   or RDP certificate was recorded by Lightsail.
--   
--   <a>$sel:fingerprintSHA256:HostKeyAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>hostKeyAttributes_fingerprintSHA256</a> - The SHA-256 fingerprint
--   of the returned SSH host key or RDP certificate.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Example of an SHA-256 SSH
--   fingerprint:<pre>SHA256:KTsMnRBh1IhD17HpdfsbzeGA4jOijm5tyXsMjKVbB8o</pre></li>
--   <li>Example of an SHA-256 RDP
--   fingerprint:<pre>03:9b:36:9f:4b:de:4e:61:70:fc:7c:c9:78:e7:d2:1a:1c:25:a8:0c:91:f6:7c:e4:d6:a0:85:c8:b4:53:99:68</pre></li>
--   </ul>
newHostKeyAttributes :: HostKeyAttributes

-- | Describes the origin resource of an Amazon Lightsail content delivery
--   network (CDN) distribution.
--   
--   An origin can be a Lightsail instance or load balancer. A distribution
--   pulls content from an origin, caches it, and serves it to viewers via
--   a worldwide network of edge servers.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInputOrigin</a> smart constructor.
data InputOrigin
InputOrigin' :: Maybe RegionName -> Maybe Text -> Maybe OriginProtocolPolicyEnum -> InputOrigin

-- | Create a value of <a>InputOrigin</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:regionName:InputOrigin'</a>, <a>inputOrigin_regionName</a> -
--   The AWS Region name of the origin resource.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:InputOrigin'</a>, <a>inputOrigin_name</a> - The name of
--   the origin resource.
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocolPolicy:InputOrigin'</a>,
--   <a>inputOrigin_protocolPolicy</a> - The protocol that your Amazon
--   Lightsail distribution uses when establishing a connection with your
--   origin to pull content.
newInputOrigin :: InputOrigin

-- | Describes an instance (a virtual private server).
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInstance</a> smart constructor.
data Instance
Instance' :: Maybe InstanceState -> Maybe ResourceType -> Maybe Text -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe ResourceLocation -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [AddOn] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe InstanceNetworking -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe IpAddressType -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe InstanceHardware -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe [Tag] -> Instance

-- | Create a value of <a>Instance</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:state:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_state</a> - The status code
--   and the state (e.g., <tt>running</tt>) for the instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceType:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_resourceType</a> - The
--   type of resource (usually <tt>Instance</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:arn:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_arn</a> - The Amazon Resource
--   Name (ARN) of the instance (e.g.,
--   <tt>arn:aws:lightsail:us-east-2:123456789101:Instance/244ad76f-8aad-4741-809f-12345EXAMPLE</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:createdAt:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_createdAt</a> - The
--   timestamp when the instance was created (e.g., <tt>1479734909.17</tt>)
--   in Unix time format.
--   
--   <a>$sel:location:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_location</a> - The region
--   name and Availability Zone where the instance is located.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sshKeyName:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_sshKeyName</a> - The
--   name of the SSH key being used to connect to the instance (e.g.,
--   <tt>LightsailDefaultKeyPair</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:addOns:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_addOns</a> - An array of
--   objects representing the add-ons enabled on the instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:username:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_username</a> - The user
--   name for connecting to the instance (e.g., <tt>ec2-user</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:networking:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_networking</a> -
--   Information about the public ports and monthly data transfer rates for
--   the instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bundleId:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_bundleId</a> - The bundle
--   for the instance (e.g., <tt>micro_1_0</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_name</a> - The name the user
--   gave the instance (e.g., <tt>Amazon_Linux-1GB-Ohio-1</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipAddressType:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_ipAddressType</a> -
--   The IP address type of the instance.
--   
--   The possible values are <tt>ipv4</tt> for IPv4 only, and
--   <tt>dualstack</tt> for IPv4 and IPv6.
--   
--   <a>$sel:supportCode:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_supportCode</a> - The
--   support code. Include this code in your email to support when you have
--   questions about an instance or another resource in Lightsail. This
--   code enables our support team to look up your Lightsail information
--   more easily.
--   
--   <a>$sel:blueprintId:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_blueprintId</a> - The
--   blueprint ID (e.g., <tt>os_amlinux_2016_03</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:privateIpAddress:Instance'</a>,
--   <a>instance_privateIpAddress</a> - The private IP address of the
--   instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:blueprintName:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_blueprintName</a> -
--   The friendly name of the blueprint (e.g., <tt>Amazon Linux</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:isStaticIp:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_isStaticIp</a> - A
--   Boolean value indicating whether this instance has a static IP
--   assigned to it.
--   
--   <a>$sel:publicIpAddress:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_publicIpAddress</a>
--   - The public IP address of the instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:hardware:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_hardware</a> - The size of
--   the vCPU and the amount of RAM for the instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipv6Addresses:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_ipv6Addresses</a> -
--   The IPv6 addresses of the instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:Instance'</a>, <a>instance_tags</a> - The tag keys and
--   optional values for the resource. For more information about tags in
--   Lightsail, see the <a>Amazon Lightsail Developer Guide</a>.
newInstance :: Instance

-- | The parameters for gaining temporary access to one of your Amazon
--   Lightsail instances.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInstanceAccessDetails</a> smart constructor.
data InstanceAccessDetails
InstanceAccessDetails' :: Maybe [HostKeyAttributes] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe Text -> Maybe InstanceAccessProtocol -> Maybe PasswordData -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> InstanceAccessDetails

-- | Create a value of <a>InstanceAccessDetails</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:hostKeys:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_hostKeys</a> - Describes the public SSH host
--   keys or the RDP certificate.
--   
--   <a>$sel:certKey:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_certKey</a> - For SSH access, the public key
--   to use when accessing your instance For OpenSSH clients (e.g., command
--   line SSH), you should save this value to <tt>tempkey-cert.pub</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipAddress:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_ipAddress</a> - The public IP address of the
--   Amazon Lightsail instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:privateKey:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_privateKey</a> - For SSH access, the
--   temporary private key. For OpenSSH clients (e.g., command line SSH),
--   you should save this value to <tt>tempkey</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:expiresAt:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_expiresAt</a> - For SSH access, the date on
--   which the temporary keys expire.
--   
--   <a>$sel:username:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_username</a> - The user name to use when
--   logging in to the Amazon Lightsail instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocol:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_protocol</a> - The protocol for these Amazon
--   Lightsail instance access details.
--   
--   <a>$sel:passwordData:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_passwordData</a> - For a Windows Server-based
--   instance, an object with the data you can use to retrieve your
--   password. This is only needed if <tt>password</tt> is empty and the
--   instance is not new (and therefore the password is not ready yet).
--   When you create an instance, it can take up to 15 minutes for the
--   instance to be ready.
--   
--   <a>$sel:password:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_password</a> - For RDP access, the password
--   for your Amazon Lightsail instance. Password will be an empty string
--   if the password for your new instance is not ready yet. When you
--   create an instance, it can take up to 15 minutes for the instance to
--   be ready.
--   
--   If you create an instance using any key pair other than the default
--   (<tt>LightsailDefaultKeyPair</tt>), <tt>password</tt> will always be
--   an empty string.
--   
--   If you change the Administrator password on the instance, Lightsail
--   will continue to return the original password value. When accessing
--   the instance using RDP, you need to manually enter the Administrator
--   password after changing it from the default.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceName:InstanceAccessDetails'</a>,
--   <a>instanceAccessDetails_instanceName</a> - The name of this Amazon
--   Lightsail instance.
newInstanceAccessDetails :: InstanceAccessDetails

-- | Describes the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud instance and related
--   resources to be created using the <tt>create cloud formation
--   stack</tt> operation.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInstanceEntry</a> smart constructor.
data InstanceEntry
InstanceEntry' :: Maybe Text -> Text -> Text -> PortInfoSourceType -> Text -> InstanceEntry

-- | Create a value of <a>InstanceEntry</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:userData:InstanceEntry'</a>, <a>instanceEntry_userData</a> - A
--   launch script you can create that configures a server with additional
--   user data. For example, you might want to run <tt>apt-get -y
--   update</tt>.
--   
--   Depending on the machine image you choose, the command to get software
--   on your instance varies. Amazon Linux and CentOS use <tt>yum</tt>,
--   Debian and Ubuntu use <tt>apt-get</tt>, and FreeBSD uses <tt>pkg</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sourceName:InstanceEntry'</a>, <a>instanceEntry_sourceName</a>
--   - The name of the export snapshot record, which contains the exported
--   Lightsail instance snapshot that will be used as the source of the new
--   Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   Use the <tt>get export snapshot records</tt> operation to get a list
--   of export snapshot records that you can use to create a CloudFormation
--   stack.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceType:InstanceEntry'</a>,
--   <a>instanceEntry_instanceType</a> - The instance type (e.g.,
--   <tt>t2.micro</tt>) to use for the new Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:portInfoSource:InstanceEntry'</a>,
--   <a>instanceEntry_portInfoSource</a> - The port configuration to use
--   for the new Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   The following configuration options are available:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>DEFAULT</tt> - Use the default firewall settings from the
--   Lightsail instance blueprint. If this is specified, then IPv4 and IPv6
--   will be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon
--   EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>INSTANCE</tt> - Use the configured firewall settings from the
--   source Lightsail instance. If this is specified, the new instance that
--   is created in Amazon EC2 will be configured to match the configuration
--   of the source Lightsail instance. For example, if the source instance
--   is configured for dual-stack (IPv4 and IPv6), then IPv4 and IPv6 will
--   be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon EC2. If
--   the source instance is configured for IPv4 only, then only IPv4 will
--   be configured for the new instance that is created in Amazon EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>NONE</tt> - Use the default Amazon EC2 security group. If this
--   is specified, then only IPv4 will be configured for the new instance
--   that is created in Amazon EC2.</li>
--   <li><tt>CLOSED</tt> - All ports closed. If this is specified, then
--   only IPv4 will be configured for the new instance that is created in
--   Amazon EC2.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If you configured <tt>lightsail-connect</tt> as a
--   <tt>cidrListAliases</tt> on your instance, or if you chose to allow
--   the Lightsail browser-based SSH or RDP clients to connect to your
--   instance, that configuration is not carried over to your new Amazon
--   EC2 instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:availabilityZone:InstanceEntry'</a>,
--   <a>instanceEntry_availabilityZone</a> - The Availability Zone for the
--   new Amazon EC2 instance.
newInstanceEntry :: Text -> Text -> PortInfoSourceType -> Text -> InstanceEntry

-- | Describes the hardware for the instance.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInstanceHardware</a> smart constructor.
data InstanceHardware
InstanceHardware' :: Maybe Int -> Maybe [Disk] -> Maybe Double -> InstanceHardware

-- | Create a value of <a>InstanceHardware</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:cpuCount:InstanceHardware'</a>,
--   <a>instanceHardware_cpuCount</a> - The number of vCPUs the instance
--   has.
--   
--   <a>$sel:disks:InstanceHardware'</a>, <a>instanceHardware_disks</a> -
--   The disks attached to the instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ramSizeInGb:InstanceHardware'</a>,
--   <a>instanceHardware_ramSizeInGb</a> - The amount of RAM in GB on the
--   instance (e.g., <tt>1.0</tt>).
newInstanceHardware :: InstanceHardware

-- | Describes information about the health of the instance.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInstanceHealthSummary</a> smart constructor.
data InstanceHealthSummary
InstanceHealthSummary' :: Maybe InstanceHealthState -> Maybe Text -> Maybe InstanceHealthReason -> InstanceHealthSummary

-- | Create a value of <a>InstanceHealthSummary</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceHealth:InstanceHealthSummary'</a>,
--   <a>instanceHealthSummary_instanceHealth</a> - Describes the overall
--   instance health. Valid values are below.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceName:InstanceHealthSummary'</a>,
--   <a>instanceHealthSummary_instanceName</a> - The name of the Lightsail
--   instance for which you are requesting health check data.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceHealthReason:InstanceHealthSummary'</a>,
--   <a>instanceHealthSummary_instanceHealthReason</a> - More information
--   about the instance health. If the <tt>instanceHealth</tt> is
--   <tt>healthy</tt>, then an <tt>instanceHealthReason</tt> value is not
--   provided.
--   
--   If <b><tt>instanceHealth</tt></b> is <tt>initial</tt>, the
--   <b><tt>instanceHealthReason</tt></b> value can be one of the
--   following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>Lb.RegistrationInProgress</tt></b> - The target instance is
--   in the process of being registered with the load balancer.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Lb.InitialHealthChecking</tt></b> - The Lightsail load
--   balancer is still sending the target instance the minimum number of
--   health checks required to determine its health status.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If <b><tt>instanceHealth</tt></b> is <tt>unhealthy</tt>, the
--   <b><tt>instanceHealthReason</tt></b> value can be one of the
--   following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.ResponseCodeMismatch</tt></b> - The health checks
--   did not return an expected HTTP code.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.Timeout</tt></b> - The health check requests timed
--   out.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.FailedHealthChecks</tt></b> - The health checks
--   failed because the connection to the target instance timed out, the
--   target instance response was malformed, or the target instance failed
--   the health check for an unknown reason.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Lb.InternalError</tt></b> - The health checks failed due to
--   an internal error.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If <b><tt>instanceHealth</tt></b> is <tt>unused</tt>, the
--   <b><tt>instanceHealthReason</tt></b> value can be one of the
--   following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.NotRegistered</tt></b> - The target instance is
--   not registered with the target group.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.NotInUse</tt></b> - The target group is not used
--   by any load balancer, or the target instance is in an Availability
--   Zone that is not enabled for its load balancer.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.IpUnusable</tt></b> - The target IP address is
--   reserved for use by a Lightsail load balancer.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.InvalidState</tt></b> - The target is in the
--   stopped or terminated state.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If <b><tt>instanceHealth</tt></b> is <tt>draining</tt>, the
--   <b><tt>instanceHealthReason</tt></b> value can be one of the
--   following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance.DeregistrationInProgress</tt></b> - The target
--   instance is in the process of being deregistered and the
--   deregistration delay period has not expired.</li>
--   </ul>
newInstanceHealthSummary :: InstanceHealthSummary

-- | Describes monthly data transfer rates and port information for an
--   instance.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInstanceNetworking</a> smart constructor.
data InstanceNetworking
InstanceNetworking' :: Maybe MonthlyTransfer -> Maybe [InstancePortInfo] -> InstanceNetworking

-- | Create a value of <a>InstanceNetworking</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:monthlyTransfer:InstanceNetworking'</a>,
--   <a>instanceNetworking_monthlyTransfer</a> - The amount of data in GB
--   allocated for monthly data transfers.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ports:InstanceNetworking'</a>, <a>instanceNetworking_ports</a>
--   - An array of key-value pairs containing information about the ports
--   on the instance.
newInstanceNetworking :: InstanceNetworking

-- | Describes information about ports for an Amazon Lightsail instance.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInstancePortInfo</a> smart constructor.
data InstancePortInfo
InstancePortInfo' :: Maybe Int -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe NetworkProtocol -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe AccessDirection -> Maybe PortAccessType -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Text -> InstancePortInfo

-- | Create a value of <a>InstancePortInfo</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:fromPort:InstancePortInfo'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortInfo_fromPort</a> - The first port in a range of open
--   ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP type for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP type for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:cidrs:InstancePortInfo'</a>, <a>instancePortInfo_cidrs</a> -
--   The IPv4 address, or range of IPv4 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol.
--   
--   The <tt>ipv6Cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv6 addresses that are
--   allowed to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:commonName:InstancePortInfo'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortInfo_commonName</a> - The common name of the port
--   information.
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocol:InstancePortInfo'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortInfo_protocol</a> - The IP protocol name.
--   
--   The name can be one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>tcp</tt> - Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) provides
--   reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of streamed data between
--   applications running on hosts communicating by an IP network. If you
--   have an application that doesn't require reliable data stream service,
--   use UDP instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>all</tt> - All transport layer protocol types. For more
--   general information, see <a>Transport layer</a> on
--   <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li><tt>udp</tt> - With User Datagram Protocol (UDP), computer
--   applications can send messages (or datagrams) to other hosts on an
--   Internet Protocol (IP) network. Prior communications are not required
--   to set up transmission channels or data paths. Applications that don't
--   require reliable data stream service can use UDP, which provides a
--   connectionless datagram service that emphasizes reduced latency over
--   reliability. If you do require reliable data stream service, use TCP
--   instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>icmp</tt> - Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is used
--   to send error messages and operational information indicating success
--   or failure when communicating with an instance. For example, an error
--   is indicated when an instance could not be reached. When you specify
--   <tt>icmp</tt> as the <tt>protocol</tt>, you must specify the ICMP type
--   using the <tt>fromPort</tt> parameter, and ICMP code using the
--   <tt>toPort</tt> parameter.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:cidrListAliases:InstancePortInfo'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortInfo_cidrListAliases</a> - An alias that defines access
--   for a preconfigured range of IP addresses.
--   
--   The only alias currently supported is <tt>lightsail-connect</tt>,
--   which allows IP addresses of the browser-based RDP/SSH client in the
--   Lightsail console to connect to your instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipv6Cidrs:InstancePortInfo'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortInfo_ipv6Cidrs</a> - The IPv6 address, or range of IPv6
--   addresses (in CIDR notation) that are allowed to connect to an
--   instance through the ports, and the protocol. Only devices with an
--   IPv6 address can connect to an instance through IPv6; otherwise, IPv4
--   should be used.
--   
--   The <tt>cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv4 addresses that are allowed
--   to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:accessDirection:InstancePortInfo'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortInfo_accessDirection</a> - The access direction
--   (<tt>inbound</tt> or <tt>outbound</tt>).
--   
--   Lightsail currently supports only <tt>inbound</tt> access direction.
--   
--   <a>$sel:accessType:InstancePortInfo'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortInfo_accessType</a> - The type of access
--   (<tt>Public</tt> or <tt>Private</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:toPort:InstancePortInfo'</a>, <a>instancePortInfo_toPort</a> -
--   The last port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP code for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP code for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:accessFrom:InstancePortInfo'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortInfo_accessFrom</a> - The location from which access is
--   allowed. For example, <tt>Anywhere (0.0.0.0/0)</tt>, or
--   <tt>Custom</tt> if a specific IP address or range of IP addresses is
--   allowed.
newInstancePortInfo :: InstancePortInfo

-- | Describes open ports on an instance, the IP addresses allowed to
--   connect to the instance through the ports, and the protocol.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInstancePortState</a> smart constructor.
data InstancePortState
InstancePortState' :: Maybe Int -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe PortState -> Maybe NetworkProtocol -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Int -> InstancePortState

-- | Create a value of <a>InstancePortState</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:fromPort:InstancePortState'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortState_fromPort</a> - The first port in a range of open
--   ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP type for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP type for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:cidrs:InstancePortState'</a>, <a>instancePortState_cidrs</a> -
--   The IPv4 address, or range of IPv4 addresses (in CIDR notation) that
--   are allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the
--   protocol.
--   
--   The <tt>ipv6Cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv6 addresses that are
--   allowed to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:state:InstancePortState'</a>, <a>instancePortState_state</a> -
--   Specifies whether the instance port is <tt>open</tt> or
--   <tt>closed</tt>.
--   
--   The port state for Lightsail instances is always <tt>open</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocol:InstancePortState'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortState_protocol</a> - The IP protocol name.
--   
--   The name can be one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>tcp</tt> - Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) provides
--   reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of streamed data between
--   applications running on hosts communicating by an IP network. If you
--   have an application that doesn't require reliable data stream service,
--   use UDP instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>all</tt> - All transport layer protocol types. For more
--   general information, see <a>Transport layer</a> on
--   <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li><tt>udp</tt> - With User Datagram Protocol (UDP), computer
--   applications can send messages (or datagrams) to other hosts on an
--   Internet Protocol (IP) network. Prior communications are not required
--   to set up transmission channels or data paths. Applications that don't
--   require reliable data stream service can use UDP, which provides a
--   connectionless datagram service that emphasizes reduced latency over
--   reliability. If you do require reliable data stream service, use TCP
--   instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>icmp</tt> - Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is used
--   to send error messages and operational information indicating success
--   or failure when communicating with an instance. For example, an error
--   is indicated when an instance could not be reached. When you specify
--   <tt>icmp</tt> as the <tt>protocol</tt>, you must specify the ICMP type
--   using the <tt>fromPort</tt> parameter, and ICMP code using the
--   <tt>toPort</tt> parameter.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:cidrListAliases:InstancePortState'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortState_cidrListAliases</a> - An alias that defines
--   access for a preconfigured range of IP addresses.
--   
--   The only alias currently supported is <tt>lightsail-connect</tt>,
--   which allows IP addresses of the browser-based RDP/SSH client in the
--   Lightsail console to connect to your instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipv6Cidrs:InstancePortState'</a>,
--   <a>instancePortState_ipv6Cidrs</a> - The IPv6 address, or range of
--   IPv6 addresses (in CIDR notation) that are allowed to connect to an
--   instance through the ports, and the protocol. Only devices with an
--   IPv6 address can connect to an instance through IPv6; otherwise, IPv4
--   should be used.
--   
--   The <tt>cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv4 addresses that are allowed
--   to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:toPort:InstancePortState'</a>, <a>instancePortState_toPort</a>
--   - The last port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP code for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP code for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
newInstancePortState :: InstancePortState

-- | Describes an instance snapshot.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newInstanceSnapshot</a> smart constructor.
data InstanceSnapshot
InstanceSnapshot' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe InstanceSnapshotState -> Maybe ResourceType -> Maybe [Disk] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe ResourceLocation -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Tag] -> InstanceSnapshot

-- | Create a value of <a>InstanceSnapshot</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:fromBlueprintId:InstanceSnapshot'</a>,
--   <a>instanceSnapshot_fromBlueprintId</a> - The blueprint ID from which
--   you created the snapshot (e.g., <tt>os_debian_8_3</tt>). A blueprint
--   is a virtual private server (or <i>instance</i>) image used to create
--   instances quickly.
--   
--   <a>$sel:isFromAutoSnapshot:InstanceSnapshot'</a>,
--   <a>instanceSnapshot_isFromAutoSnapshot</a> - A Boolean value
--   indicating whether the snapshot was created from an automatic
--   snapshot.
--   
--   <a>$sel:state:InstanceSnapshot'</a>, <a>instanceSnapshot_state</a> -
--   The state the snapshot is in.
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceType:InstanceSnapshot'</a>,
--   <a>instanceSnapshot_resourceType</a> - The type of resource (usually
--   <tt>InstanceSnapshot</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:fromAttachedDisks:InstanceSnapshot'</a>,
--   <a>instanceSnapshot_fromAttachedDisks</a> - An array of disk objects
--   containing information about all block storage disks.
--   
--   <a>$sel:arn:InstanceSnapshot'</a>, <a>instanceSnapshot_arn</a> - The
--   Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the snapshot (e.g.,
--   <tt>arn:aws:lightsail:us-east-2:123456789101:InstanceSnapshot/d23b5706-3322-4d83-81e5-12345EXAMPLE</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:createdAt:InstanceSnapshot'</a>,
--   <a>instanceSnapshot_createdAt</a> - The timestamp when the snapshot
--   was created (e.g., <tt>1479907467.024</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:location:InstanceSnapshot'</a>,
--   <a>instanceSnapshot_location</a> - The region name and Availability
--   Zone where you created the snapshot.
--   
--   <a>$sel:progress:InstanceSnapshot'</a>,
--   <a>instanceSnapshot_progress</a> - The progress of the snapshot.
--   
--   This is populated only for disk snapshots, and is <tt>null</tt> for
--   instance snapshots.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:InstanceSnapshot'</a>, <a>instanceSnapshot_name</a> - The
--   name of the snapshot.
--   
--   <a>$sel:fromBundleId:InstanceSnapshot'</a>,
--   <a>instanceSnapshot_fromBundleId</a> - The bundle ID from which you
--   created the snapshot (e.g., <tt>micro_1_0</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:sizeInGb:InstanceSnapshot'</a>,
--   <a>instanceSnapshot_sizeInGb</a> - The size in GB of the SSD.
--   
--   <a>$sel:supportCode:InstanceSnapshot'</a>,
--   <a>instanceSnapshot_supportCode</a> - The support code. Include this
--   code in your email to support when you have questions about an
--   instance or another resource in Lightsail. This code enables our
--   support team to look up your Lightsail information more easily.
--   
--   <a>$sel:fromInstanceArn:InstanceSnapshot'</a>,
--   <a>instanceSnapshot_fromInstanceArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name
--   (ARN) of the instance from which the snapshot was created (e.g.,
--   <tt>arn:aws:lightsail:us-east-2:123456789101:Instance/64b8404c-ccb1-430b-8daf-12345EXAMPLE</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:fromInstanceName:InstanceSnapshot'</a>,
--   <a>instanceSnapshot_fromInstanceName</a> - The instance from which the
--   snapshot was created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:InstanceSnapshot'</a>, <a>instanceSnapshot_tags</a> - The
--   tag keys and optional values for the resource. For more information
--   about tags in Lightsail, see the <a>Amazon Lightsail Developer
--   Guide</a>.
newInstanceSnapshot :: InstanceSnapshot

newKeyPair :: KeyPair

-- | Describes an Amazon Lightsail content delivery network (CDN)
--   distribution.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newLightsailDistribution</a> smart constructor.
data LightsailDistribution
LightsailDistribution' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Origin -> Maybe Text -> Maybe ResourceType -> Maybe Text -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe ResourceLocation -> Maybe CacheSettings -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe IpAddressType -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe CacheBehavior -> Maybe [CacheBehaviorPerPath] -> Maybe [Tag] -> LightsailDistribution

-- | Create a value of <a>LightsailDistribution</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:status:LightsailDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>lightsailDistribution_status</a> - The status of the distribution.
--   
--   <a>$sel:origin:LightsailDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>lightsailDistribution_origin</a> - An object that describes the
--   origin resource of the distribution, such as a Lightsail instance or
--   load balancer.
--   
--   The distribution pulls, caches, and serves content from the origin.
--   
--   <a>$sel:certificateName:LightsailDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>lightsailDistribution_certificateName</a> - The name of the SSL/TLS
--   certificate attached to the distribution, if any.
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceType:LightsailDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>lightsailDistribution_resourceType</a> - The Lightsail resource
--   type (e.g., <tt>Distribution</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:arn:LightsailDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>lightsailDistribution_arn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of
--   the distribution.
--   
--   <a>$sel:createdAt:LightsailDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>lightsailDistribution_createdAt</a> - The timestamp when the
--   distribution was created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:location:LightsailDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>lightsailDistribution_location</a> - An object that describes the
--   location of the distribution, such as the AWS Region and Availability
--   Zone.
--   
--   Lightsail distributions are global resources that can reference an
--   origin in any AWS Region, and distribute its content globally.
--   However, all distributions are located in the <tt>us-east-1</tt>
--   Region.
--   
--   <a>$sel:cacheBehaviorSettings:LightsailDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>lightsailDistribution_cacheBehaviorSettings</a> - An object that
--   describes the cache behavior settings of the distribution.
--   
--   <a>$sel:alternativeDomainNames:LightsailDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>lightsailDistribution_alternativeDomainNames</a> - The alternate
--   domain names of the distribution.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bundleId:LightsailDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>lightsailDistribution_bundleId</a> - The ID of the bundle currently
--   applied to the distribution.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ableToUpdateBundle:LightsailDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>lightsailDistribution_ableToUpdateBundle</a> - Indicates whether
--   the bundle that is currently applied to your distribution, specified
--   using the <tt>distributionName</tt> parameter, can be changed to
--   another bundle.
--   
--   Use the <tt>UpdateDistributionBundle</tt> action to change your
--   distribution's bundle.
--   
--   <a>$sel:originPublicDNS:LightsailDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>lightsailDistribution_originPublicDNS</a> - The public DNS of the
--   origin.
--   
--   <a>$sel:domainName:LightsailDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>lightsailDistribution_domainName</a> - The domain name of the
--   distribution.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:LightsailDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>lightsailDistribution_name</a> - The name of the distribution.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipAddressType:LightsailDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>lightsailDistribution_ipAddressType</a> - The IP address type of
--   the distribution.
--   
--   The possible values are <tt>ipv4</tt> for IPv4 only, and
--   <tt>dualstack</tt> for IPv4 and IPv6.
--   
--   <a>$sel:isEnabled:LightsailDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>lightsailDistribution_isEnabled</a> - Indicates whether the
--   distribution is enabled.
--   
--   <a>$sel:supportCode:LightsailDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>lightsailDistribution_supportCode</a> - The support code. Include
--   this code in your email to support when you have questions about your
--   Lightsail distribution. This code enables our support team to look up
--   your Lightsail information more easily.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultCacheBehavior:LightsailDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>lightsailDistribution_defaultCacheBehavior</a> - An object that
--   describes the default cache behavior of the distribution.
--   
--   <a>$sel:cacheBehaviors:LightsailDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>lightsailDistribution_cacheBehaviors</a> - An array of objects that
--   describe the per-path cache behavior of the distribution.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:LightsailDistribution'</a>,
--   <a>lightsailDistribution_tags</a> - The tag keys and optional values
--   for the resource. For more information about tags in Lightsail, see
--   the <a>Amazon Lightsail Developer Guide</a>.
newLightsailDistribution :: LightsailDistribution

-- | Describes a load balancer.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newLoadBalancer</a> smart constructor.
data LoadBalancer
LoadBalancer' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe LoadBalancerState -> Maybe ResourceType -> Maybe Text -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe ResourceLocation -> Maybe Int -> Maybe (HashMap LoadBalancerAttributeName Text) -> Maybe LoadBalancerProtocol -> Maybe [LoadBalancerTlsCertificateSummary] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe IpAddressType -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Int] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [InstanceHealthSummary] -> Maybe [Tag] -> LoadBalancer

-- | Create a value of <a>LoadBalancer</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:healthCheckPath:LoadBalancer'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancer_healthCheckPath</a> - The path you specified to
--   perform your health checks. If no path is specified, the load balancer
--   tries to make a request to the default (root) page.
--   
--   <a>$sel:state:LoadBalancer'</a>, <a>loadBalancer_state</a> - The
--   status of your load balancer. Valid values are below.
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceType:LoadBalancer'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancer_resourceType</a> - The resource type (e.g.,
--   <tt>LoadBalancer</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:arn:LoadBalancer'</a>, <a>loadBalancer_arn</a> - The Amazon
--   Resource Name (ARN) of the load balancer.
--   
--   <a>$sel:createdAt:LoadBalancer'</a>, <a>loadBalancer_createdAt</a> -
--   The date when your load balancer was created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:location:LoadBalancer'</a>, <a>loadBalancer_location</a> - The
--   AWS Region where your load balancer was created (e.g.,
--   <tt>us-east-2a</tt>). Lightsail automatically creates your load
--   balancer across Availability Zones.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instancePort:LoadBalancer'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancer_instancePort</a> - The port where the load balancer
--   will direct traffic to your Lightsail instances. For HTTP traffic,
--   it's port 80. For HTTPS traffic, it's port 443.
--   
--   <a>$sel:configurationOptions:LoadBalancer'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancer_configurationOptions</a> - A string to string map of
--   the configuration options for your load balancer. Valid values are
--   listed below.
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocol:LoadBalancer'</a>, <a>loadBalancer_protocol</a> - The
--   protocol you have enabled for your load balancer. Valid values are
--   below.
--   
--   You can't just have <tt>HTTP_HTTPS</tt>, but you can have just
--   <tt>HTTP</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tlsCertificateSummaries:LoadBalancer'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancer_tlsCertificateSummaries</a> - An array of
--   LoadBalancerTlsCertificateSummary objects that provide additional
--   information about the SSL/TLS certificates. For example, if
--   <tt>true</tt>, the certificate is attached to the load balancer.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:LoadBalancer'</a>, <a>loadBalancer_name</a> - The name of
--   the load balancer (e.g., <tt>my-load-balancer</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipAddressType:LoadBalancer'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancer_ipAddressType</a> - The IP address type of the load
--   balancer.
--   
--   The possible values are <tt>ipv4</tt> for IPv4 only, and
--   <tt>dualstack</tt> for IPv4 and IPv6.
--   
--   <a>$sel:supportCode:LoadBalancer'</a>, <a>loadBalancer_supportCode</a>
--   - The support code. Include this code in your email to support when
--   you have questions about your Lightsail load balancer. This code
--   enables our support team to look up your Lightsail information more
--   easily.
--   
--   <a>$sel:publicPorts:LoadBalancer'</a>, <a>loadBalancer_publicPorts</a>
--   - An array of public port settings for your load balancer. For HTTP,
--   use port 80. For HTTPS, use port 443.
--   
--   <a>$sel:dnsName:LoadBalancer'</a>, <a>loadBalancer_dnsName</a> - The
--   DNS name of your Lightsail load balancer.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceHealthSummary:LoadBalancer'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancer_instanceHealthSummary</a> - An array of
--   InstanceHealthSummary objects describing the health of the load
--   balancer.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:LoadBalancer'</a>, <a>loadBalancer_tags</a> - The tag
--   keys and optional values for the resource. For more information about
--   tags in Lightsail, see the <a>Amazon Lightsail Developer Guide</a>.
newLoadBalancer :: LoadBalancer

-- | Describes a load balancer SSL/TLS certificate.
--   
--   TLS is just an updated, more secure version of Secure Socket Layer
--   (SSL).
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newLoadBalancerTlsCertificate</a> smart constructor.
data LoadBalancerTlsCertificate
LoadBalancerTlsCertificate' :: Maybe LoadBalancerTlsCertificateFailureReason -> Maybe Text -> Maybe LoadBalancerTlsCertificateStatus -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe ResourceType -> Maybe Text -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe ResourceLocation -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe LoadBalancerTlsCertificateRevocationReason -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe LoadBalancerTlsCertificateRenewalSummary -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [LoadBalancerTlsCertificateDomainValidationRecord] -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Tag] -> Maybe POSIX -> LoadBalancerTlsCertificate

-- | Create a value of <a>LoadBalancerTlsCertificate</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:failureReason:LoadBalancerTlsCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificate_failureReason</a> - The validation
--   failure reason, if any, of the certificate.
--   
--   The following failure reasons are possible:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>NO_AVAILABLE_CONTACTS</tt></b> - This failure applies to
--   email validation, which is not available for Lightsail
--   certificates.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>ADDITIONAL_VERIFICATION_REQUIRED</tt></b> - Lightsail
--   requires additional information to process this certificate request.
--   This can happen as a fraud-protection measure, such as when the domain
--   ranks within the Alexa top 1000 websites. To provide the required
--   information, use the <a>AWS Support Center</a> to contact AWS
--   Support.You cannot request a certificate for Amazon-owned domain names
--   such as those ending in amazonaws.com, cloudfront.net, or
--   elasticbeanstalk.com.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>DOMAIN_NOT_ALLOWED</tt></b> - One or more of the domain
--   names in the certificate request was reported as an unsafe domain by
--   <a>VirusTotal</a>. To correct the problem, search for your domain name
--   on the <a>VirusTotal</a> website. If your domain is reported as
--   suspicious, see <a>Google Help for Hacked Websites</a> to learn what
--   you can do.If you believe that the result is a false positive, notify
--   the organization that is reporting the domain. VirusTotal is an
--   aggregate of several antivirus and URL scanners and cannot remove your
--   domain from a block list itself. After you correct the problem and the
--   VirusTotal registry has been updated, request a new certificate.If you
--   see this error and your domain is not included in the VirusTotal list,
--   visit the <a>AWS Support Center</a> and create a case.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>INVALID_PUBLIC_DOMAIN</tt></b> - One or more of the domain
--   names in the certificate request is not valid. Typically, this is
--   because a domain name in the request is not a valid top-level domain.
--   Try to request a certificate again, correcting any spelling errors or
--   typos that were in the failed request, and ensure that all domain
--   names in the request are for valid top-level domains. For example, you
--   cannot request a certificate for <tt>example.invalidpublicdomain</tt>
--   because <tt>invalidpublicdomain</tt> is not a valid top-level
--   domain.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>OTHER</tt></b> - Typically, this failure occurs when there
--   is a typographical error in one or more of the domain names in the
--   certificate request. Try to request a certificate again, correcting
--   any spelling errors or typos that were in the failed request.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:subject:LoadBalancerTlsCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificate_subject</a> - The name of the entity
--   that is associated with the public key contained in the certificate.
--   
--   <a>$sel:status:LoadBalancerTlsCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificate_status</a> - The validation status of
--   the SSL/TLS certificate. Valid values are below.
--   
--   <a>$sel:subjectAlternativeNames:LoadBalancerTlsCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificate_subjectAlternativeNames</a> - An array
--   of strings that specify the alternate domains (e.g.,
--   <tt>example2.com</tt>) and subdomains (e.g.,
--   <tt>blog.example.com</tt>) for the certificate.
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceType:LoadBalancerTlsCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificate_resourceType</a> - The resource type
--   (e.g., <tt>LoadBalancerTlsCertificate</tt>).
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>Instance</tt></b> - A Lightsail instance (a virtual private
--   server)</li>
--   <li><b><tt>StaticIp</tt></b> - A static IP address</li>
--   <li><b><tt>KeyPair</tt></b> - The key pair used to connect to a
--   Lightsail instance</li>
--   <li><b><tt>InstanceSnapshot</tt></b> - A Lightsail instance
--   snapshot</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Domain</tt></b> - A DNS zone</li>
--   <li><b><tt>PeeredVpc</tt></b> - A peered VPC</li>
--   <li><b><tt>LoadBalancer</tt></b> - A Lightsail load balancer</li>
--   <li><b><tt>LoadBalancerTlsCertificate</tt></b> - An SSL/TLS
--   certificate associated with a Lightsail load balancer</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Disk</tt></b> - A Lightsail block storage disk</li>
--   <li><b><tt>DiskSnapshot</tt></b> - A block storage disk snapshot</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:arn:LoadBalancerTlsCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificate_arn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name (ARN)
--   of the SSL/TLS certificate.
--   
--   <a>$sel:createdAt:LoadBalancerTlsCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificate_createdAt</a> - The time when you
--   created your SSL/TLS certificate.
--   
--   <a>$sel:location:LoadBalancerTlsCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificate_location</a> - The AWS Region and
--   Availability Zone where you created your certificate.
--   
--   <a>$sel:loadBalancerName:LoadBalancerTlsCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificate_loadBalancerName</a> - The load balancer
--   name where your SSL/TLS certificate is attached.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serial:LoadBalancerTlsCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificate_serial</a> - The serial number of the
--   certificate.
--   
--   <a>$sel:isAttached:LoadBalancerTlsCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificate_isAttached</a> - When <tt>true</tt>, the
--   SSL/TLS certificate is attached to the Lightsail load balancer.
--   
--   <a>$sel:revokedAt:LoadBalancerTlsCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificate_revokedAt</a> - The timestamp when the
--   certificate was revoked. This value is present only when the
--   certificate status is <tt>REVOKED</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:notBefore:LoadBalancerTlsCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificate_notBefore</a> - The timestamp when the
--   SSL/TLS certificate is first valid.
--   
--   <a>$sel:revocationReason:LoadBalancerTlsCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificate_revocationReason</a> - The reason the
--   certificate was revoked. This value is present only when the
--   certificate status is <tt>REVOKED</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:domainName:LoadBalancerTlsCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificate_domainName</a> - The domain name for
--   your SSL/TLS certificate.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:LoadBalancerTlsCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificate_name</a> - The name of the SSL/TLS
--   certificate (e.g., <tt>my-certificate</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:renewalSummary:LoadBalancerTlsCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificate_renewalSummary</a> - An object that
--   describes the status of the certificate renewal managed by Lightsail.
--   
--   <a>$sel:supportCode:LoadBalancerTlsCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificate_supportCode</a> - The support code.
--   Include this code in your email to support when you have questions
--   about your Lightsail load balancer or SSL/TLS certificate. This code
--   enables our support team to look up your Lightsail information more
--   easily.
--   
--   <a>$sel:domainValidationRecords:LoadBalancerTlsCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificate_domainValidationRecords</a> - An array
--   of LoadBalancerTlsCertificateDomainValidationRecord objects describing
--   the records.
--   
--   <a>$sel:issuedAt:LoadBalancerTlsCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificate_issuedAt</a> - The time when the SSL/TLS
--   certificate was issued.
--   
--   <a>$sel:keyAlgorithm:LoadBalancerTlsCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificate_keyAlgorithm</a> - The algorithm used to
--   generate the key pair (the public and private key).
--   
--   <a>$sel:signatureAlgorithm:LoadBalancerTlsCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificate_signatureAlgorithm</a> - The algorithm
--   that was used to sign the certificate.
--   
--   <a>$sel:issuer:LoadBalancerTlsCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificate_issuer</a> - The issuer of the
--   certificate.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:LoadBalancerTlsCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificate_tags</a> - The tag keys and optional
--   values for the resource. For more information about tags in Lightsail,
--   see the <a>Amazon Lightsail Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:notAfter:LoadBalancerTlsCertificate'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificate_notAfter</a> - The timestamp when the
--   SSL/TLS certificate expires.
newLoadBalancerTlsCertificate :: LoadBalancerTlsCertificate

--   validation.
newLoadBalancerTlsCertificateDomainValidationRecord :: LoadBalancerTlsCertificateDomainValidationRecord

-- | Contains information about the status of Lightsail's managed renewal
--   for the certificate.
--   
--   The renewal status of the certificate.
--   
--   The following renewal status are possible:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>PendingAutoRenewal</tt></b> - Lightsail is attempting to
--   automatically validate the domain names in the certificate. No further
--   action is required.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>PendingValidation</tt></b> - Lightsail couldn't
--   automatically validate one or more domain names in the certificate.
--   You must take action to validate these domain names or the certificate
--   won't be renewed. If you used DNS validation, check to make sure your
--   certificate's domain validation records exist in your domain's DNS,
--   and that your certificate remains in use.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Success</tt></b> - All domain names in the certificate are
--   validated, and Lightsail renewed the certificate. No further action is
--   required.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Failed</tt></b> - One or more domain names were not
--   validated before the certificate expired, and Lightsail did not renew
--   the certificate. You can request a new certificate using the
--   <tt>CreateCertificate</tt> action.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newLoadBalancerTlsCertificateRenewalSummary</a> smart
--   constructor.
data LoadBalancerTlsCertificateRenewalSummary
LoadBalancerTlsCertificateRenewalSummary' :: Maybe LoadBalancerTlsCertificateRenewalStatus -> Maybe [LoadBalancerTlsCertificateDomainValidationOption] -> LoadBalancerTlsCertificateRenewalSummary

-- | Create a value of <a>LoadBalancerTlsCertificateRenewalSummary</a> with
--   all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:renewalStatus:LoadBalancerTlsCertificateRenewalSummary'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificateRenewalSummary_renewalStatus</a> - The
--   renewal status of the certificate.
--   
--   The following renewal status are possible:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b><tt>PendingAutoRenewal</tt></b> - Lightsail is attempting to
--   automatically validate the domain names of the certificate. No further
--   action is required.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>PendingValidation</tt></b> - Lightsail couldn't
--   automatically validate one or more domain names of the certificate.
--   You must take action to validate these domain names or the certificate
--   won't be renewed. Check to make sure your certificate's domain
--   validation records exist in your domain's DNS, and that your
--   certificate remains in use.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Success</tt></b> - All domain names in the certificate are
--   validated, and Lightsail renewed the certificate. No further action is
--   required.</li>
--   <li><b><tt>Failed</tt></b> - One or more domain names were not
--   validated before the certificate expired, and Lightsail did not renew
--   the certificate. You can request a new certificate using the
--   <tt>CreateCertificate</tt> action.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   
--   <a>$sel:domainValidationOptions:LoadBalancerTlsCertificateRenewalSummary'</a>,
--   <a>loadBalancerTlsCertificateRenewalSummary_domainValidationOptions</a>
--   - Contains information about the validation of each domain name in the
--   certificate, as it pertains to Lightsail's managed renewal. This is
--   different from the initial validation that occurs as a result of the
--   RequestCertificate request.
newLoadBalancerTlsCertificateRenewalSummary :: LoadBalancerTlsCertificateRenewalSummary

-- | Describes the origin resource of an Amazon Lightsail content delivery
--   network (CDN) distribution.

--   a worldwide network of edge servers.

data Origin

-- | The password data for the Windows Server-based instance, including the
--   ciphertext and the key pair name.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newPasswordData</a> smart constructor.
data PasswordData
PasswordData' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> PasswordData

-- | Create a value of <a>PasswordData</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:keyPairName:PasswordData'</a>, <a>passwordData_keyPairName</a>
--   - The name of the key pair that you used when creating your instance.
--   If no key pair name was specified when creating the instance,
--   Lightsail uses the default key pair
--   (<tt>LightsailDefaultKeyPair</tt>).
--   
--   If you are using a custom key pair, you need to use your own means of
--   decrypting your password using the <tt>ciphertext</tt>. Lightsail
--   creates the ciphertext by encrypting your password with the public key
--   part of this key pair.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ciphertext:PasswordData'</a>, <a>passwordData_ciphertext</a> -
--   The encrypted password. Ciphertext will be an empty string if access
--   to your new instance is not ready yet. When you create an instance, it
--   can take up to 15 minutes for the instance to be ready.
--   
--   If you use the default key pair (<tt>LightsailDefaultKeyPair</tt>),
--   the decrypted password will be available in the password field.
--   
--   If you are using a custom key pair, you need to use your own means of
--   decryption.
--   
--   If you change the Administrator password on the instance, Lightsail
--   will continue to return the original ciphertext value. When accessing
--   the instance using RDP, you need to manually enter the Administrator
--   password after changing it from the default.
newPasswordData :: PasswordData

-- | Describes ports to open on an instance, the IP addresses allowed to
--   connect to the instance through the ports, and the protocol.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newPortInfo</a> smart constructor.
data PortInfo
PortInfo' :: Maybe Int -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe NetworkProtocol -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Int -> PortInfo

-- | Create a value of <a>PortInfo</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:fromPort:PortInfo'</a>, <a>portInfo_fromPort</a> - The first
--   port in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP type for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP type for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:cidrs:PortInfo'</a>, <a>portInfo_cidrs</a> - The IPv4 address,
--   or range of IPv4 addresses (in CIDR notation) that are allowed to
--   connect to an instance through the ports, and the protocol.
--   
--   The <tt>ipv6Cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv6 addresses that are
--   allowed to connect to an instance.
--   
--   Examples:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>To allow the IP address <tt>192.0.2.44</tt>, specify
--   <tt>192.0.2.44</tt> or <tt>192.0.2.44/32</tt>.</li>
--   <li>To allow the IP addresses <tt>192.0.2.0</tt> to
--   <tt>192.0.2.255</tt>, specify <tt>192.0.2.0/24</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocol:PortInfo'</a>, <a>portInfo_protocol</a> - The IP
--   protocol name.
--   
--   The name can be one of the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>tcp</tt> - Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) provides
--   reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of streamed data between
--   applications running on hosts communicating by an IP network. If you
--   have an application that doesn't require reliable data stream service,
--   use UDP instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>all</tt> - All transport layer protocol types. For more
--   general information, see <a>Transport layer</a> on
--   <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li><tt>udp</tt> - With User Datagram Protocol (UDP), computer
--   applications can send messages (or datagrams) to other hosts on an
--   Internet Protocol (IP) network. Prior communications are not required
--   to set up transmission channels or data paths. Applications that don't
--   require reliable data stream service can use UDP, which provides a
--   connectionless datagram service that emphasizes reduced latency over
--   reliability. If you do require reliable data stream service, use TCP
--   instead.</li>
--   <li><tt>icmp</tt> - Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is used
--   to send error messages and operational information indicating success
--   or failure when communicating with an instance. For example, an error
--   is indicated when an instance could not be reached. When you specify
--   <tt>icmp</tt> as the <tt>protocol</tt>, you must specify the ICMP type
--   using the <tt>fromPort</tt> parameter, and ICMP code using the
--   <tt>toPort</tt> parameter.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:cidrListAliases:PortInfo'</a>, <a>portInfo_cidrListAliases</a>
--   - An alias that defines access for a preconfigured range of IP
--   addresses.
--   
--   The only alias currently supported is <tt>lightsail-connect</tt>,
--   which allows IP addresses of the browser-based RDP/SSH client in the
--   Lightsail console to connect to your instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipv6Cidrs:PortInfo'</a>, <a>portInfo_ipv6Cidrs</a> - The IPv6
--   address, or range of IPv6 addresses (in CIDR notation) that are
--   allowed to connect to an instance through the ports, and the protocol.
--   Only devices with an IPv6 address can connect to an instance through
--   IPv6; otherwise, IPv4 should be used.
--   
--   The <tt>cidrs</tt> parameter lists the IPv4 addresses that are allowed
--   to connect to an instance.
--   
--   For more information about CIDR block notation, see <a>Classless
--   Inter-Domain Routing</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:toPort:PortInfo'</a>, <a>portInfo_toPort</a> - The last port
--   in a range of open ports on an instance.
--   
--   Allowed ports:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>TCP and UDP - <tt>0</tt> to <tt>65535</tt></li>
--   <li>ICMP - The ICMP code for IPv4 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>8</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMP type), and <tt>-1</tt> as
--   the <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMP code), to enable ICMP Ping. For more
--   information, see <a>Control Messages</a> on <i>Wikipedia</i>.</li>
--   <li>ICMPv6 - The ICMP code for IPv6 addresses. For example, specify
--   <tt>128</tt> as the <tt>fromPort</tt> (ICMPv6 type), and <tt>0</tt> as
--   <tt>toPort</tt> (ICMPv6 code). For more information, see <a>Internet
--   Control Message Protocol for IPv6</a>.</li>
--   </ul>
newPortInfo :: PortInfo

-- | Describes the query string parameters that an Amazon Lightsail content
--   delivery network (CDN) distribution to bases caching on.
--   
--   For the query strings that you specify, your distribution caches
--   separate versions of the specified content based on the query string
--   values in viewer requests.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newQueryStringObject</a> smart constructor.
data QueryStringObject
QueryStringObject' :: Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Bool -> QueryStringObject

-- | Create a value of <a>QueryStringObject</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:queryStringsAllowList:QueryStringObject'</a>,
--   <a>queryStringObject_queryStringsAllowList</a> - The specific query
--   strings that the distribution forwards to the origin.
--   
--   Your distribution will cache content based on the specified query
--   strings.
--   
--   If the <tt>option</tt> parameter is true, then your distribution
--   forwards all query strings, regardless of what you specify using the
--   <tt>queryStringsAllowList</tt> parameter.
--   
--   <a>$sel:option:QueryStringObject'</a>, <a>queryStringObject_option</a>
--   - Indicates whether the distribution forwards and caches based on
--   query strings.
newQueryStringObject :: QueryStringObject

-- | Describes the AWS Region.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRegionInfo</a> smart constructor.
data RegionInfo
RegionInfo' :: Maybe [AvailabilityZone] -> Maybe RegionName -> Maybe [AvailabilityZone] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> RegionInfo

-- | Create a value of <a>RegionInfo</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:availabilityZones:RegionInfo'</a>,
--   <a>regionInfo_availabilityZones</a> - The Availability Zones. Follows
--   the format <tt>us-east-2a</tt> (case-sensitive).
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:RegionInfo'</a>, <a>regionInfo_name</a> - The region name
--   (e.g., <tt>us-east-2</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:relationalDatabaseAvailabilityZones:RegionInfo'</a>,
--   <a>regionInfo_relationalDatabaseAvailabilityZones</a> - The
--   Availability Zones for databases. Follows the format
--   <tt>us-east-2a</tt> (case-sensitive).
--   
--   <a>$sel:displayName:RegionInfo'</a>, <a>regionInfo_displayName</a> -
--   The display name (e.g., <tt>Ohio</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:continentCode:RegionInfo'</a>, <a>regionInfo_continentCode</a>
--   - The continent code (e.g., <tt>NA</tt>, meaning North America).
--   
--   <a>$sel:description:RegionInfo'</a>, <a>regionInfo_description</a> -
--   The description of the AWS Region (e.g., <tt>This region is
--   recommended to serve users in the eastern United States and eastern
--   Canada</tt>).
newRegionInfo :: RegionInfo

-- | Describes a database.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRelationalDatabase</a> smart constructor.
data RelationalDatabase
RelationalDatabase' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe RelationalDatabaseEndpoint -> Maybe Text -> Maybe ResourceType -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe ResourceLocation -> Maybe Text -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [PendingMaintenanceAction] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe PendingModifiedRelationalDatabaseValues -> Maybe Text -> Maybe RelationalDatabaseHardware -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Tag] -> RelationalDatabase

-- | Create a value of <a>RelationalDatabase</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:engineVersion:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_engineVersion</a> - The database engine version
--   (for example, <tt>5.7.23</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:relationalDatabaseBundleId:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_relationalDatabaseBundleId</a> - The bundle ID
--   for the database. A bundle describes the performance specifications
--   for your database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:masterEndpoint:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_masterEndpoint</a> - The master endpoint for the
--   database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:state:RelationalDatabase'</a>, <a>relationalDatabase_state</a>
--   - Describes the current state of the database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceType:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_resourceType</a> - The Lightsail resource type
--   for the database (for example, <tt>RelationalDatabase</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:publiclyAccessible:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_publiclyAccessible</a> - A Boolean value
--   indicating whether the database is publicly accessible.
--   
--   <a>$sel:masterUsername:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_masterUsername</a> - The master user name of the
--   database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:arn:RelationalDatabase'</a>, <a>relationalDatabase_arn</a> -
--   The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:createdAt:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_createdAt</a> - The timestamp when the database
--   was created. Formatted in Unix time.
--   
--   <a>$sel:location:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_location</a> - The Region name and Availability
--   Zone where the database is located.
--   
--   <a>$sel:engine:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_engine</a> - The database software (for example,
--   <tt>MySQL</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:latestRestorableTime:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_latestRestorableTime</a> - The latest point in
--   time to which the database can be restored. Formatted in Unix time.
--   
--   <a>$sel:preferredMaintenanceWindow:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_preferredMaintenanceWindow</a> - The weekly time
--   range during which system maintenance can occur on the database.
--   
--   In the format <tt>ddd:hh24:mi-ddd:hh24:mi</tt>. For example,
--   <tt>Tue:17:00-Tue:17:30</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:relationalDatabaseBlueprintId:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_relationalDatabaseBlueprintId</a> - The
--   blueprint ID for the database. A blueprint describes the major engine
--   version of a database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:caCertificateIdentifier:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_caCertificateIdentifier</a> - The certificate
--   associated with the database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:RelationalDatabase'</a>, <a>relationalDatabase_name</a> -
--   The unique name of the database resource in Lightsail.
--   
--   <a>$sel:backupRetentionEnabled:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_backupRetentionEnabled</a> - A Boolean value
--   indicating whether automated backup retention is enabled for the
--   database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:preferredBackupWindow:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_preferredBackupWindow</a> - The daily time range
--   during which automated backups are created for the database (for
--   example, <tt>16:00-16:30</tt>).
--   
--   <a>$sel:pendingMaintenanceActions:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_pendingMaintenanceActions</a> - Describes the
--   pending maintenance actions for the database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:supportCode:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_supportCode</a> - The support code for the
--   database. Include this code in your email to support when you have
--   questions about a database in Lightsail. This code enables our support
--   team to look up your Lightsail information more easily.
--   
--   <a>$sel:secondaryAvailabilityZone:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_secondaryAvailabilityZone</a> - Describes the
--   secondary Availability Zone of a high availability database.
--   
--   The secondary database is used for failover support of a high
--   availability database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:pendingModifiedValues:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_pendingModifiedValues</a> - Describes pending
--   database value modifications.
--   
--   <a>$sel:masterDatabaseName:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_masterDatabaseName</a> - The name of the master
--   database created when the Lightsail database resource is created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:hardware:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_hardware</a> - Describes the hardware of the
--   database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:parameterApplyStatus:RelationalDatabase'</a>,
--   <a>relationalDatabase_parameterApplyStatus</a> - The status of
--   parameter updates for the database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:RelationalDatabase'</a>, <a>relationalDatabase_tags</a> -
--   The tag keys and optional values for the resource. For more
--   information about tags in Lightsail, see the <a>Amazon Lightsail
--   Developer Guide</a>.
newRelationalDatabase :: RelationalDatabase

--
